38856294.review:
Hexcells Infinite is the final Hexcells game and boasts a random puzzle generator along with its own set of hand-crafted puzzles. But how good is it? This is what I think of Hexcells Infinite.

Very good, in fact. As you would expect with a third entry it is the most feature complete and the best experience, in my opinion. It strikes a nice balance between the last two games in terms of difficulty and with it's random generator, you can play this game indefinitely. Everything you have come to expect from Hexcells is here, and it's brilliant. 

Like before, your task remains the same; clear the board by colouring or deleting hexes, using the set rules of the game. You know the drill, troops. I think this title does a better job of mixing in all kinds of puzzles in terms of difficulty. For instance, I really struggled with one but afterward I didn't have any problems with the one after that. In Hexcells Plus it would have bludgeoned you to death daring you to take it on with your logic. My logic sucks. So no surprises I enjoyed this one more. There are fiendishly difficult puzzles though, don't worry about that. 

The real reason why I love this one the most though is the random generator. This thing is awesome. It uses an eight digit seed to randomly assign you new puzzles at the click of a mouse. You could even feasibly play just one every day using the different dates as the seed. Simple but brilliant. I often log in and play five or so at a time, listening to music and just relaxing. The random puzzles aren't as hard as the hand-crafted ones, or as unique, but you occasionally get one that keeps you on your toes, just to make sure you're paying attention. Love it.

Other cool little features include in-level saving. I never realized this was needed until it was there. Now you can exit a puzzle anytime and pick up when you play again. Simple and effective. Also, the area of effect hexes(as I like to call them,) now have a toggle so the area that appears is outlined by a black line. This makes it much easier to see hexes in the zone without squinting. Excellent. 

Overall, this is the best Hexcells experience. With 36 puzzle of its own, and with its random generator, there is enough here to keep you occupied for some time. I have no doubt this will remain my favourite puzzles game, and I'm a little sad there is no more Hexcells. In the meantime, however, I'll continue solving random puzzles and having a blast. Do yourself a favour and pick this one up. You won't regret it.

38353383.review: Hexcells Infinite is yet another standalone expansion to Hexcells, and like Hexcells Plus, just adds a whole new set of puzzles without really improving the game in any way. All of the same shortcomings are still present and accounted for: menu icons are still unintuitive and lack any sort of tooltip to explain what they do; completed levels still do not track how many mistakes were made; the soundtrack is still the same one track on a loop; and there is still no "maybe" marker for bigger, tougher puzzles. The menu just felt broken in general, with clipped text and overlapping elements. Difficulty-wise, Infinite is on par with Plus - much tougher than the original game, but unlike previous games, there was at least one puzzle that required a 50-50 guess to complete. I looked at the last couple of unopened cells every which way and there were simply not enough clues to deduce where the blue cells hide, which is disappointing in a puzzle game. The only real addition is a random puzzle generator, and it is rather underwhelming. All of the puzzles I generated were pretty much identical blobs of cells that were far too easy to solve and got repetitive very fast. It is a nice addition for those who can’t get enough of these puzzles, but it would be much more valuable if the generator could come up with a greater variation of tougher patterns. All in all, though, the core gameplay of Hexcells Infinite is still just as good as its predecessors and is still definitely worth buying.

Мэтью Браун сделал чудесные игры-головоломки. Рекомендую брать сразу все три Hexcells, Hexcells Plus и Hexcells Infinite. А ещё лучше весь бандл пазлов от этого автора (это ещё дополнительно Squarecells и Crosscells).
Если вам нравится сапёр - Hexcells вам зайдёт однозначно. Сложность идёт по нарастающей от Hexcells, затем Hexcells Plus и наконец Hexcells Infinite. Первые две мне удалось пройти идеально, а вот последнюю пока нет. Реиграбельность у игр хорошая, ибо даже в пройденных по несколько раз уровнях у вас не получится запомнить расположение "мин". Плюс ко всему в Hexcells Infinite есть генератор уровней, что делает игру бесконечной.

Игры этой серии примечательны приятной графикой и прекрасными музыкой и звуками. Что мне ещё понравилось - в отличие от того же Сапёра в серии игр Hexcells мало попадается "мин", которые нельзя просчитать и необходимо угадывать.

Squarecells и Crosscells мне понравились меньше, но тоже вполне могут прийтись вам по вкусу.

Проблем с запуском игр на openSUSE x64 c блобом nvidia никаких. Маленький косяк есть в Squarecells или Crosscells -
 работает только в оконном режиме из-за какого-то бага в движке Unity, но это не страшно.

В общем эти игры заслуживают всяческой пахлавы и вашего внимания. Плюс они ещё и стоят смешных денег. Однозначный маст хэв, вы не пожалеете!

和前两代已经很优秀的《Hexcells》相比，界面和配乐都上升了一个台阶。元素与《Hexcells Plus》没有区别，但关卡设计却更为精巧，糅合扫雷与数独的思想，越到后期越能感受到制作组的用心——他们将每个提示都运用得恰到好处。[spoiler]另外恕我愚钝，六大关中除过几个并不难且收尾处错一两个不会影响全收集的小关卡外，并没有找到一些评论所说的“二选一”太多的情况。[/spoiler]
作为解法唯一的六边形扫雷，解密仍旧需要严谨的推算才能得出结论。难度递增与新元素介绍相对《Hexcells Plus》要亲民许多。
制作组总算添加了虽然设计感不太强但日后总算可以继续游玩的无尽关卡，算是圆了前两作的遗憾。[spoiler]不过个人只是草草刷了60关拿了个全成就就溜了，过于花眼的雷数与繁杂却没有太大意义的提示与本体的精巧大相径庭。[/spoiler]

总分：8/10

37749570.review:
Hexcells Infinite is an awesome conclusion to the Hexcells series. The puzzles are extremely well crafted and relaxing to play. It introduces mechanics quickly and uses them well to form the great hand-crafted levels. The level generator is a great addition, and it allows for you to play the game whenever you need a break even if the main levels are complete. I find the random levels usually only take a few minutes, and aren't nearly as hard as the last few levels of the 'campaign'.

Achievements are tied to completing the levels with few mistakes, which doesn't require you to go too far out of your way, and for doing 60 of the random levels, which takes a few additional hours. 

Pick up the bundle of the three Hexcells games if you want really excellent puzzles.

Muy buen juego de puzzles, con un estilo gráfico minimalista y sobrio, y una música muy zen y poco intrusiva. Pero el arma definitiva para los momentos complicados es apagarla y poner música rock a un buen volumen para que las ideas fluyan. Ouh yeah!! Jejeje.

La mecánica principal es similar a la del clásico Buscaminas: Tienes un panel de piezas hexagonales conectadas entre ellas donde cada pieza puede estar vacía o llena, y se trata de resolver el estado de todas ellas usando las pistas que hay encima y/o en la parte exterior de algunas piezas. Muy simple como concepto, pero con algunos niveles muy complicados. 

He resuelto todos los puzzles en aproximadamente 40 horas de juego, y además tiene un generador random de niveles, y carga de niveles customizados, así que hay juego para rato.

Muy recomendable!

Saludos!!

Best puzzle game I've come across in years on Steam. It eases you in on the concept, starting very easy at first, and gradually turning into a real brain burner. In a good way. And if that's not enough for you, there's the random levels (which, for the most part, over-compensates for being random, and gives too many clues, so they are usually pretty easy).

If you're looking for a challenge, there's also the level editor and option to "paste" in levels by other creators. These are WAY harder than anything that came with the game.

I think this might actually be the first game I've earned every achievement in on Steam.

Best short-term timekilling game out there.

Recommended for any fan of "Minesweeper". In 70h of gameplay I never came across an unsolvable puzzle and all the puzzles can be saved to come back later. But why 70h of gameplay you ask? Well, infinite is not truly infinite in this game but the "seed-generator" uses numbers big enough that you wont see a puzzle twice if you dont want to. Instead of a random seed you can also let it fill in the current date, which is neat. The campaign puzzles are nice and challenging but the generation of random seeds makes this the best "Hexcells" title in my opinion. Go play the others as well!
One downside: The randomly generated puzzles are obviously not that thought through and handcrafted like the campaign, in other words: they tend to be easier than the later campaign puzzles but there are hard ones as well occasionally.

Final word: I was surprised by how nice the soundscape in this game is.

This game is 20/10. If you wasted countless hours (or days) playing Minesweeper only to be frustrated when you have 1 mine left with an equal probability of being in multiple cells, YOU NEED TO PLAY HEXCELLS.

The elegance of this game is the simplicity of it's concept. Your only goal is to find the occupied cells. Hexcells will give you very limited information to accomplish that goal while giving you all of the information you need to find every single cell with absolute certainty.  If you ever need to guess in this game then you literally still have alot to learn.  This is not a guessing game, it's a pure logic puzzle that is AMAZING!

36614525.review:
Its essentially the same game as the previous Hexcells, but now it has the restart puzzle feature i mentioned i wanted. They also added the infinitely generated puzzle feature. Nice.

The game is essentially minesweeper with better defined rules, less rng, and paths that go off on thier own that aren't shaped like squares. This means you can work through your checklist of math rules a certain row has, and once you finish that row the new information you have will help you solve other rows of the equation. The branching paths were cool, but sometimes the puzzles got so big that it took a really long time to work through a branch and once i was done i would still have like 5 other paths to work on, which can be pretty exhausting. 

The repeat in mechanics really knocks the game down a peg. A big part of why a puzzle is interesting is because it's new; having to work with new problems and rulesets is a big part of why the game is fun. The more i play this puzzle game, the less i enjoy it because it feels exactly the same as the last game.

The no mistakes requirements to unlock new levels also really got on my nerves this time around. Making players constantly have to resolve puzzles they already worked through is frusterating and i found it to be a big turn off from the game. Once i finshed a row of hexes, i was thinking thank god, now i can finally attempt one of the other dozen paths that are in this level. 

I will say

35949831.review:
運要素ナシでぜったいにクリアできるマインスイーパ改ってかんじのHexcells、の続編のHexcells Plusのさらに続編です。
頭の体操にぴったり。

今作はマップ生成モード搭載で無限に遊べるようになりました。

■tips
・前作までできたマウスクリックの入れ替えは今回からゲーム内メニューでできます。1-1でもできます。
・枠外にある数字はクリックすると列がハイライトされてべんり。不要になった数字は右クリックで薄くできる。
・青数字はクリックすると範囲が見える。不要になったら右クリックで薄くできる。

前作との相違点はこんな感じ。
・キー操作をゲーム内で変更可能。
・青数字の範囲が見やすくなった。
・メニューからexitすると中断できるようになった。
・難易度、というか手掛かりの発見がさらに難しくなった。特にラスト数ステージはエベレスト級です。
・自動生成モード搭載！
　ランダムシードから生成したマップを無限に遊べるまさにInfinityモードです。
　シードは今日の日付を指定したりランダムで生成したり、クリップボードから貼りつけることもできるので難しいマップを探して友達と競ったりすることもできます。


キャンペーンは前作よりもさらに手掛かりが少なくなっており、広大なマップのほんのわずかな手掛かりに手をかけながら進んでいく様子はさながら脳を使ったロッククライミングのようです。
地雷の存在しない場所に手をかけて身体を引き上げ、次の手掛かりを探してマップを見渡す。一歩一歩進んでいくとやがてすべてを見下ろすところにたどり着くといった具合。

マップは固定なので適当にクリックして地雷を特定していけば絶対にクリアできるんですが、偶然に頼らず遊んだ方が楽しいと思います。

誤クリック対策か1ミスまではパーフェクトクリアと見なされるようです。
2ミス以上したマップはアイコンが光らなくなります。パーフェクト実績を取るときは確認してみて下さい。


オススメ。

Hexcells Infinite is just some dang good puzzling. It builds confidently on the Minesweeper-like structure of Hexcells and H+ before it, makes the UI slightly cleaner, and finally adds a random puzzle generator to keep you going indefinitely. It's not going to change your life, but it's a great way to hunker down on a relaxing morning.

If you're looking at this, it's probably worth picking up the entire Logic Puzzle Pack. This is the high water mark of the bunch, but each has their own charms.

Excelente trilogía con idénticas bases y aspecto en cada juego. No es imprescindible haber jugado los interiores, en cada uno se dan las instrucciones necesarias. Soluciones muy elegantes en los 3 repasando todas las pistas cuando parece que ya no puedes avanzar (con la excepción de algunos niveles del "Plus", como comentaré).

El primero, Hexcells, tiene una [b]duración de menos de dos horas[/b]. Una única solución posible en cada nivel. Muy recomendable empezar por este y ver si es lo tuyo o no, porque siempre podrás devolverlo si no te convence.

La continuación Hexcells Plus introduce nuevas reglas, tiene unos cuantos niveles de bastante mayor dificultad, pero el problema de que algunos tienen múltiples soluciones y no hay pistas suficientes para saber cuál es la correcta, tienes que jugártela a suertes. En mi opinión el desarrollador colocó un producto mal terminado para aprovechar el tirón del anterior.

El último de la serie, Hexcells Infinite es el que debes comprar después de haber probado el primero. Mismo aspecto y mecánica, pero algo más demandante y con un generador de niveles para que no se te acabe y la opción de dejar un tablero parcialmente resuelto para continuar en otro momento.

34092421.review:
Hexcells Infinite is a great little puzzle game that also fixes a few of the issues of the earlier games in the series, HexCells and HexCells Plus (both of which I also fully recommend, despite their minor flaws). This game has both premade puzzles, on a fair learning curve of difficulty, and a procedural generation system that presumably is capable of generating an additional 100,000,000 different puzzles. This solves the replay issue of the previous games, and also includes a save feature (letting you leave a puzzle and come back without having to start over), and the option to swap your mouse buttons (which is critical if you're a Minesweeper player as the default "safe" or "flag" buttons are opposite). And just as HexCells Plus increased the size and complexity of puzzles compared to HexCells, HexCells Infinite increases them even more, so that save function is a lifesaver on the later puzzles.

And yes, this is a Minsweeper style puzzle game, but because the levels are premade they progress on a fair learning curve and are all 100% logic solvable with no guessing required, ever. At the risk of sounding condescending, if you're reading a negative review by someone who says guessing is required, they just couldn't logic the puzzle out. I was able to logic solve them all, and when I did make an error, I was able to figure out what error in logic I had made, or what I had failed to notice, that caused my mistake. The game lets you make a few mistakes without failing you on the level, but as a perfectionist I restarted from scratch each time, and was able to clear them all.

Even the procedurally generated "Infinite" levels seem to follow the 100% solvable rule, I've done about 20 so far and had no problems, and in each I could see what are probably the base elements of coding that ensure the levels are solvable. There are often multiple - or as I see it, overlapping - ways to prove many of the cells as safe or not, which I'm guessing comes from the failsafe coding. The downside to this is they tend to be fairly easy, even the really large puzzles (the generator makes them in multiple sizes as well as configurations) have none of the complex logic required to beat the higher premade levels.

The only downsides I see are:
1. Because this is a standalone game, it has tutorial style puzzles to teach the mechanics of the various logic rules, but if you're already familiar with the series you'll solve them almost instantly.
2. There's still no "maybe" flag, so any "what if" analysis you do has to be in your head or on paper, and with the complexity of some of the puzzles, this is an ever bigger problem here than it was in the earlier games int he series.

Fully recommend.

"Hexcells Infinite" continues the upward trend of the already great "Hexcells" line of games.  This game differs from the previous game in that it now includes a puzzle generator and the ability to save the progress of a game.  So, once finished with its 36 built in puzzles, you can play an infinite number of generated puzzles (hence the name), and when you get brain-fatigue in the middle of a big puzzle, you can quit without losing your progress.  As with "Hexcells Plus," "Infinite" jumps right in and ramps right up.  The game is excellent and all puzzles are solvable without guessing.  The save ability is especially useful because some of these puzzles are huge (puzzle 6-8 took me about 3 hours to complete).  My only real complaint is that some of the puzzles are still too big (even though they can be saved).  With exception of completing 60 randomly generated puzzles to get the final Achievement, finishing the game with all the rest of the Achievements took 19.8 hours.  So, again, it's a game well worth the money.

For those who don't believe all the puzzles can be solved without guessing, I refer you to a guide which proves it:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=373284523

First time giving a shot for an English review.
K, if you are looking for a good puzzle game. Dah, right place for ya.
Hexcell series is very (not) brain-friendly, and I absolutely love it.

The "Infinite" mode, as I saw in some other reviews, appears to be repeative. And it is.
Here is a quick answer for those who are bothered by this problem.
These "random" stages, as you can see on the generating page, are generated from a certain seed. 
If you don't understand what this seed stands for, don't bother. Just FYI, a certain seed can only generate one certain pattern of Hexcell puzzle. This explains why you sometimes see repeated puzzles. Well, I guess the one you see most times is the one generated by those zeroes, lol.

Anyway, I am not able to explain the algorithm how a Hexcell puzzle is generated from a seed. But you still have 10^8, which is eight hundred million, puzzles to enjoy in total (they may not be as challenging tho). So I believe it is worth having this interesting game collected in your library.

33440959.review:
Minesweeper + Sudoku Part III

Hexcells Infinite is back with the same formula but with a ton more content. Aside from the 36 campaign puzzles (that sprinkle in a few tutorials to explain the core concepts) Infinite has an infinite more (well, 999,999,999 mode to be more precise). Obviously infinite mode gives the player a lot of value and replay ability as most of these puzzles (I've done 60 of them) take between 2-15 minutes. The option to use the date as a seed is a nice touch for daily playing.

Infinite added a much needed save feature: maintaining the progress of your current campaign or infinite level. I say needed because some of the campaign levels can take a long time to solve (a few clock in at well over an hour during first playthrough). This also resets all the available information which is great if you accidentally or foolishly turned off some vital clue.

I give credit to the sound design. Aside from the pleasant music, revealing hexes produce one of several different musicle cues. It's just a nice touch to engage the player and give a bit of variation.

My only complaints are that highlighting columns and particularly blue hexes) to give information can sometimes make it difficult to see elements of the game. Several times the faint flashing  against the white backdrop almost blends in which may lead to mistakes. As for mistakes, while there is no guessing in the game, it can be a bit of a chore to put an hour into a level only to have a misclick force a restart (but no one said achievements are supposed to be easy).

Hexcells infinite gives some strong improvements over past iterations while keeping the core mechanics in tact. There is a ton of value for this game at any price for those looking for a challenge.

33034357.review:
Hexcells Infinite 是一款结合了数独和扫雷元素的益智类休闲游戏。界面简洁内容有趣。不过和扫雷的区别是没有扫雷的惩罚元素（选错及结束游戏），但会记录错误数。相比数独又多了及时性，你选择就会知道对错。
此作是3个系类作品中最难也是关卡最多的一作（108关）。
1关卡数量多一方面也是因为它包括了前作的一些关卡。所以重复度高也是它的一个不可忽视的缺点。
2难度方面挺可观的，由易到难，如果你追求无错通关的话难一点的关卡可能会花费你15分钟以上。不过总的来说也并不是异常为难你的难度，所以还是得算它休闲吧。此外还有一个无尽模式，关卡随机，由输入种子得到（种子8位数）。缺点是毕竟是随机。难度的设计上肯定不如固定关卡有趣和难。
3全成就简单不过有点麻烦。除去正常游玩固定关卡得到的成就，需要在无尽模式中完成60次随机关卡（可以是同一关）才可获得最后一项成就。
如果你是全成就党又想快速完成这个成就，可以选择雷数比较少的关卡（如00000011）不计通关时错误数目下左右键一起全点开过关就好。不过估计60次需要花费你最快15分钟左右，还是很无趣而且累人的。建议还是每天玩几关。
总的来说内容我是推荐的。不过估价10元，毕竟有些不可忽视的缺点。所以建议还是在打折的时候入吧。

32508896.review:
基本通关了，回来补上这篇评测。

[h1]游戏类型[/h1]
极简主义风格的“扫雷”进阶版；与扫雷极大的区别在于，你可以通过严密的逻辑推理逐步揭开每一块未知雷区，而完全可以撇开运气成分。

[h1]游戏推荐人群[/h1]
钟情于烧脑而又慢节奏，极简主义画风，需要锻炼逻辑推理能力的人群；

[h1]游戏基础操作[/h1]
鼠标左右键用于黑与蓝两种颜色的标记（由于可以设置颠倒设定，所以我有点忘记了具体是怎么对应了）；
可以随时返回退出，本局进度会被自动保存；

[h1]通关要求[/h1]
使用鼠标左右键对标记相应色块，不限制mistakes错误数，只要全部标记完成即可通关。
但是主线的内设关卡需要逐级解锁，前面关卡通关错误越少犯奖励的解锁点数就越充足，所以最好每一关都0错误通过，这一点对解锁成就很重要。

[h1]游戏提示[/h1]
游戏中有多种提示符号或线索，是玩家逻辑推理的重要依据，有以下类型：
[b]A. 数字型及对应逻辑含义[/b]
1）黑块上的数字——表示区域【相邻】的蓝色方块数量；
2）蓝块上的数字——表示区域【与本蓝块距离为2的半径内】所含其他蓝块数量（左击数字开启或关闭辅助范围，右击隐藏显示该数字）；
3）边缘标注的数字——表示区域【在数字文本指代的一条[b]射线[/b]上】所含蓝块数量（左击数字开启或关闭辅助线，右击隐藏显示该数字）；
4）游戏右上角remaining数字——表示其余未标注区域内存在的蓝块数量；

[b]B. 字符型及对应逻辑含义[/b]
1）短线内数字（形式 -x-,  x表示数字，下同）——表示区域内有x个不完全相邻的蓝块；
2）大括号内数字（形式 {x}）——表示区域内有x个位置连续的蓝块；

[b]注意[/b]：如果是边缘标注的短线内数字或大括号内数字，作用的一条直线即使中间有空，空位两侧也要视为是连续的。
例如在一个未完全标出的一条线的一端有标记{3}，排列为：【黑1，黑2，黑3，蓝4，空5，空6，蓝7，未知8，未知9】，这里要把空5和空6忽略，把蓝4和蓝7当做连续的，根据{3}表示连续3个蓝块，推知未知8是蓝块而未知9是黑块；

[h1]游戏模式[/h1]
游戏有三个存档来记录主线关卡的进展；另外有一个模式是用户随意输入8位数字程序生成随机关卡，玩法与主线经典关卡一样。

[h1]游戏总评[/h1]
+画风极简 5/5；
+逻辑严密 5/5；
+操作简单 5/5；
+音乐空灵 4.5/5；

- 主线的经典关卡容错率很低——游戏难度：对逻辑要求较高；
- 背景看久了眼睛还是有点累，能够换色，
或是增加些类似“夜间模式”的背景就会更加舒适了——美工-舒适度：不宜玩太久；
- 背景音乐有点少，不过可以静音边听其他音乐边玩——音乐-多样性：欠佳；
- 一旦掌握规律，玩久了容易腻；

推荐指数：★★★★☆
价钱合理：★★★★★

31869620.review:
Before I start this review, I wanted to recommend "Tetrobot and Co." to those who look for intellectual challenges. It's a far superior puzzle game than the Hexcells trilogy, and is a game that actually challenges your problem solving skills.

Now onto Hexcells Infinite.

The idea of different types of hints comparing to minesweeper is refreshing, there are 3 types of additional hints besides the number of adjacent blue hexes: 
1) Number of blue hexes in a column
2) Consecutive or non-consecutive blue hexes in adjacent hexes/column
3) Number of blue hexes in 2 hex radius

However the freshness of new ideas runs out extremely quickly, and there will be no more new mechanics from that point on - the game becomes extremely repetitive, with few exceptions.

There are 2 methods the developer adopts to make this game challenging:
1) Reduce redundant information to bare minimum, by giving you non-blue hexes with question mark instead of an actual number. In my eyes, all this does is to make the levels long, and extremely unsatisfying to solve. It doesn't really pose interesting challenges, instead it just creates dead ends and forces you to move to somewhere else. When you have a board with over 400 hexes, it gets extremely annoying and frustrating to click on that one non-blue hex only to see a question mark.
2) Create extremely large levels that take over half an hour to complete (if your goal is to make 0 mistakes) - or significantly longer if you are not a fast thinker. Many levels include completely independent sections which would have served much better as multiple smaller levels. Instead of keep creating interesting mechanics, the only variation becomes the overall shape of each level. It's quite sad to see a promising idea dying so quickly, it's like a novel with amazing first 3 chapters, but 20 more boring and mundane long chapters after, ruining the entire book.

The way this game works, is for the player to slowly exhaust all the available information to determine which ones are blue hexes. But because there are only 4 types of information, it really doesn't require that much problem solving skills or creativity. Most later campaign levels feel like chores, and you are forced to do them slowly. At some point you might be forced to take a guess, and seeing the 0 mistake jumping to 1, ruining your perfect record, is quite infuriating.


The game has nice audio, however there are some minor technical issues:
1) Regardless of which monitor is selected to play the game in windowed mode, the game would always launch across all monitors. If the developer wanted to, this bug can be easily fixed in minutes.
2) If you click really quickly, sometimes clicks won't register.

In conclusion, I wouldn't recommend this game to any of my friends.

One of the best logic puzzles I've ever played. I do the "today's date" random puzzle everyday, and often more than that. It's a relaxing game for the most part--sometimes it's frustrating when I don't see what I need to see.

Some people are comparing it to sudoku or minesweeper. It's sort of like they hooked up and had a baby together and the result was Hexcells.

31281024.review:
Le troisième jeu de la série des Hexcells, plus facile que le deuxième volet (Hexcells Plus) et plus difficile (disons plus évolué et plus complet) que le premier.
Comme d'hab, que de la logique pure, pas la peine de s'en remettre à la chance pour résoudre les puzzles.

Cet opus à l'énorme, l'immense, que dis-je, l'incommensurable avantage de disposer d'un "générateur aléatoire" de puzzle, ce qui, en plus des 36 puzzles du jeu "in-built" (difficulté croissante, explication des règles petit à petit,...), vous permet de profiter d'un infinité (ou plus précisément de 100 000 000) de puzzles supplémentaires d'une difficulté intermédaire.

C'est un très bon jeu, un très bon passe-temps, à faire seul ou à plusieurs.
Et si des trois jeux Hexcells vous ne vouliez en acquérir qu'un seul (bien que je vous conseille de profiter pleinement des trois opus), alors c'est sans hésiter celui-là qu'il vous faudrait.

30573039.review:
This was my first foray into the hexcells series. I'm not much of a puzzle game fan though I really like logic problems which this definitely caters to. It's super interesting to see how the puzzles develop over time as you learn more and more principles about the mechanics of the puzzles. I also like that there's only one right answer but multiple ways to go about solving the puzzle; you can go at your own pace and take any direction you wish. If you get stuck, just look at a new area of the puzzle and you might have new information since your last visit.

The instructions to hexcells are a little vague, so definitely take your time on the first instruction puzzle of each series and don't worry about finishing without mistakes the first go around. The most important lesson is that marking hexes grey can sometimes be just as important, if not more important, as marking hexes blue. Keep that in mind and you'll have a great time.

If you are new to the hexcells series -- this is the one to get. I haven't tested the other standard levels, but this one offers longterm replayability that the other two games don't by adding a custom levels feature. Reddit.com's /r/hexcells and /r/hexcellslevels are great tools for finding cool community-created levels as well as installing plugins to make applications of the levels faster and easier. Hexcells Infinite also comes with a new puzzle a day and a random puzzle feature. I will warn you that the random hex puzzles are rather easy to complete, often giving a ton of information for free without needing any moves, and don't give the same satisfaction completing them that finishing the base set does. I will definitely be purchasing the other two hexcells games to get my puzzle fix soon.

As for value, I beat 36 included levels in about 11 hours according to steam, though I've played the game sometimes without launching steam so I'm not sure if it tracked everything. I'd say the total is closer to 20 hours for the base levels, and I expect to probably sink another 20 or so hours playing custom levels and the new daily puzzle. For $5 that's a steal, I paid like a buck and a half on sale which is highway robbery. 

To the developer, if you made new levels in a DLC I'd definitely buy it! I would also humbly suggest a way to play this in the dark like SquareCells has, spent a lot of late nights burning my eyes out with this game :)

30564258.review: Delete all puzzle games you may have in your library because Hexcells Infinite is the only one that you need in your life.

30515332.review:
The thrid in the Hexcells series, Hexcells Infinite is a refreshing addition to this line of minesweeper inspired puzzle packs. The original Hexcells was refreshing and fun whilst Hexcells Plus was, at times, exceedingly tedious with some of the puzzle designs. The tedium of Plus--as generally caused by a little too much "mucking around" with the blue cell counter mechanics on some puzzles, is not replicated in Hexcells Infinite. Hexcells Infinite, unlike it's predecessors does have some capacity for random puzzle generation. Although, thus far, the randomly generated puzzles are not as complex as many of the prefab puzzles in the "story set"--for lack of a better term--they remain fun and the seed system does afford sufficient depth of puzzles able to be generated to afford extensive diversionary and casual replay value.

The soundset remains relaxed and in sync with the previous titles and the controls remain identical as well.

My greatest irritation remains with perfecting each puzzle--which is to say, the instant one makes a mistake, to erase that mistake one must start the entire puzzle from scratch. This is perfectly fine, in terms of design overall, but I have found myself, at times, forgetting which button tags a blue cell and which uncovers a yellow cell--resulting in stupid mistakes and thus having to redo an entire puzzle from scratch. An undo function, allowing for a single mistake to be back-tracked once per puzzle would remove the occassional misclick irritation of having to restart a puzzle you already know how to do but were "clumsy" in regards to inputs.

Overall, this is an excellent program, surpassing it's two predecessors in replayability, and would be enjoyed by any fan of minesweeperesque puzzle games. Definately worth a buy--especially when the full series goes on a sale.

30340648.review:
Der Name von Hexcells beschreibt das Spiel eigentlich schon ganz gut. Hexcells ist eine Art Minesweeper-Variation nur mit hexagonalen, also sechseckigen, Spielfeldern. Es gibt auch keinen echten Niederlage-Zustand. Das Spielfeld ist zunächst meist komplett gelb, ihr versucht anhand der Informationen, die ihr habt die Felder in schwarze Felder und blaue Felder einzuteilen. Fehler werden gezählt. Die schwarzen Felder haben Zahlen in ihnen, die angeben, wie viele angrenzende Felder blaue Felder sind. 

Zum Zeitpunkt des Reviews gibt es drei Hexcells-Spiele: Hexcells, Hexcells Plus und Hexcells Infinite. Der erste Teil hat mich laut Steam etwa 2 Stunden gebraucht bis zur Vollendung, Plus etwa 4, Infinite etwa eine, allerdings habe ich die letzten beiden Spiele nicht abgeschlossen. Dieser Review beschreibt alle drei Spiele, weil die sich sehr ähnlich sind. Nicht alle Elemente der späteren Spiele sind in den früheren. So enthält Infinite einen Zufallsgenerator für Level, der euch quasi unendlich viele Level zur Verfügung stellt, die ihr lösen könnt. Die früheren beiden Spiele haben das nicht. Plus ist meiner Ansicht nach der schwierigste Teil der Serie. 

Das Prinzip von Hexcells ist recht einfach, aber es kommen noch weitere Elemente hinzu. So stehen Zahlen an den Spalten, bzw. an den Kanten von Sechsecken, die angeben, wie viele blaue Felder in der Reihe sind. Zahlen in geschweiften Klammern stehen dafür, dass die blauen Felder definitiv komplett verbunden sind, mit Minuszeichen an der Seite dafür, dass die Felder nicht alle verbunden sind (wenigstens ein Feld steht ab). Später kommen noch Zahlen in blauen Feldern hinzu, die angeben, wie viele blaue Felder in der Umgebung von zwei Feldern sind, und schwarze Felder mit Fragezeichen drin, d.h. ohne Angabe, wie viele blaue Felder in der Nachbarschaft liegen. 

Die Rätselspiele steuern sich gut, mit einer Taste (bei mir linke Maustaste) deklariert ihr das aktuell mit dem Cursor überfahrene Feld als schwarz, mit einer anderen (bei mir rechte Maustaste) als blau. Weiter könnt ihr noch die Hilfestellungszahlen an den Rändern und in blauen Feldern ausgrauen, um zu markieren, dass die für euch keine Bedeutung mehr haben, weil ihr die Reihe bspw. schon gelöst habt. Ziel des Spiels ist es die Rätsel fehlerfrei zu lösen um die Maximalzahl an blauen Dreiecken zu erhalten. Mit denen schaltet ihr neue Rätsel frei. Es gibt in den drei Spielen jeweils sechs Welten mit jeweils sechs Rätseln, Infinite bietet den Zufallsgenerator, dürfte damit der klare Gewinner sein, wenn es um Inhalt geht. 

Das Spiel wirkt von der Optik her sehr klar, sehr rein, sehr stilsicher. Auch die Hintergrundmusik passt perfekt zum Spiel. Sehr ruhige Töne, die den Spielfluss gut unterstreichen. Jedes Mal, wenn ihr ein Feld aufdeckt macht das Spiel einen Ton - das passt einfach zusammen.

Hexcells ist ein cooles kleines Spiel, was euch für ein paar Stunden unterhalten wird. Wer auf Rätsel steht, macht mit den Spielen der Serie nichts falsch. Meiner Ansicht nach ist der Erstling der einfachste, damit ein guter Startpunkt für Anfänger, wer sich nur eines der Spiele kaufen will, sollte zu Infinite greifen, weil dort durch den Zufallsgenerator noch etwas mehr Inhalt geboten wird.

30336766.review:
Третья игра, превосходное завершение серии Hexcells.

[u]Игровая механика и геймплей[/u]
Как и в первых двух частях, игрок ищет голубые ячейки-мины, используя числовые подсказки на уже открытых шестиугольниках - число соседних ячеек, данные об их последовательности, количество в столбце, диагонали или окружности диаметром в пять ячеек. Уровни непростые, но решаемые - угадывать в игре не придётся, каждый уровень составлен безупречно и требует лишь логических рассуждений. Добавлена возможность сохранения прогресса при выходе из уровня и, самое главное, - режим случайно генерируемых головоломок, который сводит количество игровых часов к бесконечности. Тут уж придраться не к чему, 10/10.

[u]Визуальное оформление[/u]
В оформлении ничего не изменилось, как было простым и идеальным, так и осталось - 10/10.

[u]Звуковое оформление[/u]
Фоновый эмбиент, куда без него? А если быстро (и правильно) разбивать ячейки, можно услышать подобие клавишной мелодии. Оценка - 9/10.

[u]Достижения[/u]
Помимо разблокировки всех миров-наборов уровней и прохождения каждого уровня без ошибок, игра потребует пройти 60 головоломок из бесконечного режима.

Общая оценка - 10/10, рекомендую однозначно.

30257656.review:
作为一个类扫雷游戏，拿它和扫雷比自然是少不了的：
相比传统扫雷，本作需要的运气成分要少得多，当然它的游戏系统也注定了玩家必须具备更强的耐心，因为后面难度较高的关卡中蓝块很多、地图很大，常常要为了找一个突破口盯着屏幕看上几分钟。

关于操作：
第一次玩的时候，一打开本作的主界面，看到左下角有个鼠标形状的按钮，立刻心领神会的我感到非常欣喜
因为本作的前两代都是用左键将蓝块标出，用右键将灰块点开，和传统的扫雷操作正相反，对于经常玩扫雷的玩家来说这个操作方式简直可以用反人类来形容（我玩本作的前两代时为了能够流畅操作，只好打开控制面板设置鼠标，将左右键切换）。而这一代提供了能直接在游戏中切换左右键的功能自然是再好不过了

另外，点击有数字的蓝块和外围的数字可以作出相应的辅助线，希望不要有人像我一样老是要对着屏幕比划半天最后依旧看岔行（事实上本作第一代就有这个功能，而我竟然玩到这一代时才知道_(:з」∠)_）

总之作为本作最成熟的一代，扫雷爱好者入一个错不了的。

30043246.review:
Contrary to what other reviewers have said, you do not ever need to guess with Hexcells Infinite. I will admit to not completing many of the generated levels yet,though each so far has required nothing more than logic.

As such, Hexcells is a near perfect puzzle game. Infinite improves upon the previous two games not just by providing a near endless number of generated levels to play, but by improving nearly every other aspect of the game. 

The UI is friendlier; you can have just the 'click' sounds, with or without the music, expanded hexes are more clearly distinguished against others. 

This installment is by far the hardest. The previous two start off easy and work up to much more difficult puzzles, this is no different, but some were so large and challenging that I have sat there staring at the screen for hours in single puzzles.

If you like minesweeper and hate ever having to guess, get this game. My only recommended game on steam with a library of over 300!

30026139.review: This is a very well thought out, polished game.  The best part is it doesn't have the most frustrating part of minesweeper since you very very rarely have to *guess* where a blue tile/bomb is.  Speed running in it is different than minesweeper since you have to look all over the board for info about the area you are working on.  There are more rules to it than minesweeper.  I beat the game and make few mistakes, but after the playtime shown for me, I could still improve my times by 2x after more practice.  So yes, it's a great game that develops some skill even beyond basic logic and arithmetic.

It's a very zen-like experience.  That's not to say that it isn't tough.  It is!  I love this game quite a lot and cannot recommend it enough.

29950976.review:
Hexcells is a minesweeper with 0% luck and 100% guess, hexagons instead of squares and (far) better graphics. The rules are quickly and efficiently explained, leaving you to focus on solving the puzzles.

As the third and last installment of the Hexcells serie, the game mechanics remain the same as the previous Hexcells but new puzzles are introduced as well as the ability to save and quit in the middle of a puzzle (very welcome for the harder ones) as well as a random generator of puzzles.

This latter feature adds infinite replayability altough the random puzzles are never as well-thought (i.e. hard) as the ones from the game developpers.

29925106.review:
This is a good, simple-but-tricky variation on minesweeper.  It's fun, and the later puzzles especially can be rather challenging.  It took me nearly 24 hours of play time to finish the "campaign" levels (albeit while multitasking).

Compared to the previous games (Hexcells and Hexcells Plus), Infinite strikes a good balance in its difficulty, and is also has an important new feature:  randomized puzzles.  The addition of these procedurally generated puzzles means that there are effectively about 1 billion puzzles in this game, which is effectively unlimited (it would take someone, nonstop, about 500,000 years to complete, even if they could solve a puzzle in ~5 minutes).  The randomized puzzles so far seem to be a bit easier than the regular puzzles, but are still enjoyable and are hard enough to keep your brain awake, at the very least.

29910133.review:
Hexcells is a fantastic series that you should definitely play.

It is reminiscent of Minesweeper, but the puzzles can be solved deterministically with no random chance or luck involved, only clever inferences based on each cell's surroundings.

The game starts off simple, but getting a perfect score on the later levels approach crushing levels of difficulty as you're asked to mentally juggle more and more possibilities - or you can just use a guide. :P

Hexcells Infinite introduces randomly generated levels in addition to the set of handcrafted ones already present... but the results are basic. The rules for the generator tend to produce puzzles that are pretty easy to solve and can only compensate for their lack of it by making them larger in scale.

29452308.review: With an overwhelmingly large amount of time in this game, and 720 of the random levels completed as of this review, I can assure that this game is one of the best ending games to a series of games. There isn't a single level you can't complete with guessing as you'll always have one move you can logically make, though it can be obscure. As always, even the 36 "story" levels prove to have an equal difficulty curve, albeit steeper than the previous two games. For anyone who wants a well-made puzzle game that can also prove calming, I suggest this one as well as the previous two. Though, this game allows you to change the controls, so superior game goes to Infinite.

29404122.review:
Fun game for those who like Mine Sweeper or other logic solving games.  Slightly more complicated rules for hints, there's the rows/columns hints that isn't present in Mine Sweeper.

There's also pleasant ambiance music, soothing and easy to listen to while solving.  Doesn't mesh well if you're in the hasty mind pushing yourself to beat best times.  But when you're just playing the game and relaxing, it is wonderful.

I recommend the Hexcells Infinite version because you can generate random puzzles to play.  The other versions in the Hexcell series (including this one) all have pre-made maps for you to play that are deliciously complicated and ramp up in difficulty.  But once you've beaten the premade's, you've beaten them.  You'll get your money's worth on each game, but you may not want to go back to the premades for some time.  Having a huge amount of random generated puzzles to tap whenever you want to play a fresh game?  Delightful.

29390362.review:
I love hexcells, but this new version has cells that you cannot deduce, you have to guess. Being able to deduce the answer without guessing is what makes a puzzle game a puzzle game. So I cannot give this product a positive review.
EDIT: I just realized there is a box in the upper left that says how many blue squares are remaining in the puzzle. This is very important to realize,as the puzzles are not solvable without the box.

29390187.review:
There are some games that are genuinely addictive but, this is one of those games where you feel like it's not a time waste of nothingness. Sometimes I can just get so absorbed in Hexcells that I lose track of time. The ambient music, the blinding light of the screen can keep you glued to your seat for minutes deciphering some of these puzzles. After each puzzle you say "one more won't take long" then 2 more hours have passed. 

The logic of this game is wonderful something similar to that strange Windows game Minesweeper only no annoying little bombs that end the game when you hit it. Actually I would say it's a reverse Minesweeper and instead of bombs you've got blue dots. And every time you deduce a blue dot some piano keys play in the background. Sometimes I imagine Hexcells is what happens when your brain is on drugs. I'm not quite sure which drugs yet but it leaves you with a good feeling afterward so take your pick. 

The only issue I have with the game is the blinding white light that entrances you. It would be nice to have the option of a dark screen. It was implemented on the game Squarecells so I don't see why the developer couldn't add the same function to this one. Also LOVE the random puzzle generator. It breaks up the monotony of the regular levels, which are a challenge unto themselves.

29351704.review: 虽然是个小游戏，但是非常耐玩！

29350668.review: An amazing minesweeper like game that brings so much more to the table. ONe of the best, if not the best puzzle game I've played.

29341969.review:
The Hexcells series has been a fun and relaxing way for me to pass the time. The calm ambience and minimalistic structure of the games makes it easy to keep coming back to whenever you have a little time to kill. Infinite makes things far more convenient with the save feature, especially once you start getting into the really meaty and challenging puzzles later on. That was my only real complaint about its precessors, and it makes a world of difference in Infinite. 

While the randomly generated puzzles aren't quite as challenging as the expertly crafted stages, it's a nice feature that adds more playability to the game. I find that I spend more time testing speed over accuracy, whereas the main puzzles really encourage you to fill your cells in carefully (if you want to get the completionist achievements, anyway!). 

I think the only thing that has given me trouble is just how easy it is to misclick, particularly when you're on a roll. Luckily, the game doesn't penalize you for errors and allows you to finish each puzzle regardless of how many you make. 

Overall, a fun and simple game does what it sets out to do: scratching that puzzle itch in a quick and conveninent manner. I really appreciated the amount of creativity and challenge that was put into some of the game's main puzzles and I think it'd be worth playing them through again sometime.

29340828.review:
Just as good as Hexcells Plus. If you liked it, here's more of the same.

The handcrafted levels are good, but don't count too much on the procedurally generated levels to provide a lot of extra play value. 
The challenge they pose bears no comparison with the rest of the levels, you're probably better off replaying these unless you memorised them.

29327600.review:
This is the third in a series of puzzle games, with this one being the clearly superior production out of the three.  I say this because, like the first game, it gives a short tutorial level for any of the gameplay mechanics that are necessary to play the game.  However, unlike the first game, which developed these aspects much more gradually with several easy levels, this game starts applying these ideas at more advanced difficulty and application quite quickly.  This is a good thing in my view, since like all of the other games in the series, each one only has 36 designed levels for you to solve.  If too much time is spent walking the player through the gameplay, not enough time can be spent on levels that challenge all of the aspects the player had to learn to make it that far.  

The last few levels were quite challenging, and I was happy to tackle and master them.  All of them could be solved logically without guessing, but it took me some time working out what combination of information available to me would let me click or destroy the next block.  One aspect I was immensely thankful for was that the developers put in a level save feature, so whatever progress you made already could be saved for later, giving you a chance to take a break and come back to the place you had got stuck on.  You could jump inbetween levels, making progress until you hit a roadblock, and then switch your focus somewhere else.  It helped me tremendously.  

What ices the cake for me and gives this title the most value out of the others is that there is a puzzle generator for this game.  Very similar to how you can find websites to solve nigh infinite combinations of Sudoku puzzles, you can generate all of the puzzles you could ever want to do for this game.  The only flaw is that the puzzles are immensely easier than the ones with a human touch, and there's no way to select if you want a smaller, easier puzzle or a larger, more difficult puzzle.  It's all randomly generated with no way to set parameters for the puzzle you get (unless you look up specific codes, if there would be any of those listed somewhere in the first place).  Either way, I have enjoyed the trilogy, and can always come back to this one in the series if I want to play new puzzles.

29230105.review:
Hexcells erinnert anfangs an Minesweeper, wird jedoch schnell abwechslungsreicher. Ziel des Spiels ist es alle Felder aufzudecken. Diese können entweder Blau sein oder Grau sein und dann Informationen über die Anzahl benachbarter blauer Felder enthalten. Durch diese Information werden dann benachbarte Felder systematisch nach dem Ausschlussprinzip aufgedeckt. Zusätzlich wird durch Zahlen außerhalb der Felder angezeigt, wie viele blaue Felder sich in einer Linie befinden. Seit dem zweiten Teil der Serie, gibt es zusätzlich Informationen über die angrenzenden Felder auch in blauen Feldern. Jedoch beschränkt sich die angezeigte Zahl nicht auf die 6 direkt anliegenden Felder sondern auf 18 umliegende Felder, also quasi 2 Kreise um das Feld herum. In Hexcells Infinite sind viele Puzzle nur über gegenseitigen Ausschluss zu lösen, was die Komplexität und damit die Schwierigkeit enorm erhöht.

Falls man mehr als einen Fehler in einem Level macht, bekommt man Punkte abgezogen. Am Ende des Levels erhält man dann eine für das Level festgesetzte Anzahl Punkte. Wenn man nicht alle Punkte freischaltet muss man das Level noch einmal machen und mit nur einem Fehler bestehen. Mit einer gewissen Anzahl Punkten kann man dann immer 6 neue Level freischalten bis insgesamt alle 30 Level freigeschaltet sind.

Zusätzlich gibt es in diesem Teil der Serie einen Levelgenerator, der bis zu 1 Millionen verschiedene Level generieren kann und somit die Mischung aus einfachen, schweren, symmetrischen, chaotischen und in Mustern angeordneten Leveln durch eine riesige Anzahl zufälliger Level abgerundet und dadurch die Wiederspielbarkeit massiv erhöht.

Da Hexcells ein abwechslungsreiches und auch auf gewisse Weise schönes Rätselspiel ist, dass sich mit etwas Ruhe und Geduld gut bewältigen lässt, kann ich es sehr empfehlen. Der Preis ist recht günstig und die Errungenschaften sind in diesem, dritten Teil der Serie, mit viel Geduld und etwas Ausdauer gut zu erreichen.

Ich empfehle, dass Hexcells Complete Pack zu kaufen, da die Schwierigkeitskurve bei Hexcells Infinite sehr steil ist und das Puzzle ohne zumindest Hexcells Plus gemeistert zu haben schnell sehr schwer und dadurch frustrierend werden kann. Der Preisvorteil des Complete-Packs gegenüber dem Einzelkauf der Spiele ist ein weiterer Grund für das Pack. Besonders im SALE ist das Complete Pack durch seinen geringen Preis ein tolles Geschenk für Fans von Logik-Puzzles.

29053593.review:
This is my next favorite puzzle game. You're going to hear comparisons to Minesweeper, but I can assure you that the differences are enough that you might love this game even if Minesweeper isn't your thing.

That's certainly the case for me. To start with, there is never a need to guess. Every puzzle has all the clues you need. Now, admittedly, guessing can sometimes be fun and fulfilling, but this is the kind of game where if you fail, it isn't because of the random flip of a coin, but because you didn't pay close enough attention.

That's what I love about this game: It is a pure logic test that does great things for exercising your brain. The first couple of worlds introduce you to the rules. After you've got the rules, though, the priceless part of the game is the random puzzle generation that will make a seemingly endless stream of puzzles.

It isn't without problems, though. The music gets to be a bit much, fortunately you can turn it off. There are surprising UI elements missing. You can't advance through the game numbers (seeds) in a linear fashion, unless you're willing to remember your 8-digit numbers yourself. Even so, I'm not sure how random the random system really is, since I SWEAR I've replayed some of the games.  Some players might appreciate a hint system.

All that aside, though, it is a very enjoyable puzzle game, and is likely to go on my list of puzzle games that take all my time.

Cała seria Hexcells to bardzo pozytywne doświadczenie, ale brakuje tutaj jakiegoś dodatkowego szlifu. Np. bardzo brakowało mi tak prostej opcji jak zmiana kolorystyki plansz. 29005331.review:
整个系列包括三部作品。Hexcells，Hecells Plus，Hexcells Infinite。因为系统基本一样，所以放到一起来讲。
游戏时间：（全成就通关）
Hexcells 2小时
Hexcells Plus 9小时
Hexcells Infinite 主线通关大概13小时，60关随机无尽大概5小时

缺点：
界面过分简洁。想把音乐关掉还要回主菜单。前两代没有关卡进度储存，也没有暂停菜单。三代才有了一个聊胜于无的暂停菜单和自动进度储存。
按键跟扫雷相反。改键的话，一二代要在进游戏之前修改，三代要在主菜单修改。不是很方便，不过只用改一次，也可以接受。
完全没有自动完成的概念。举个极端的例子，所有雷已经被标出的情况下，那些不是雷的方块也需要一个个点开，有点麻烦。
对于追求完美通关的人来说，失误惩罚略严重。大图快完成的时候点错一次简直想死，建议掏出手机拍照重新点一次。状态不好经常点错的话（推理数错，点的时候脑抽搞不清楚左右键等等）建议睡一觉第二天再玩，不要硬来。
总的来说都是一些细节上的小缺陷，不算什么。
优点：
最重要的一条，每一关都一定有可以只通过推理得到的唯一解（而且这个推理不会复杂到整个图试填的级别，基本可以只靠眼睛看）。这是这个游戏的正确打开方式。有为数不多的几个英文差评说这个游戏需要猜，我只能说请给智商充值。另外，这个有唯一解的特性有时可以帮你跳过一些推理步骤（例如ABC一横排三个点，关于BC唯一的信息是BC之中有且只有一个雷，那么A一定不是雷，因为这样你才可能解出BC是什么），但其实不是必要的，建议不要用。
没用了的信息除了不是雷的点上的数字（黑数字）之外都是可以隐去的。当然如果可以把黑数字也隐去就更优雅了，不过现在这样已经很方便。
辅助线和辅助区域的设计非常贴心。在有了进度保存的第三作，如果你觉得辅助线不小心开了太多不想一个个关，或者是在某一关卡住了之后怀疑自己隐去了不该隐的数字，可以退出关卡重进，所有辅助线和隐去的数字都会恢复（当然点开的雷和数字不会，不然就不叫进度保存了）。

上面都是系统，下面说关卡。只有优点。
关卡设计都非常精巧，不是随便挑一些比较难的infinite的关然后就当作主线了。（后面的关）信息量被压缩到了最小，如果观察不同人同一关的流程，基本上会是一样的。不过这种唯一性因为条件设计得足够隐蔽，并不会无聊。
足够难。这个游戏的玩法本身可以做成扫雷那样的运气推理结合的游戏也可以做成数独那样纯粹的推理游戏，它选择了后者。有的推理很难，可能要看几分钟甚至更多才能看出来，但是也正是这种推理在完成之后给人最大的满足感。这是一个纯粹推理的游戏应该做到的。
节奏感非常好。数独这类的填空推理，都会有一种滚雪球效应。一开始填最难，后面空格少了之后就水到渠成了。Hexcell通过引入？方块，可以将你的成果截住。经常出现的情况是苦思几分钟，势如破竹扫雷一般搞定半片地图，又卡住，再苦思几分钟然后扫雷。这种张弛之间的节奏感是很难得的。

一个纯粹的解谜游戏，循序渐进、难而有趣的关卡，张弛有度的推理快感，优雅的设计（唯一解、隐去数字、画面简洁）。
全包原价34人民币总共108关加上infinite无限生成说实话已经算便宜了，打折之后全包只需10块简直不买是人。
抽象解谜类作品的必玩典范，非常推荐。

本来想先拿到全成就再来写评测的。现在肝到6-2，感觉通关大概还要一阵子，先写了算了。
本作延续了1和2的特点，但是有一些改进。首先增加了左右键切换，个人猜测挽救了不少扫雷玩家，不过我没有尝试（虽然我也是扫雷爱好者）；其次蓝色六边形的激活效果增加了闪烁，一定程度上增大了可见度，但是玩多了还是觉得有点晕。。以上就是我注意到的两点改善。
就难度而言个人感觉infinite不如2代难（好吧和plus差不多啦）。至少打到6之前没怎么卡关。[spoiler] 除了4-4，打了四五遍才过去…	[/spoiler]
当然这和plus操作还不那么熟练以及两代累计下来的经验有关。（更重要的是打到infinite我已经知道该怎么沉住气了…）还是老规矩，所有六边形都是可以通过分析打开的。所以现在基本上每次卡关都在纠结逻辑问题而不是应该蒙哪个…
至于无限模式，整体难度较任务关卡而言简单了很多。但是我在这个地方遇到一个问题：在玩世界4的时候手贱去玩了一下infinite，然后我的记录就没有了（妈蛋我世界5的成就都拿到手了好么），只好先打完无限模式成就然后重新玩任务。曾经尝试过将任务进度打到3%然后玩无限模式，任务进度在打完两关无限之后又一次被清零。打任务不影响无限模式进度。建议想刷全成就的玩家先打完6个世界再玩无限模式，或者解锁了无限模式成就以后再进行另一个。[spoiler] 无限模式的成就只要玩过60关就行，不用管自己错了几个，强迫症的福音。但是这也导致我在玩任务的时候也习惯性的浪起来，然后就玩脱了…	[/spoiler]
infinite的无限模式除了刷成就略显鸡肋。任务谜题就plus而言并没有太大的进步。刚刚通关，个人非常喜欢infinite的最后一关。难度哪个更难我不敢说。Infinite6-5虽然卡了很久，但是实际卡住的地方本身并没有很大的难度，感觉和plus卡关的时候差不太多。（只是更熟练了…）[spoiler] Infinite结束关卡的提示翻译过来大意就是每一列中的蓝块数量都是基数，里面的六边形每个都有七个蓝块。一开始没看明白意思耽误了不少时间，希望能够有所帮助ww	[/spoiler]
强烈建议打折的时候买包入，价格也相当便宜。总之是一款很良心的游戏。（有了Hexcells，妈妈再也不用担心我沉迷扫雷了~咦妈妈你为什么要删它QAQ）

28487384.review:
While I have only played a short bit so far, I can say that the puzzle aspects of this game are fairly interesting. Gameplay is (as others have noted) reminiscent of Sudoku and Minesweeper. The puzzles themselves arent very hard, and to my knowledge have no life system other than the fact that you get rewards based on how few mistakes you make. This system works very well and is very easy to understand the mechanics of the game with its "do it to learn it" tutorials.
This game has my praise as being a simple brain teaser, and I recommend it for this reason. It does its job and it does it well. Everything else below this is annoyances I have however, as this is a game about following the limited rules, and trying to do as well as possible. Some of the rules introduced, however, limit your ability to use your brain however and this peeves the hell out of me.
An annoying point for this system is that 1 mistake might be no lost points in some levels, while other more difficult puzzles might be that 2 mistakes is 2 lost points. Another issue I have with this is the need for guessing, in a system that gives its credits based on mistakes made. This game REQUIRES you to guess all the time, even in the first few levels even. And what I mean by guessing is that instead of intellectually plotting out your course, you are required to take a stand and say "well at least its just 50/50." And this is exacerbated by the "?" buttons. There is a level where there are ROWS of these unknown buttons, making it impossible to go around and therefore impossible to know how to move on without guessing. Turning this puzzle game of intelligence into a bit of a dick. And then theres the fact that the blocks you fill in as correct dont have numbers on them too. Meaning that if you are in a choke a couple blocks wide and you only get fillers then you have no way of moving forward, yet again forcing you to GUESS!

I was enjoying the game, until world 3-4. At that point, the rules were violated twice in the same puzzle (-3-). This drove the point home of an earlier puzzle where there was an entire solid block of ? cells, requiring me to randomly click and memorize the pattern for the replay. I suppose it would be possible to map the entire puzzle out and model it based on how many pattern cells are remaining, but for a "casual puzzle game" I wouldn't be expecting something like that actually be required to proceed.

The game is created fairly well, the principles and mechanics are great, but the world puzzles are badly planned out.

I did not try the Infinite portion, and since it is the biggest advertised part of the game, perhaps that is the key feature. But I can only imagine that something procedurally generated will be pertinent to the other issues experienced.

I will leave this review negative purely on the basis of requiring the developer to more consisely explain the various facets of each rule. This remains my only caveat with this game, as my review states in the introduction, I was having fun.


I humbly ask the people downvoting this review to reconsider based on the additional pertinent information.

27975260.review:
I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone & everyone including those that may not know how to play Minesweeper style games.
 
The Hexcells games involves a much improved and varied Minesweeper style gameplay compared to the standard Minesweeper clones that are nearly everywhere (including the standard Minesweeper installed on most Windows computers). 

Hexcells improve on the basic Minesweeper format in quite a number of different ways that change up the Minesweeper gameplay by adding different alternative ways on locating the mines. I won't spoil the fun of working them out for you though.

Speaking about the new and different ways of locating the mines, the main campaign of pre-defined set levels slowly introduce these new mechanics to players while explaining the methods you can use these to solve the puzzles. This starts with the basics so that even a novice easily start to play and goes all the way up to some really challenging tests towards the end with the final puzzle taking hours to complete. Luckily this game auto saves constantly so you can ways come back to where you left off.

Hexcells Infinite is probably the best of out the 3 current Hexcells games due to the new Infinite mode (that wasn't in the previous 2 games) which randomly generates new levels so there's always something to come back to or continue on after the main campaign is completed. 

As you can see in the screenshots on this store page it has a nice minimalist look with both light & dark setting so that you're not blinded by that white blackground all the time. 
It runs very well on any PC that I've had no matter the specs low or high. Variety of resolution settings which all seem to work great and a nice window mode setting so you can play while doing something else (like watching a movie or TV show, etc). 

The only improvement I could think of was if the Infinite mode had some more generation settings so you can generate a puzzle more to your liking rather then it being nearly completely random.

9.5/10

27680360.review:
Achtung! Suchtgefahr! 
Ich habe schon die beiden Vorgänger gespielt und war begeistert.
Mittlerweile träume ich von Sechsecken.

In diesem Puzzlegame geht es darum, ähnlich wie beim guten alten Minesweeper durch vorgegebene Kästchen oder Nummerierungen am Rand herauszufinden an welche Stelle ein blaues und an welche ein graues Sechseck gehört.
Von leicht bis kniffelig ist alles dabei. 

Für mich bedeutet dieses Spiel Entspannung pur und ist ein richtiger Zeitfresser. 

Im gegensatz zu seinen beiden Vorgängen bringt Hexcells Infinite einen Unendlichkeitslevel mit, das jedes Mal andere Vorgaben und Formen des Spielfeldes ausspuckt. Somit wird es im Gegensatz zu den Vorgängern nicht langweilig.

Von mir gibt es für so viele Stunden Entspannung, Gehirntraining und Spaß alle Daumen nach oben.

看好评率这么高，就趁着打折买来当个扫雷加强版随便玩玩。然后发现这小游戏确实有过人之处。
扫雷大家都知道，有些地方就得靠蒙，二选一运气不好就触雷gg。但是这游戏就不需要蒙，似乎每一关都经过精心设计，以至于一局下来的每一步都一定能用推理解决，只要肯动脑就能零失误，光这一点就让它成为我心中最完美的扫雷游戏了。
难度方面，因为规则多（但是教程循序渐进理解毫无困难），难度是要比扫雷高不少的，大概从3-1开始就不是那种一眼就能看出结果的局了。实在过不了瞎点几下碰运气也是可以打开局面的。
还没玩到无限关，很期待电脑算法的表现。无论如何，单单前面的这些关所表现出的素质就值一个大大的好评。

26950229.review:
The puzzles in the main game are well crafted, the developer having put some real thought into how they're laid out and how the player may approach solving them, but there aren't really enough puzzles of this sort in the game. Even with the previous two games, there's less than 100 handcrafted levels, most of which take only a couple of minutes to complete. 

I also would have loved more puzzles like the final one in the game where additional rules were added, putting and interesting twist on solving it.

The level generator on the other hand is somewhat disappointing, due to the seemingly limited number of puzzle layouts - how the puzzle initially appears ignoring all hints - though at 100 million possible puzzles, it does add an almost "infinite" number of levels to solve, which can serve as an interesting timewaster.

The Hexcells Levels reddit at https://www.reddit.com/r/hexcellslevels/ must be mentioned though, since it is a community based on creating further handcrafted puzzles for Hexcells Infinite and I can't recommend it enough.

With all of this in mind, I highly recommend Hexcells Infinite.

(First off, try to get the prequels Hexcells and Hexcells Plus as well, they make a good progression when played in order)

That said, this is the best of the Hexcells saga.

+ Relaxing and satisfying puzzles plus good ambient sound, just like in the prequels.
+ Random level generator (thus "Infinite") for when you just need more. Adds a ton of replayability.

- The random levels aren't as satisfying as the handcrafted ones.
+ Fortunately the game allows custom puzzles. There are some great ones at the hexcellslevels subreddit.

All around, this game is a must if you are remotely interested in the genre.

26837034.review:
The final, and most definitive, Hexcells experience.

If you're only going to buy one Hexcells game, get this one. It has the best (read: hardest) puzzles and the (admittedly easy) Infinite Mode - which while not actually "infinite", will take you longer than the average lifespan of a human being to complete. It's pointless to get only one Hexcells game though, since the Complete Pack is dirt cheap on a sale.

So if you like Minesweeper and Picross, would love to play a bastard child of those two, and see this game on sale - don't wait. Just take your credit card out of your wallet and input them digits into Steam's purchase form.

26813646.review:
Hexcell games are a cross between minesweeper and picross set on a hex grid. I've always found the game play enjoyable and the music/sound that comes with them extremely relaxing.

In Hexcells Infinite you get the most challenging puzzles of the three games, as well as an Infinite mode that allows for playing a random game from 100,000,000 other puzzles. The Infinite puzzles aren't as challenging as the pre-made puzzles included but that hasn't stopped my from doing about 3000 of them.

26622356.review:
Das Spiel ist mittelprächtig.

Das Spiel hat (wie seine Vorgänger) 36 vorgegebene Rätsel und etwas die Hälfte von ihnen ist gut, ja sehr gut, die anderen sind schlecht. Für erstere mag ich das Spiel ganz ausdrücklich, für die anderen halte ich das Spiel für schlecht.

Das Rätsel sind (oder sollten es sein) reine Logikrätsel, bei denen man mit Hilfe und beginnend mit den vorgegebenen Hinweisen die Felder mit unbekannten Inhalt als Blau ("Mine") oder Schwarz ("Leer") kennzeichnet. Die dazu nötigen logischen Schlüsse können einfacher oder komplexer Natur sein.

Es ist vergleichbar mit Sudoku, wo es auch einfache oder komplexe Rätsel gibt. Bei letzteren muss man vielerlei Überlegungen anstellen, bis man gewisse Schlüsse definitiv ziehen kann und damit weitere Hinweise auf die verbliebenen Felder erhält.

Aber wie bei Sudoku sollte es nie passieren, dass man keine definitven Schlüsse mehr ziehen kann und also mehre alternative Lösungsmöglichkeiten übrig bleiben.

Genau dies ist aber bei in etwa der Hälfte der Rätsel der Fall. Bei einigen dieser Rätsel könnte es, das sei zugegeben, noch sein, dass mit außerordentlich komplexen Überlegungen noch weitere Schlüsse gezogen werden können (welchen Spaß hat man da noch daran? Man bedenke, z.B. 30 Minen auf 70 Felder verteilen und jeweils prüfen, ob die Randbedingungen erfüllt sind, ohne zu wissen, ob eine eindeutige Lösung existiert, ist eine Lebensaufgabe), bei den meisten bin ich mir aber verdammt sicher, dass sie nicht eindeutig lösbar sind.

Dass es nur eine einzige, vom Spiel akzeptierte Lösung gibt, das sollte klar sein, hilft da nicht aus der Bredoullie. Das wäre ja wie beim Sudoku, wenn man die Lösung nachblätert und daraus schließt, dass das Sudoku eine eindeutige Lösung hat.

So sehr mich genau die Rätsel begeistert haben, wo man gerade so mit viel Überlegung eine eindeutige Lösung finden konnte, finde ich es insgesamt schlecht, wenn dies m.E. bei etwa jedem zweiten Rätsel nicht möglich ist.

Das Spiel enthält nun auch zufallsgenerierte Rätsel. Das ist grundsätzlich schon mal gut, weil so der Rätselspaß verlängert werden kann. Andererseits sollte dies doch zeigen, dass die Entwickler ein Computerprogramm zur Erstellung der Rätsel verwendeten. Ob sie dies auch bei den 36 vorgegebenen Rätseln taten, weiss ich nicht. Aber um so mehr frage ich mich, wie es passieren konnte, dass einige Rätsel nicht eindeutig lösbar sind.

Die Spielidee und die "guten", meist anspruchsvollen Rätsel sind, wie gesagt, aber sehr gut.

Der Spielstand eines Rätsel wird nun (im Gegensatz zu den Vorgängern) sogar gespeichert, aber nicht in der Form, dass man dahin zurück kommt, wenn man sich beim Rätsel vergallopiert hat, sondern nur inder Form, die eine Pause beim Spielen erlaubt ohne bei der nächsten Sitzung das Rätsel neu beginnen zu müssen.

Pro & Contra:

+ Sehr gute Spielidee
+ Viele gute, anspruchsvolle Rätsel

- Viele nicht eindeutig lösbare Rätsel

Wegen der Mängel im Rätseldesign (die zumindest den Spielspaß töten, wenn sie auftreten) kann ich das Spiel trotz der guten Spielidee und vieler guter Rätsel nicht empfehlen. Dennoch kann das Spiel teilweise sehr gefallen.

[i]Falls mir jemand aufzeigt, wie alle Rätsel durch Logik lösbar sind, ohne einen Computer in Anspruch zu nehmen, wäre ich interessiert daran, dazu zu lernen.[/i]

26545470.review:
This review is written for Hexcells, Hexcells Plus, and Hexcells Infinite
[h1]Hexagonal Puzzler[/h1]
[b]Reviewed after completing all achievements[/b]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Hexcells plays like an average 2d puzzle games, you click your mouse to solve the puzzles not hard.  Untill you get to the later puzzles that is.  This game has one of the most ingenious puzzle systems I've played to date.  It isn't so complex that you're left scratching your head at what the rules that these puzzles follow are, but it isn't so simple that it becomes boring after you've completied a few of them.

I will say that while trying to %100 this game I looked up a few of the solutions [i]after[/i] completing them once.  This is because this game has a 'perfect' rating, in which there must be no missclicks on a puzzle to actually complete it for the achievements.  And while I did mess up sometimes when solving these puzzles, most of the time these missclicks were due to me acidentally resting my fingers on my buttons while trying to solve a hard section, or right clicking when I should have left clicked that time damn it!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

This game has a great look to it, but playing it at night will strain your eyes due to the brightness of it.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

This is a great game and well worth your time if you're looking for a puzzle game to play.  Though the achievement in Hexcells Infinite where you must complete some of the random puzzles just takes far too long.

[h1] 8/10 [/h1]

Hexcells Infinite est le troisième titre de la série Hexcells.
Mais est-ce le plus abouti?

Si Hexcells Plus était "plus" difficile qu'Hexcells, est-ce que Hexcells Infinite l'est infiniment plus?
Loin s'en faut!
Hexcells Infinite est plus simple qu'Hexcells Plus, il nous invite simplement à revoir notre façon d'appréhender les tableaux.

Il faut chercher la signification du "Infinite" ailleurs.

Outre le même nombre de tableaux que dans les deux précédents titres, vous avez un second mode de jeu logiquement appelé "Infinite".
Ce mode consiste en une infinité (enfin techniquement 1.000.000.000, mais ça fait déjà beaucoup!) de tableaux générés aléatoirement.

Il n'y a malheureusement rien de réellement plus intéressant à dire sur ce titre si vous avez déjà joué à la série.


L'affreux.

26496357.review:
Gran juego de lógica basado en [i]buscaminas[/i] y [i]sudoku[/i]: 
 · Las celdas te dan información de su alrededor;  en este caso son hexágonos
 · Existen números que indican la cantidad de "minas" en toda una línea recta

Mezclando estas dos mecánicas y un par mas (minas contiguas o separadas, etc), se llegan a conseguir puzzles MUY complejos. Todos ellos siempre con una solución a la que poder llegar sin usar para nada el azar. Estamos hablando de unos últimos niveles en los que, sin inspiración afortunada, pueden costar cerca de una hora planteando posibilidades absudas y demostrando que son incorrectas al toparse con un error. 

Este nivel de dificultad solo se encuentra en [i]Hexcells Infinite[/i], ya que es la tercera y última entrega. Reúne todas las mecánicas, y por ello también todos los puzzles grandes y costosos de resolver. El primer juego, [i]Hexcells[/i], es sencillo y refrescante. El segundo, [i]Hexcells Plus[/i], añade un concepto extra para amunetar las posibilidades de los puzzles. Por supuesto, todos ellos tienen una breve introducción que permite jugarlos sin orden. Ah, y una maravillosa banda sonora zen que ayuda a relajarse y concentrarse <3

[b]Concluyendo;[/b] el mayor avance que aporta [i]Hexcells Infinite[/i] es el modo infinito, un generador de niveles de aleatorios (999.999.999 posibes seeds). Los puzzles son de una dificultad media-avanzada, perfecta para presentar algo de desafio pero nunca pararte a pensar demasiado. Esto, obviamente, lo hace el mas rejugable de las tres entregas. 

··Totalmente recomendado, calidad excepcional (ya me gustaría a mí hacer un juego como este <33)··

26463168.review:
More of the same as the previous Hexcells games; if you have played those than this is less a natural progression and more of just filling the same niche.  Which doesn't mean it is bad by any means!  Rather it is just a significantlly expanded collection of logic puzzles without any real alteration in figuring them out.  That having been said, there is a LOT here.  The Level progression seems a bit more erratic than previous ones - some of the puzzles in Chapter 6 are easier than previous puzzles you encounter - but that isn't too much of a drawback in the grand scheme.  I've barely tapped into the "random" puzzle generator (reputed to be 1,000,000 puzzles at your reach) and that is really where the meat of the title is; be aware that the Level campaign of Hexcells Infinite took significantly less time for me to complete than Hexcells Plus (roughly half the time!).  If you don't plan to play the random levels that may be something to keep in mind, but I would still wholeheartedly recommend the game regardless.  

On Mac the game ran extremely smooth with no hiccups, freezes, or CTD.  The only problem is when using a Mac Magic Mouse sometimes right clicks were wrongly interpreted as left clicks, ruining perfect level runs (I'm looking at you 6-5!!!!).  If you are a perfectionist and using a Magic Mouse ... use caution or you can ruin 30+ minutes of effort in an instant.  It should also be noted that perfect runs don't have to be perfect: you can actually make a wrong move or two and still get credit as acing the level on some of them.

26333234.review:
Enjoyed this game a lot! Gives a minesweeper kind of feel, which adds in more puzzle enhancements as you progress through the levels. Starts off very basic so that you get a feel for the game, and then you look up and all you want to do is perfect all the levels. So the games goes, there are a few blocks with numbers on the board and you have to puzzle out whether the block is another number or a blue block. The block has 6 sides (obviously) and the number says how many blue block are touching it. As the game progresses, it adds {} around a number to say the blue blocks are sequential, or -- around a number to say they are split. It then goes father to say that there are so may in this line by putting the number on the outside of that row or column. The easy feature which helps a lot for bigger puzzles is that you can click on the outside number and it draws a line through that row or column to see which ones.

All in all lots of fun and challenging at the same time. Gets more challenging as the game goes on. Expansion on the origional Hexcells. The intimate mode and challenge to get achievement is very repeatitive...

26230932.review:
Hexcells Infinite is a fun little game that will make you feel smart... for a while. Like all the best puzzle games, its rules are simple but their applications can be fiendishly difficult.

I love the mental gymnastics I have to do while I'm playing. "If this is a blue cell, then this column has five blue cells, which means there's only room for one more, which means that black 4 is forced to use two cells from the neighbouring column, which gives that nearby black 1 too many blue cells... therefore (going back to the start) this can't be a blue cell, so it must be black instead." Proof by contradiction. At some point the proof gets too complicated for me to keep in my head so I have to resort to pen and paper, but that's fun too.

I wish the game contained a tool to mark "candidate" cells à la Minesweeper, and it would be great to be able to toggle the advanced rules for the randomly generated levels (I find the "number inside blue cell" mechanic makes the game really slow), but those are only minor complaints. Recommended.

Ну и конечно же, разработчик шел к этому целых полгода, теперь можно не клепать новые части игры, потому что наконец то появился рандомный генератор уровней! *Фейерверк* Уровни генерируются на основе некоторого числа, сида, которое вы можете ввести любое, минимум восьмизначное, или сегодняшнюю дату, или ваше ДР. 26045206.review:
I feel the same way as many other reviewers, it is one of the best puzzle games out there and even projected on all games easily one of my top 5, which you can check seeing the (a little inflated) hours I played it.
At first I didn't like it at all, because especially in the first few levels it seemed like a hexagonal minesweeper, in the way that only the early conceptualizing phase is fun, but this phase just keeps coming with new features and of course there never is this 50:50 tile in the end.
That's all for the main game which "plus" and to some extend the original version also had.
Additionally, Infinite has the new addition of the eponymous "infinite" randomly (aka algorithmically) created levels, which to be honest are not that amazing, granted I played less than 0.01% of them all, but like 90% aren't challenging in any capacity. 
You can get a few good ones, but generally the only fun aspect would be speedruning them (I would recommend having fewer levels and then a leaderboard for the respective levels).
The feature of the game that I used 90% of my time on, is one that you may not have even seen at first or second glance: custom levels that you can copy into your game and create yourself (no creator interface thus far though).
https://www.reddit.com/r/hexcellslevels/ has 100+ posts of levels and level packs that are all amazing that is why this is  in my opinion the only game of the trilogy you really HAVE to get. 
I got all three for like 2 bucks, but this game is easily worth the 5 it costs normally.
The game of course doesn't get worse the longer it's out it gets better, so you might aswell wait for a sale, unless you've really tasted blood now.

26025188.review:
Did you like Hexcells and want more? If yes, buy it.

Unlike plus, this feels like DLC which is good if you wanted more. The puzzles are harder and get harder a hell of a lot faster until at the end, you're facing a wall of hexes to clear. I like the infinite mode. I feel like it would be better on mobile where you could just pull out a grid and play but I find it relaxing.  Play this if you want harder puzzles or infinite (really a million) puzzles.

---About the game in general---
Hexcells is a logic game sort of like minesweeper but at any given point in the game, you always have a logical way to solve the problem. This part is important because it gives puzzle fans something that relies only on skill and not on guesswork.

26004646.review: The original Hexcells and this one should have been the same game (Infinite being an eventual free update or DLC). This is the definitive version of Hexcells, but it's missing the easy beginner levels from the original.  It also has a different set of sound effects to it.  If you played Hexcells Plus, Hexcells Infinite is just that with slightly different puzzles for the stages and a random puzzle generator for those who need more content.  The only problem I have with this is the puzzles sometimes require a bit of guessing, so mistakes aren't always your fault but a lack of information being conveyed to you about the empty hexes.  I personally think you should play Hexcells first, skip Hexcells Plus, and play Hexcells Infinite if you simply like the original.

25995451.review:
[COPIATO E INCOLLATO DALLA RECENSIONE DI HEXCELLS]
Il vostro PC è un tostapane?
Avete speso tante di quelle ore su Campo Minato, Sudoku e simili al punto tale che avreste potuto laurearvi, trovare un lavoro e sposarvi?
Se la risposta è Sì, allora questo è il gioco che fa per voi.

Hexcells è un puzzle game molto interessante ispirato a Campo Minato con qualche richiamo a Sudoku. In ogni livello dovrete sbloccare tutti gli esagoni, e per farlo il gioco vi fornisce indizi come per esempio quante celle blu si trovano in una colonna o sono adiacenti a un esagono nero, ecc.
Man mano che si procede la complessità dei livelli aumenta sempre più, ma comunque, il gioco non è un gioco basato sulla fortuna: niente è lasciato al caso. Gli indizi che vi forniscono sono strutturati in maniera tale che potete finirlo senza fare un errore (sfida che gli amanti hardcore dei puzzle apprezzeranno).
Graficamente si presenta minimalista e piacevole, in grado di girare anche su PC estremamente datati.

L'unico difetto è l'assenza di un generatore di livelli e la possibilità di poter salvare la partita anche durante un livello. Per la seconda spesso ovviavo a ciò facendo uno screenshot del livello.

Hexcells Plus aggiunge sostanzialmente altri livelli, più complessi presentando gli stessi difetti del primo.
Hexcells Infinite, invece, oltre ad aggiungere nuovi livelli risolve anche i difetti legati ai primi due giochi, ovvero la generazione casuale di livelli e la possibilità di salvare la partita.
Sono giochi che consiglierei l'acquisto in bundle (Hexcells Complete Pack) e magari a prezzo scontato.
