25979490.review:
The third part of the Hexcells series is definitely its peak. There are no new game mechanics. The tutorial aspect is handled better than in the first game. There is a nice progression between easy and challenging levels and the game felt much more balanced than the first two rather one-sided parts. The pre-made levels took me about 10 hours to complete as a seasoned logic puzzle player and featured a few really nice stages.
Arguably its main selling point is the titular infinite mode. Finally Hexcells allows you to generate millions of levels and thus offers near infinite gameplay. The levels are usually much easier than the pre-made levels, which is completely fine with me and makes this an even better casual game for inbetween. My only gripe with this mode is its large randomness. Generated levels take anywhere between 3 and 20 minutes to complete. I would have liked a little more control over length and difficulty.

The interface is much improved compared to its predecessors. Finally you can mute the music independenty from the sound effects. The game lets you save levels mid-progress, visibility of areas can be improved and you can swap mouse buttons more easily. It is such an improvement that it makes you wonder why the previous two games weren't patched to this UI. Like with the other parts I've never encountered a bug, error or crash.

Due to the infinite mode this game as a stand-alone is worth full price. I recommend picking it up as part of the compilation or during one of the frequent sales which make this brilliant game a real bargain.

25789009.review:
Hexcells Infinite is probably the absolute puzzle game in the Hexcells series ([url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890/]Hexcells[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900/]Plus[/url]). It feels like a new version of the previous two with new levels and a random generator for even more levels. Since this feels like a refresh of the series I will copy/paste elements from my review of the previous two and build upon them.

Hexcells is a fairly simple game, much of it employing a combination of mechanics from minesweeper and nonograms (Picross) on a non standard 2D grid. It is a logic game were rules of the levels are defined by numbered brackets (minesweeper style) that give information on whether nearby brackets are false or true. This is sometimes mixed in with column markers that do the same, but for a column (picross style). To deepen the gameplay a bit more, you are sometimes also presented with special rules beside the numbers which frankly, in my humble opinion, make minesweeper look like a joke.

The base levels start easy enough but the difficulty curve steeps beyond what was comfortable in the first game yet stays bellow the hellish fires of Hexcells Plus. This time round we are presented with a random level generator which definitely extends the game but sadly does not escape the dredge facing all random generated content. Even though Hexcells level are simple, they always feel like it is you against the designer. Where the designer tried fooling you with level symmetry, hiding some emotion in the puzzles. In contrast, random generated levels feel cold and somewhat uninviting. It's not a dealbreaker by any means but I would have opted for community designed level sharing instead.

As with previous games, It kept me coming back. Infinite is challenging and fun. Cheap and as long as you'd like it to be. Took me 13 hours to get 100% achievements but I have 999,999,940 levels to go.

25784561.review: Un petit jeu de réflexion très bon avec une bande-son sympathique. Le jeu se laisse parcourir agréablement et moins rapidement que ses prédécesseurs car plus difficile. Il profite des deux premiers Hexcell et n'ajoute là que de nouveaux niveaux plus longs et plus complexes, mais beaucoup plus satisfaisants, et a eu la bonne idée d'intégrer un mode "infini" générant d'autres puzzles, pour prolonger l'expérience.

25456670.review:
[h1]А можно просто объяснять всем, кто этого ещё не понял, что "Тетрис", пасьянсы, шахматные и карточные программы, Bejeweled, Lines, Jawbreaker и прочие — не компьютерные игры. На компьютере? Да, и что с того? Так вот и в нашем случае: "Hexcells Infinite" на компьютере "только ездит", по-настоящему он его не использует. © Андрей Ленский, журнал ЛКИ[/h1]

[b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] - логическая казуальная игра, совмещающая в своих правилах "Сапёра", японские кроссворды, щепотку новизны разработчиков, дополнена нетривиальными ситуациями, в которой необходимо перевернуть определенным образом гексы на игровом поле, с режимом бесконечной генерации головоломок.

По аналогии с сапёром есть игровое поле, состоящее из гексов, на котором присутствуют чёрные гексы с цифрами в середине, показывающими дополнительное количество чёрных гексов в пределах одного радиус-круга. Всё остальное - гексы голубые. Благо в настройках при запуске можно поменять раскладку, а то всё по старинке ищем отсутствие "мин", вместо их присутствия. При прохождении 6 головоломок откроется ещё 6, могут добавиться новые условия, например, количество голубых гексов в радиусе двух и т.д. Задача - решить все головоломки. В каждой головоломке можно сделать одну ошибку. Обучение текстовое на простом английском, да и игра начинается с интуитивно понятных задач. В игре остались ситуации, когда приходится выбирать наугад, ввиду недостатка информации, чего не было в оригинальной Hexcells. Слово "Infinite" в названии не просто так, ибо теперь нам подарили режим случайной генерации из 999 999 999 комбинаций головоломок! Появилось сохранение результата!

Графически игра сделана в стиле минимализма. Радиус двух, благо, выделен яркой серой линией!

Музыка же представляет из себя эмбиент, вот только если заранее известно какие гексы где находятся, быстрое переворачивание приведёт к игре, как на клавесине. Озвучки никакой нет.

Управляется игра мышью.

Недостатки: хоть и присутствует разнообразие графического разрешения, но почему-то 1280х1024 нет. Для обладателей математического склада ума эта игра развлечёт на работе больше, чем ранее упомянутые "LYNE" и "Faerie Solitaire" и ещё сильнее, чем прародительница Hexcells и Hexcells Plus, ввиду бесконечного режима. Достойная компьютерная версия не компьютерной игры. [b]Hexcells Infinite[/b], рекомендую.

P.S.: на случай отключения интернета на каждом компьютере для убийства времени теперь в обязательном порядке ставится эта игра!

25442991.review:
La série Hexcells offre à chaque fois une série de puzzles à résoudre sur le même principe.

On commence par des puzzles simples et on introduit petit à petit de nouvelles mécaniques qui complexifient la chose. Et c'est bien pensé.

Côté réalisation, c'est bien fait, minimaliste, et à mon avis un peu parresseux, mais j'y reviendrais plus tard.
Les graphismes sont simples mais ça passe bien, le son c'est pareil mais à mon avis la musique est un peu trop pesante avec le temps, un peu ambiante mais sans grande qualité.

Les puzzles sont bien choisis et donnent toujours une solution pour trouver la solution logique sans faire d'erreurs ni tricher.
Je parle de tricher parcequ'en effet, aucun mécanisme ne permet de détecter une erreur quand on tente un coup sans raison logique, qu'on le fasse exprès ou pas.
Vous serez donc face à vous même dans la réalisation des puzzles, chacun fera comme il veut, mais à mon avis le jeu ne vaut le coup que lorsqu'on tente de résoudre un puzzles sans faire aucune erreur.

Hexcells infinite est très bien, et ajoute un mode infini ou des niveaux sont générés aléatoirement, mais ces niveaux sont beaucoup trop faciles car on a trop de possibilité de jeu pour avancer vers la résolution. Néammoins ce mode est bienvenu et remplit son rôle de passe temps.

C'est comme ça que j'ai envie de qualifier Hexcells, c'est moins un jeu qu'un passe temps. C'est pas très dur, même si vous allez sans doute bloquer un peu sur un niveau ou deux, une fois qu'on a compris le truc ça va vite.

J'ai néanmoins passé pas mal de temps sur les jeux, donc il faut croire que c'est un passe temps sympa.
(ne vous fiez pas trop au temps que j'ai passé sur le jeu, je l'ai laissé tourné quelques heures par "accident" dans le vide, mais pour débloquer tous les succès à la régulière ça prendre quand même pas mal d'heures)

Malgré tout, il y a tant de jeux bien meilleur que je ne recommande pas ce titre.

25177968.review:
Hexcells is, on the most basic level, a more sophisticated version of Minesweeper. You are given a layout of golden hex tiles, possibly with one or more of them already highlighted or flipped. Flipped tiles have numbers on them, and also labels indicating whether or not adjacent tiles which should be highlighted are continuous or non-continuous (or no designator at all). There are also row and column labels which allow you to see how many tiles need to be highlighted in any given row or column.

Each puzzle mixes these up in a unique way to push you to solve it.

Thinking about this game as a more sophisticated version of minesweeper is, I think, fairly ideal, because that is more or less what it is, and the function it serves. It is something to throw away a bit of time on, not sit down and play continuously.

It is about as fun as Minesweeper is, and I’d basically consider it filling that role in your game library.

The sequels get steadily harder, and unfortunately, I'm not 100% sure all the puzzles are solvable without guessing - there were a few points where I got stuck and the only way forward seemed to be taking a guess. That happened on only a small fraction of the puzzles, but I'm not sure if I was simply not good enough, or if they are legitimately ambiguous.

My advice? Pass. It isn’t a bad puzzle game, but it isn’t anything remarkable either. If you did get it as part of a bundle or something, it isn’t a terrible thing to install and just screw around with when you’d mess around with solitaire or minesweeper or whatever, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to buy this.

[h1]A Minimalistic Puzzle Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/td3a_kVk6zU
+ The gameplay is very simple and mainly consists of flipping over tiles to find the correct pattern. Very comparable to Minesweeper as unactivated tiles will have a number which designates how many adjacent tiles connected to it should be flipped. By using this information along with info from other hex squares you are able to begin eliminating / breaking unneeded tiles and finding the correct ones to activate.
+ Nice relaxing ambient background sounds that is very peaceful
+ The game gets quite challenging later on and has plenty of stages to keep you content for hours

- For me personally, this game feels a bit repetitive after a short while once you understand the mechanics. Every level is different and it does try to add a few new mechanics as you progress, but overall it was just a bit too simplistic visually.

I have played many puzzle games. The hexcells series is simply, in my humble opinion, the very best. It avoids the pitfall of so many similar games: trial and errror. While interesting games like Lyme, Quell, Kami, Unium, etc. are asking you to think ahead, sure, but mostly to try, end up in a dead end, try something else, get stuck, try again, etc.  this is not the case here. The only real way to play for me is to accept no error. In any case, there is never a reason to guess or play the probabilities. There is always a solution and it's always certain.

Clever, just challenging enough without being frustrating, but also soothing. This last opus is even infinite...

マインスイーパ+ピクロスの様なパズルゲームです。
へクス(六角形のマス)の中の数字は隣接する塗りつぶせる青マスの数を、盤外の数字は直線状に存在する青マスの数をそれぞれ表しているほか、{}で囲まれた数字は連続した青マス等々、パズルを複雑に、面白くするルールがいくつかあります。

24449248.review:
If you think "sudoku is fun, but I'd rather try something new", this is a great diversion.  Building up the core concepts and leaps of logic necessary to tackle the end game, level by level, you slowly grow quicker and more efficient at making the deductions and planning your assault on this "mindsweeper on crack".

First you'll pore over seemingly impossible puzzles, wondering how you could possibly make headway.  Then...  You'll see something.  You'll realize a single hexagon has to be blue or clear.  You'll realize this forces its neighbor to be one or the other.  You'll ponder the region, column, or row.  Slowly the puzzle will take shape and bow to your superior intellect.  Eureka...  Satisfaction.  The hexlord reigns.

This game will test your patience, and it's delayed gratification.  Self-select whether this is your cup of tea.

Nitpicks: I wish there had been more end-game content, as the "infinite" mode is a fair step down from the level 5/6 puzzles.

24410875.review:
Review: "Hexcells: Infinite"
9/10

Hexcells: Infinite is the third and final installment in the Hexcells trilogy.  I would highly reccomend this game regardless of whether or not you've played the prior two.  Like the previous two, it begins quite simply and progresses in difficulty and complexity through the introduction of more and more complex elements.  What sets this game apart from the past two is twofold.  The first is the difficulty ramps up much more quickly and to a much greater degree.  The second is the ability to randomly generate puzzles, which are solveable and add a near infinite replayability factor.

If you like puzzle games, this is the best one you're going to get on steam.

这个游戏好玩，非常好玩！和扫雷很像，但是比扫雷高不知道哪里去，无论从趣味性还是逻辑性上都碾压扫雷。三作我都买了，全完美通关之后来这里写个评测表示资磁，如果还能有后续就更好了。

不过有一说一，对！就是挑刺！人为设计的关卡还是比电脑自动生成的要好玩很多，无限模式开局一堆的3、4、5基本上就把整张图点亮大半了，剩下的基本上就是机械性操作。经常一条线上会有10+的数字，虽然说数数大家都会也不难，不过盯着这样的画面看久了会头晕，数的时候会愣神数错。玩的时间不宜过长，算是一点小小的不足吧。


打折的时候好像会三作打包一起卖的样子，建议等打折一起入。如果等不及的话，我个人更喜欢2设计的关卡，不过其实三作前面关卡设计都是一个路数的，无限的话是可以玩很多次，买哪个看个人喜好吧。

24101095.review:
I read the (few) negative reviews because I was curious what could cause someone to vote negatively.  Most of the negative reviewers were down voting because they felt cheated that the ? cells forced them to guess.  Truth is that if I had to guess I would likely feel cheated as well.  Here's the thing:

If you are guessing, you're doing it wrong.

Hexcells is not about guessing.  You can complete every puzzle without guessing.  That has been my experience.  I have completed all three games (less two puzzles at the end of the third that I'm still struggling with), plus nearly a hundred on inifite.  Mind you, there are some puzzles that you have to spend a whole bunch of time trying to bend the logic to your will, but...

That's the point, right?

The question mark cells simply don't tell you anything not to force you to guess, but to keep the level of challenge up.  Which, IMO, I think is just about perfect.  Great job devs.

tl;dr

No guessing or cheating necessary.  Whole-heartedly recommend.

Edit from six months later:  I have now completed all the puzzles in the main games, and over three hundred puzzles in the infinite mode.  Still looking for one where I have to guess.  In my top five favorite games of all time.

24007589.review:
Simply the best puzzle game series you're going to find. Hexcells Infinite is the best of the three, but working your way from the first game to the third (with its prize of an unending number of puzzles) brings as much satisfaction as the puzzles themselves.
Instead of being repetitive and mind-numbing, the Hexcells games are ones you can relax into and play for hours without tiring of them. Unlike most logic puzzles they maintain difficulty levels and continually present challenges without ever relying on guesswork.

This entire series is a must-have for anyone who enjoys logic puzzles.

24005059.review:
Hexcells Infinite is a fitting conclusion to the Hexcells trifecta. The campaign boasts some of the most difficult hand-crafted puzzles seen in the series, and [i]more of them[/i], thanks to an abbreviated tutorial. (You really are expected to have already familiarized yourself with the mechanics via the previous two Hexcells installments.) The new Infinite Mode is a fantastic new feature, producing a near-endless barrage of randomly generated puzzles. It's immediatley obvious that the random puzzles are not as difficult as the hand-crafted campaign puzzles (the constructions leave far too many unnecessary hints), but it's nice to have something different to sic the ol' brain on each evening.

If you've enjoyed the first two Hexcells installments, you simply must get Hexcells Infinite and complete your experience.

I'm glad I got the whole Hexcells series. Each one of them has been incredibly fun.  I am spoiled now — I will never be able to go back to Minesweeper again. Or Sudoku, for that matter.

23932310.review:
首先，Hexcells Infinite 算是 Hexcells 的正式版，它包含 Hexcells 的全部关卡，并且新增了难度陡增的更多关卡。
    Hexcells Infinite 是一款与扫雷非常类似的解谜游戏，简单来说就是通关棋盘上给出的数字去推断周围的格子是否可以打开。难度上比扫雷要高很多，但是与扫雷相比，Hexcells Infinite 有一个显著的优点，就是这个游戏绝不含有“不确定性”，意思就是你的每一个判断都应该是有据可循的，而不是靠臆测。
    目前这个游戏我已经通关了，在基本关卡中（共36关），后期会有很多关让你感觉无从入手。但是这个游戏存在一个我称之为“难度自适应”的机制。简单来说，如果只为了解开一个棋盘，你完全可以直接在每个格子上，左右键各按一次；如果是为了完美通关，你更可以试开整个棋盘，然后截图，重开，照着图片过关即可。
    所以，如果不想要难度，这个游戏可以说是完全没有难度的；如果想要一点点难度，那么只有在你实在想不出答案的情况下试开几个格子就行了。但是，如果你是一位愿意花时间烧脑、去亲力亲为解开每一关的玩家，那么作为一个纯靠推算完美通关的玩家，我负责任地给你打一剂定心针：我保证每一关每一个格子都是可以靠推理来完成的，不存在无解以至于你必须去拼人品的地方。所以想要挑战自己的玩家，不妨多花上一些时间——甚至可能是几天——去好好琢磨一下那些难住你的关卡吧。并且，这个游戏由于其推算的性质，导致你的解法与其他人未必相同，所以想要找攻略是很难做到的，只有两条路摆在眼前：要么看答案或者拼人品打开一块格子，要么就是耐心去推理，总有解开的一天。
    另外需要补充一点，这个游戏为了保证其耐玩性，加入了无尽挑战模式，可以输入任意八位数字来挑战随机关卡，也可以用当天的日期来生成随机关。但是无尽模式的关卡与正常流程相比，明显质量差了太多，约束条件要么是很无脑，要么就是太强以至于过多的线索指向同一个格子。无尽模式可玩性不强。所以综合来说，这只是一个小品游戏，36关普通关过了以后就可以删游戏了。
最后，如果你是解谜游戏的发烧友，我推荐这款并不昂贵的小品游戏，它可以确保你大约一周的时间内有东西来磨砺脑子。

23822215.review:
When I reviewed the original Hexcells, I was rather hesitant with praise.  It's a great idea, but there were a number of things I had issues with in the first game.  Hexcells Infinite fixed pretty much all my issues, and is a fantastic game.

This game is a terrific logic puzzle, along the lines of Macross/Nanograms/Griddlers/Pic-a-Pix - whatever you call them.  It's more complicated than any of those, however, bringing in some ideas that seem almost Minesweeper-esque, without the guesswork of Minesweeper.

The first two games in this series feel almost like tough tutorials for this third game.  This one has much more complex logic puzzles, but not a single one needs any guessing or significant backtracking to solve.  

The 36 main puzzles take a lot longer than the first two games - one of my biggest complaints about the first Hexcells is that it seemed rather short.  Hexcells Infinite not only takes longer to solve due to the tough puzzles, but it also has a random puzzle generator, with almost one billion puzzles in it.  They're all easier than the hardest of the Infinite puzzles, but there are some that require a bit of work, and it's great to know you'll never run out of puzzles.

My other large issue with the previous two Hexcells was the lack of any save function, which Infinite added (thank goodness).

Overall, Hexcells Infinite is a fantastic game for anyone who likes logic puzzles.  I can't recommend it enough, especially at the cheap price.  Buy it in a package with the other two Hexcells if you can afford it, because the other two ramp up the difficulty much more gently than Infinite does.  But if you can only afford one of them, definitely get this one.

Since I've seen a lot of reviewers do personal scales, and it's helped me a lot to decide what to buy, I put my own here. [b]I give Hexcells Infinite a 5 out of 5[/b]. Additionally, I usually only give a thumbs up if I got at least two hours of enjoyment out of it for every dollar I spent, and this game did that. 

[b]5: Amazing game, easily worth the full price.[/b]
4: Good game, solid addition to the genre, might want to wait for a discount.
3: Pretty entertaining game, but some issues. Buy at a discount unless you love the genre.
2: More cons than pros, a lot of issues. Only buy with a strong discount, and only if the game truly sounds like something you'd enjoy.
1: Don't get this game unless it's free. Even then, consider spending your time playing something decent.

23593362.review:
很不情愿地给好评，尽管这个游戏在很多方面让人太不爽了！！！

先说好的方面吧：
1. 很喜欢游戏的规则和关卡的设计，难度比前两作高，需要很仔细地观察和占内存很大的推理233~ 虽然还是有过量的信息，但总体很精巧，非常有挑战性！
2. 增加了保存功能，再也不用为了打大的图吃不了饭了！

然后是不好的方面：
1. 默认左右键操作和扫雷是反的，需要改设置（这不重要）。
2. 操作非常捉鸡，只能用左右键一个个点，点起来好吃力。想念扫雷的左右键一起按 QwQ（这也不重要）
3. 这个游戏是没有任何提示的！比如哪怕高亮了一整行也不会告诉你这一行的 12 个雷你已经全标识出来了，或者悬浮到哪一格就把相关的一行高亮出来之类的，甚至玩家自己也不能做标记，全靠脑子记吧。（这也不重要）
4. 这就算了，最坑爹的是你点错了他就告诉你错了，等于允许了猜，但同时也让手滑党告别了完美通关！！！强迫症受不了啊 TAT 结合以上三条，倒数第二关的超大图我手滑了无数次了，最后气急败坏截图看着答案填，还是一直填错 TAT 对不起，这个成就我不要了 TAT
5. 另外，新增的无限关卡非常鸡肋，地图极大，但又远没有流程中设计好的图那么精巧，依然是通关就不怎么想继续玩了。

23233101.review:
[b]You might like if:[/b] You lost far too many hours playing Minesweeper back in the day - and want that all over again.

Not a bad game (but could be more fiendish). Imagine if Minesweeper met Nonograms and had hexagonal babies... then you're close.

Pure deductive logic. The solutions are unique and reasonably tricky, but fair. There's no trick questions or guessing. If you're used to Japanese deductive puzzles (like Kakuro or Ken Ken) then ignore the previous 2 iterations and jump straight to this one.

Unfortunately the 'infinite' puzzles are a bit inconsistent. Many lack much of a challenge, meaning you can kinda mindlessly click through them, akin to Minesweeper: relaxing but not overly taxing. Whether that's a bad thing ultimately depends on what you're looking for. If you want something quite gentle, this'll tick it perfectly. If not... how much are 36 puzzles worth to you?

If you want to up the ante and hit a [i]really[/i] fiendish puzzler; a game called 'Patterna' has surfaced on Greenlight (funnily enough, inspired by Hexcells!) - A demo is freely available, so I'd recommend giving it a peek:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=628954870

23199697.review:
Without a doubt the best puzzle game available on steam right now.

Hexcells Infinite is just that: infinite.

I did the math. It would take a player about 1,141 and half years (with a 6 minute per puzzle average) to exhaust every available puzzle, and that's assuming that they never eat, sleep, or take any breaks. If you were to buy just one installment of the Hexcells franchise, it would be a mistake not to get this one. It simply has the greatest value per dollar spent. (roughly 228 years of gameplay per dollar if you were wondering, and that's not even when it's on sale.)

Numbers aside, this game is an absolute masterpiece. From the minimal sound effects to the tranquil soundtrack, the sound design is spot on and keeps the player engaged. The gameplay is heavily influenced by japanese logic games and minesweeper, but it still manages to feel completely original and unique. More importantly, the concept is easy to learn and it only takes a few minutes for a new player to get used to the gameplay and environment. 

And that's not even the best part - the best part is that it NEVER feels impossible to solve. More often than not, when a player makes a mistake, they immediately realize what they did wrong. Even if you feel like you're stuck, there's always that one number you missed that tells you where to look. This game is like a great magician, in the sense that a great magician leaves nothing to chance despite how wildly impossible their act may seem. If you love puzzle games, Hexcells Infinite is a must for your Steam library.

I give this game a 9.8/10.

Not a perfect score for the following reasons:
- Highlighting an external grid number underneath another highlighted external grid number works OKAY, but I'm sure there are better options than white on white lines.
- You can make any number of mistakes on the infinite puzzles without facing any sort of penalty. Maybe I'm just being nitpicky at this point, but it just seems like a loose end in an otherwise flawless game. They could at least have it set up in a way where the puzzle doesn't count as completed if you make 3 or more mistakes.

Suggestions:
- Themes! I'm talking unlockable themes, different hex colors, player-created backgrounds, custom cursors, and so on. This game would certainly benefit from workshop access and, dare I say, skins. It'd be nice to have a change in scenery after playing with the same background and color scheme for hours.

23142383.review:
A fun and challenging logical puzzle game similar to MineSweeper.
Using the numbers to work out which tiles to mark.

The big difference between Hexcells and Minesweeper is that you never need to guess at any point, there's always a way to work out where to click.
Also, numbers can be shown on the outside of the grid and show a different symbol with the number to tell you how the tiles you need to mark are laid out.

Unlike Hexcells and Hexcells Plus, Hexcells Infinite has a random level generator in which will allow you to play new puzzles all the time.
It's also possible to make your own and share them with others or try theirs out.

If you wish to save a bit of money then I suggest only buying HexCells Infinite due to the fact you can play an 'infinite' amount of levels giving you many more hours of playtime.

23077759.review:
*This review will cover all three Hexcells games (Hexcells, Hexcells Plus & Hexcells Infinite) as they are very similar.*

Hexcells Infinite is a 2d puzzle game similar in nature to Minesweeper that involves hexagons. Using clues given by previously discovered tiles, more and more of the puzzle is shown and finally completed once all tiles are revealed. This series goes beyond your normal Minesweeper in the fact that clues will often involve more then the directly adjacent tiles  i.e. columns, diagonals, non-continuous, continuous only, double spaces, etc... If you get Infinite, it boasts an infinite puzzle generator that was some estimated 999,999,999 random puzzles to try so, good luck with that. All and all, a really great game if you enjoy the Minesweeper style but also want a bit of originality as well.

23042928.review:
Hexcells Infinite is the third and last game in series, with new 36 mind boggling levels which will keep you preoccupied for quite a while. No new mechanics are added compared to previous games, if you played them you know what to expect but that is not necessary in order to enjoy this one.

It is Minesweeper-like game where your goal is to decipher the pattern and mark the blue cells by gradually eliminating empty ones. They contain numbers which show how many blue cells are adjacent to them. New rules are introduced which add to game complexity, such as number of cells in columns, clusters of cells that must be separated from each other or adjacent to one another and blue cells with numbers which show how many of them are located in a 2 hex radius. I completed the game in slightly less than 8 hours. Much of it were spent in staring at the screen in order to find which cells to eliminate. Ending levels are really big and spotting sometimes obvious solution can be quite tricky.

The biggest change is introduction of an Infinite mode, you can play as many random generated levels as you want. Your brain cells will be happy, your free time surely will not.

23022171.review:
这是一款类扫雷+数独的游戏。玩法很简单，在所有的六边形格子里找出所有蓝色的格子，根据在六边形格子周围的数字提示，左键确认其为蓝色，右键确认其不是蓝色，直到找到所有蓝色的格子为止。
优点：
1、相比与传统的四边形扫雷模式，使用六边形作为格子的标示，增加了不同的提示方式。
2、以数学逻辑为主，鼓励玩家使用逻辑分析来进行游戏，游戏初出现的提示往往能一步步的推导到游戏结束，而不是传统的随机式扫雷。
3、随机生成的关卡，seed上限到999999，意味着可以玩999999关不带重的。
缺点：
1、游戏时长较长，除前期教学关卡外，一般一关在30-40分钟之间，后期及随机关卡的推导过程则更长。

infinite版基本把前两作的所有玩法都整合进去了，所以如果想体验的话单入这版就行，超级耐玩XD

23010644.review:
It seems from Hexcells to H. Plus to H. Infinite the games keep getting harder. I consider this a good thing, but I feel like this would be poor place in the series to start. That said, if you're willing to jump into harder puzzles right away, then this is probably the best in the series. It has a mode with infinite or more accurately "more puzzles than anybody has time to play", which allows you to keep playing new puzzles for as long as you want after the main puzzles are done. The downside is that the puzzles have differing difficulties and there's no way to say "generate a medium level puzzle".

As far as gameplay goes, there are no new mechanics from the other games in the series, but I consider that a good thing. The core gameplay was fun, so I'm glad that it wasn't changed. That said, some may feel that this game is essentially the same as the others but with things mixed up a bit. I think if I had bought this first, the other games would feel like more of the same since this offers the 'infinite mode', but since I played it last, I feel like it's a good way to end the series.

22618661.review:
I bought the game because it sounded interesting and I'm a lot more willing to buy games now that I can refund if I don't like it. I tried it out and thought it was great, played it for a little bit, then went to bed. The next day, I look at steam and am surprised to see it says "You have played 100 minutes"

I was genuinely stunned - those 100 minutes flew by so damn fast, I swear I thought I had only played for like 15-20 minutes.

If you like logic based puzzle games with clear rules, this is a must have.  Think minesweeper but set up such that you NEVER have to guess. You can always figure out the solution without guessing in any way, like sudoku. Sure, you CAN guess then just remember what the answer was, restart, and pretend like you figured it out with no mistakes, but the way you SHOULD play this game is to never ever click anything unless you are 100% certain you're right. It's much more entertaining and satisfying this way.

Additionally, it's all broken up into fairly small, bite-sized levels, so you can spend just 10 minutes playing while waiting for something and still get through a level or two. Of course you can also do what I did and spend almost two hours playing without even realizing time is passing by...

Get all three and Squarecells! Some of the best puzzle games I've ever played. Great for casual gamers and 'hardcore' gamers alike. Each puzzle is lovingly crafted and a really well done tutorial. I love this game, can't stop. The seeded runs aren't as well done as the actual levels, but no one can expect someone to make over 9 milion perfect levels. Perfect way to pass time.  Matthew Brown is an amazing puzzle game maker, and he has proved that he deserves my money for his games. No bugs, no real patchs, the biggest problem is that there isn't a big settings menu, but this type of game doesn't really need one. With the seeded levels, any arguments of lack of content are completely null. If you need to get more proof of how good it is, look up Nerdcubed's video on it. His video caused me to buy all three. I bought Squarecells when it came out and I can say it's great as well.

After you buy these games, you can thank me.

这是一个六边形的扫雷游戏，同时又有许多新的元素，可谓是在传承基本扫雷的游戏体验又不乏创新。
Infinite游戏版本中除了基本的6*6关之外还有另外99999999个seeds，输入代号即可进入这些额外关卡，这也就意味着这个游戏里有∞个关卡，大大增强了可玩性。
如果你不是一个有情怀的人，个人推荐hexcell这一系列的游戏就先买这一个（反正你这一辈子也玩不完(^^)/~~~）
额外的seeds基本上都是大地图，不算难，只要时间足够（平均10min）都能过，但是主体关卡非常难，（烧脑洞的时刻到了～
游戏的BGM总共6组，非常丰富，音效也和BGM契合的非常完美，推荐戴耳机玩游戏。
总的来说，这是一款非常优秀的益智小型游戏，老少皆宜，既可以玩seeds烧时间，也可以玩主线关卡烧脑洞。

PS.  游戏唯一的不足是鼠标按键机制，有点混乱，对新人不算友好。如果不及时适应，会经常因为误点错而出现不必要的错误，而因此丢失成就。

22220249.review:
[Play Time] : 27시간 (스팀 도전과제 100% 진행 기준)

[게임장르] : 퍼즐게임

[게임소개]
 : 육각형(헥셀)의 네모네모로직과 지뢰찾기를 맛깔나게 버무린 퓨전 형태의 퍼즐게임

[한줄 평]
 : 저렴한 가격에 장시간 즐길 수 있는 흡입력 강한 퍼즐게임


[게임평가]
 : 네모네모로직과 지뢰찾기를 맛깔나게 잘 버무린 퍼즐게임(Hexells Infinite) 입니다. 사실상 Hexells 의 3번째 작품으로써 전작들에 비해 많은 발전을 이루었다고 하나, 필자는 3번재 작품을 먼저 접하였기에 발전된 부분에 대해서는 언급하지 않도록 하겠습니다.

 본 작품은 비록 한국어화가 되어 있지 않지만 친절한 튜토리얼로 게임 Rule에 대해 자세히 설명하고 있기에 게임을 학습하고 진행하는데 큰 어려움이 없습니다. 그리고 게임을 플레이 하게 되면 게임 초반 육각형(헥셀)에 숫자가 표기되어 있고 그 주위에 파란 헥셀의 갯수를 나타내는 것이 꼭 단순한 지뢰찾기의 업그레이드 버전이라고 생각할 수 있으나 '{}', '-', 파란헥셀 안의 숫자 등을 통해 파란색 헥셀의 위치를 다양하게 표기하고 있기에 단순한 지뢰찾기의 업그레이드 버전이라고 보기에는 어려울듯 싶습니다.

  또한 상하좌우의 라인의 숫자 또한  '{}', '-' 옵션을 통해 파란색 헥셀이 위치를 다양하게 표현하고 있으므로 일반적인 네모네모로직에서도 좀 더 발전된 형태로 이 발전된 게임방식들이 잘 버무려져 흡입력 강한 헥셀이라는 퍼즐게임로 재탄생되었다는것은 필자의 조그마한 뻥(?)을 덧붙여 기존에 존재하는 것으로 부터 한단계 발전된 퍼즐로 퍼즐계의 한 획을 긋는 대단한 발견이 아닐까 싶습니다

 퍼즐이란 장르는 단순하지만 말로써는 평가하기 어려운 장르라 생각됩니다. 그러므로 즉, 백문이 불여일견 플레이어가 직접 본 작품을 경험을 해보는 것이야말로 글로써는 다 표현하지 못해 경험으로만 느낄 수 있는 그 감정을 더하여야만 정확한 판단이 가능할 것이라 생각되어지며, 필자의 부족한 필력으로 본 작품의 진정한 맛(?)과 즐거움이 많이 표현하지 못해 생기는 부분은 플레이어가 본 작품을 직접 즐겨가면서 필자가 제대로 표현하지 못한 아쉬움을 채워나갈 수 있을 것이라 단언합니다.

 게임의 튜토리얼이 자세하게 설명되어 있으나, 필자처럼 이해를 잘 못하는 사람이 있을 수도 있기에 게임에 대한 Rule과 게임의 편의성에 대해 설명하는 것으로 게임평가를 마치도록 하겠습니다.

[게임진행 방식] : 캠페인(Campaign), 생성기(Generator) 2가지 플레이 방식
 
1. Campaign : 총 6단계의 레벨로 분류되며 도전과제 획들을 위해서는 1개 이상의 Miss가 발생되어서는 안된다.
- 1~2단계 : 게임의 Rule 을 설명하는 튜토리얼 개념
- 3단계 : 지뢰찾기 방식의 플레이
- 4단계 : 네모네모로직 방식의 Rule 이 추가
- 1~4 단계는 헥셀과 상하좌우의 숫자 힌트를 통해 논리적인 방식으로 클리어 가능 (1 Miss 클리어 기준)
- 5단계 : 힌트없음(?)이 등장하며 논리적으로만 풀기는 어려우며 수학적인 통계학이 필요함
- 6단계 : 힌트없음(?)들로 인해 맵에서의 구간이 나뉘는 경향이 있어 어느정도의 운이 따라야만 함.
- 도전과제를 클리어 하기 위해서는 정상적인 방법 보다 반복적인 재시작을 통해 해당 맵을 외워 클리어 하는 경우가 대다수임

2. 생성기(generator) 
 -  생성기(랜덤 숫자)를 통해 퍼즐로 난이도는 캠페인 4단계 이하로 판단됨
 - 해당 게임에 익숙해 진다면 생성기를 통해 만들어지는 맵은 2~4분 내에 1 Miss 클리어 가능함

[게임 Rule]
 - 검은색 헥셀 내 숫자 : 해당 헥셀 주위(범위:1)에 있는 파란색 헥셀 갯수를 나타낸다
 - 파란색 헥셀 내 숫자 : 해당 헥셀 주위(범위:2)에 있는 파란색 헥셀 갯수를 나타낸다
 - {숫자} : 헥셀이 붙어 있는 것을 나타낸다 (ex. {2} : 파란색 헥셀이 2개 나란히 위치해 있음}
 - '-숫자-' : 헥셀이 붙어 있지 않고 떨어져 있음을 나타낸다. 
 - 숫자만 표기되어 있다면 붙어 있을 수도 있고 떨어져 있을 수 있으나 {}는 무조건 붙어 있고 -는 1개 이상은 헥셀이 무조건 떨어져 있다는 것을 나타낸다.
 - '?' : 힌트없음으로 해당 헥셀 주위에 몇 개의 파란색 헥셀이 존재하는지 모른다는 뜻이다.
 - 상하좌우에 있는 숫자 : 해당 라인(Line)에 존재하는 파란색 헥셀 갯수를 나타낸다.


[장점]
 - 파란색 헥셀 숫자 On/Off 기능 : 파란색 숫자를 클릭하면 엷은 검은색으로 표기된다 (우측 마우스)
 - 파란색 헥셀 범위 On/Off 기능 : 파란색 헥셀을 클릭하면 해당 헥셀 범위가 표시된다 (좌측 마우스)
 - 상하좌우 숫자 On/Off 기능 : 상하좌우 숫자를 클릭하면 엷은 검은색으로 표기된다 (우측 마우스)
 - 상하좌우 라인 On/Off 기능 : 해당 라인의 엷은 하얀색 줄이 표시되며 해당 라인의 가시성이 향상된다 (좌측 마우스)


[총평]
 : 퍼즐게임은 뇌를 건강하게 운동(단련)시키는 효과가 있어 치매를 예방하는 효과가 증명되어 있는 만큼 게임 불감증 또는 심신이 피폐해진다면 꼭 퍼즐 게임중에 본 작품(Hexcells Infinite)를 즐겨볼것을 권해본다.

22090111.review:
I can easily recommend this game if you like brain puzzles. The 36 main puzzles of the game are well made and very challenging, although some of the time you'll just be looking for that one piece of information you missed to progress forward. A lot of the puzzles are huge, and it takes some time to find that one tile you need to swap.

The second part of the game doesn't shine as bright, though; the infinite levels. You input or generate a random string of numbers, and a puzzle is made from that. When you've passed through the crafted levels, you'll likely find these generated levels simplistic and more of a timesink than an actual challenge. It's mostly repetition from what you've learned from the designer's levels, and while there may be some golden nuggets among these numbers, there's an 8-digit string to generate levels from, which is where the "infinite" part comes from. This of course doesn't mean they're bad, they're just not as good as the designed ones.

All in all, I can say that if you like brain training games that challenge your logical side, this one's worth it, and the infinite levels serve nicely as a filler for when you've got nothing better to do.

Think of minesweeper crossed with sudoku.
Hexcells Infinite is basically that with a few extra gimmicks added in.

When playing, I feel like I'm using sudoku logic, but in a binary way, where each square will be either blue or black.

Despite the simplicity of how it looks, this is actually a fairly challenging game.

Apparantly you never have to guess on any level, even if it is a procedurally generated one, but sometimes, I'll be looking at the puzzle for a while, oblivious to what I'm supposed to do next.

This is a fun game if you enjoy thinking things through logically and enjoy puzzles such as sudoku. I personally enjoy this more than sudoku.

As a bonus, completing a level will create a pattern, which is interesting to look at sometimes.

21778058.review:
A brilliant puzzle game! If you play it properly and not just by clicking random cells until you finish it, then it is superb.
In order to get the best out of this game (and in my opinion the only way to play it) you should challenge yourself to not make one single move if you are not 100% sure about it. As many have said before; the puzzles are supposed to be solved without having to guess or be in doubt whether the cells should be blue or not, so do not guess, do not think "hm, maybe this should be blue", "this is probably right" or anything along these lines. If you are not completely sure, then do not click. 

Improvements have been made since the last two games. One is that you can save your puzzles and then go back later and finish them (which is what I recommend you to do if you get stuck. Take a break, go do something else and then come back later and you will see new per,c  that you did not see before. It is so easy to get stuck focusing too narrowly on one area or staring blindly on a spot that might already be solved). The other thing is that a random puzzle generator has been added. Although the random puzzles are easy and does not require much effort and thinking they are still addictive! It is very relaxing to solve them and great if you just want to wind down a little bit. 

If you are already a fan of minesweeper or sudoku, then you will LOVE this game. Hexcells is the perfect mix between those two. 

In conclusion; I cannot recommend this game enough! I loved the first two ones, Hexcells and Hexcells Plus, and now with this one having a random puzzle generator just makes it the ultimate puzzle game.

21680922.review:
If you're on the fence about the series or played one of the earlier games and aren't sure if you want to pick up the new one let me sum it up for you: This is the one you want to buy.

Hexcells Infinite, to me at least, is a big improvement on an already fun series. For those not in the know, Hexcells is a puzzle game that's similar to mine sweeper only with 6 sides instead of 4 and an error counts against you but doesn't end the game. Also you never have to guess in Hexcells, there is always sufficient evidence given to correctly select the next move (though you may find yourself pulling out your hair until you find it). 

This game has the same clean graphics and soothing atmospheric music as the previous 2 games but does have some improvements. The biggest of which is you now have the ability to save and come back to a puzzle. This is a huge improvement and especially helpful as some of the levels in the base game are larger and more complicated than levels in previous games. You can also now set which mouse buttons you want to use to mark a square as blue or not which is a bonus to us lefties.  

Where Hexcells Infinite really shines though is in the Infinite part. In addition to a set of given puzzles you can there's also an infinite mode where a set of 8 numbers (selected randomly, shared with friends or based on the date) will bring you a specific puzzle for you enjoyment. These puzzles tend to be shorter than the 'main' puzzles and are a great way to pass the time or give yourself a quick mental warm up for the day. And yes, you can save you progress on these too!

21679232.review: This game makes me feel autistic and I love it.

Once you've done all of the puzzles present in the game, you can either do randomly generated puzzles (fun for a bit, but, eh, not the most important bit here) and, fantastically, custom levels! Would for sure reccommend buying pack for all the games as they all have different, intersting puzzles.

21546194.review:
In a nutshell: Hexcells Infinite is Minesweeper on steroids. 

Long story: Just like in Minesweeper, sometimes you’ll have to guess (which may or may not annoy you), but unlike Minesweeper, Hexcells allows you to make as many mistakes as necessary in order to complete a map, and THAT is my major beef with the game, because it detracted a lot from the challenge. That’s right: There is no *significant* reward for completing a map with zero mistakes, and there is no punishment for literally guessing every step of the way and finishing with 20+ mistakes (other than barring your progress through the blocks of preset levels, but unlocking all puzzle groups doesn't really pose much of a challenge, i.e. you can do that even if you finish each map with a few mistakes). 

On the bright side, extra points go to sound design, as every correct click results in a soothing, oddly satisfying sound bit; however, there is no volume control in the game, only an ON/OFF switch, which I suppose is aligned with the game’s minimalistic design, but it’s a feature I missed nonetheless. 

All in all, the game is reasonably priced, and certainly a step up the challenge of playing Minesweeper. If you’re looking for some casual distraction of the “minesweeping” variety, I’d say go for it.

As a perfectionist, I find short, challenging games to be the best fit for me.
Hexcells Infinite takes the hexagonal challenge to a new level. I found myself spending anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour on some challenges, without getting bored or wanting to give up.

The challenges here are never unfair, but give you great satisfaction when you finally figure out what you were doing wrong. The main focus here is you, your mind, and your way of thinking, helping you evolve your thought processes and think more outside the box as you progress.

This game also comes with "Infinite Mode" which generates an unlimited amount of puzzles once you are done with the "campaign" levels. Once you finish those levels, the Infinite Mode puzzles are quite simple, and I find that I am challenging myself to finish the levels as quickly as possible with no mistakes, like Minesweeper.

Till now, I'm still enjoying this game and open it up every so often to pass some time.

21370805.review:
Hexcells Infinite, like the other hexcell games, still follows the same gameplay. Basically a mix of minesweeper and sudoku. The game has nice background music like the others and this particular game has an added feature where you can play custom puzzles. 

However, where this game fails for me is it’s made the same mistake as hexcells plus. While the original hexcells had a nice difficulty curve, this one's all over the place. I actually enjoyed playing the first hour and I thought they'd redeemed themselves from hexcells plus. I was getting stuck, but still progressing which makes the game fun. But the levels difficulties are all over the place. For example one level introduced a new concept and gave you an incredibly easy puzzle to make sure you understand it. Then just the level after it throws you into this massive puzzle with numbers all over the place and I'm just sitting there thinking, I can't be bothered with this. It becomes more of a grind and loses its fun. I think it would have been nice for the dev to add a mid-level save so you can come back later; some of these levels are massive and will take a long time.

I'm also very disappointed that they added a ? cell. It's so cheap because it forces you to solve the puzzle in only one possible way. It can also be so disheartening; you might spend a solid 5 minutes to find a cell you can make progress on only to uncover it as a ? so you can no longer progress any further down that route.

However, do I think this game is worth buying? Yes! Solely because you can play custom levels. It offers more than the other hexcells games. So, although there are some things wrong with this game I can still say it's worth buying.

3部全成就，应该有资格评测了。总体结论就是：如果你喜欢扫雷的话，那么这款游戏千万别错过。

+之前也玩过六角扫雷的游戏，但六边形周围区块只有6块、相邻公用区块只有2，相间公用区块甚至只有1，比正方形（8、4、3）要少得多，基本上都挺枯燥。此款六角扫雷创造性地设计了连续/不连续、空缺块、每列雷数、二圈雷数等关联条件，趣味性大大增强；

21166429.review:
For the uninitiated, Hexcells Infinite is a game where you improve your logic and extend your patience as you purge through cells of impurities by discovering where the “mines” are with the help of numbers. In short, this is the minesweeper of the new generation.

Hexcells Infinite provides enjoyment for both newcomers and veterans alike. Newcomers can enjoy the slow romp of increasing difficulty that teaches you the mechanics of the game. With veterans, they can immediately jump right into the tougher puzzles via Infinite Mode, which gives you difficult random generated puzzles, without concerning themselves with finishing the easier ones (that the newcomers are meant to finish).

Having Hexcells Infinite invalidates the existence of the 2 previous Hexcells games. The previous 2 titles end up only existing as a way of gifting to your friends and supporting the developers. This is absolutely fine because Hexcells Infinite is the next step in its evolution as a game sequel. Everything you need and more is in this definitive sequel.

Ultimately, this is game that is an expertly made for the expert to be. It has evolved in the right direction and should be played & kept by many for generations to come.

The last and best in the Hexcells series (so far, in case it's going to be continued) provides the same kind of gameplay as Hexcells Plus did, but gives you now 3 crucial features:

- Steam cloud lets you continue your progress where you left off on another computer or after formatting
- Continue puzzles in progress (instead of having to go at it again from the beginning)
- Puzzle Generator: after "beating" the preset levels you can now play levels generated from one of 1 000 000 000 seeds

Although there are no new mechanics introduced and I think the proximity mechanic (which at least for me takes a decent amount of time for counting and double-checking) is overused, this is a solid game with the Puzzle Generator giving it a lot of replayability if you just cannot get enough of the basic puzzle principle. I recommend picking it up in a bundle along with the other 2 in a sale.

20635161.review:
Having played through the previous two entries, I was delighted to find that most of the tutorial levels--in addition to swiftly establishing mechanics that I had already learned from the previous entries--included at least one pattern requiring a multi-step inference that I didn't recognize from previous puzzles. After three games, I could not only understand this odd language Matthew Brown has invented, but I could appreciate the subtle cleverness of the puzzle construction and recognize the discovery of a new turn of phrase. That he has managed to create this connection upon a foundation of clicking hexagons is a testament to his mastery of this subject.

The addition of an automatic puzzle generator is perhaps the most compelling evidence that this format has been exhausted by the creator. While the puzzles are good in a perfunctory way, I'm happy to wait for more hand-crafted levels from the next game, whatever that may be.

Best puzzle game of the Hexcell series!

The third version of this game, following Hexcells and Hexcells plus.
Again the basic puzzles are a bit harder than with plus and a LOT harder compared to the first Hexcells.
Where plus gave us additional new rules for the puzzles, this sequel doesn't do that. It only perfects the difficulty of what the previous parts had to offer.
But why the name "infinity"? It comes with a Random Puzzle Generator, offering no less than 100.000.000 puzzles. This is where the true replay value shines. Want to share a certain puzzle with a friend? Just give the puzzle grid number to him and he can load it no problem. You can even save a puzzle midway, Something that is lacking in the standard puzzles.
All in all a very valuable addition to an already great game. 

As with the previous two parts, ALL puzzles can be solved by using simple (and sometimes not so simple) logic. You never have to guess to solve something there's always a "if this needs this, then that must be so or so". Highly recommended if you enjoyed the previous parts. If you found 'plus' too hard, the random puzzles are a bit less difficult sitting somewhere between the original and plus.

20461841.review:
A logic puzzle that is like a combination of Minesweeper and Kakuro. Simple design & graphics, fitting music. You have numbered tiles that tell how many adjacent mines there are. And later on there are numbers outside the grid that tell how many mines are in that column and numbers inside mine tiles that tell how many mines are within a two tile radius. You use the information given to get through tiles and eventually uncover the whole area. There are no game overs (so you can continue on despite guessing or making mistakes) but you can do the puzzles without guesswork.

The controls are pretty simple (left click to mark as a mine, right click to reveal). You can also right click on column numbers/mine numbers to hide them. It's not very obvious but you can access the menu/restart the stage by clicking on the word MENU on the top left corner.

I enjoy logic puzzles and these kept me entertained for a several hours (I spent a good amount of time just thinking about the problems and eventually got hints from people on the forums).

The Infinite version finally allows for saves so you can safely take a break during puzzles (which I often did to reset my mind and try again later).

It also introduces randomly generated levels (based on seeds) so you can keep playing after you finish the campaign. However, from my limited experience, the randomly generated levels are usually not as satisfying as the dev-selected campagin levels. The generated levels don't usually require thinking about more than one layer of information at a time and have a good amount of simple cascades. I didn't really think about or appreciate the developers' puzzle design skills until I started playing the generated puzzles.

The most polished and, in my opinion, the best of the three Hexcell games. The difficulty curve isn't as steep as Plus (they offer more levels that help show needed concepts) but I'm not sure if Infinite is a little easier than Plus or if Plus' puzzles conditioned me and helped me solve these faster.

If you like logic puzzles like Sudoku/Kakuro you should try the original Hexcells first. If you enjoyed Hexcells and are looking for a new and harder challenge, this will probably be your cup of tea.

20460137.review:
If you don't like this game then you're stupid.  I mean that in a literal sense -- your IQ must not be high enough to understand it.

Years ago there used to be this board game "Mastermind".  It was hard as hell, you had to deduce the colors that  your opponent had chosen and was hiding behind a tiny screen.  To make it more difficult, you could have blanks.  You had a limited number of guesses to deduce what the colors were.

Flash forward 20 years to the game "Minesweeper" included with Windows '95.  In that game, as many of us remember, you had to figure out which of the hidden squares on a grid held a mine and which did not.  You were told, given an empty square, how many mines bordered that square.

Hexcells Infinite is a wonderful combination of both.  It requires focus, patience, and some abstract reasoning abiliity.  Some evenings, after a long day at work (or working two jobs), I actually find it pretty relaxing to be able to focus my thoughts on something else.  My mind never shuts down, it is always thinking about something.  Other thank alcohol or other illicit drugs, this game is one of the great ways to derail my thinking from all of the stresses in my life.

I've played about 15 hours so far and have not solved the game.  This is because you need to achieve a certain level of perfection on each level.  For every error you make, you earn fewer points. You need a certain number of points in order to "open" a different, more complex level.  You will definitely finding yourself approaching levels over and over trying to achieve perfection.  But it doesn't feel like grinding, not one bit.

The numbers that you reveal can be coded in different ways.  One way means that there are that many mines bordering that hex.  Another means that there are that number of mines bordering the hex, but they are in sequence (for example, -2-).  Another means that there are that number of minuntes bordering the hex, but they are not next to each other (for example, [3]).  There are several other different notations and on many levels the game gives you just enough (JUST enough) information to deduce the layout of the hexes.

Thoroughly enjoyable.  There is also a daily randomly generated hexcell grid that you can generate, but even without this the replay value will be medium to high if you give yourself enough time to forget the layout of the grids.

A wonderful little game, high recommended.

Note: This review is for both Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite, because they're basically a single game divided in three parts.

The Hexcell games are a series of brilliant crafted puzzles that at first glance may seem like a six-sided minesweeper, but the logic used to solve them is closer to sudoku. As you progress through the levels, you are also introduced to some new mechanics accompained by a tutorial level to make sure that you understand them. Because the puzzles are carefully and wonderfully designed, you never have to guess your next move, but finding it gets hard in the later puzzles. The interface is clean and the sound effects are cool. Hexcells is easy, Hexcells Plus gets harder in the second half and Hexcells Infinite steps back a little at the beginning, but in the end offers the most challenging puzzles. It also comes with a seed-based puzzle generator, adding 999,999,999 additional puzzles (even if they aren't hand crafted, they're still good). My recommendation is that you get and play all three games in order, but if you can only pick one, pick Hexcells Infinite, it's main levels difficulty is nicely spread not to mention the puzzle generator.

It's easy to understand, its art style and design is very fluent, and I find it very satisfying when I get the smooth responses after I click on a hexagon and the little orange particles fall down to reveal the black underneath or the blue fades in from the centre. 20137365.review:
Heads up: this is the final game in the Hexcells series. If you haven't played any of the previous games, I highly recommend buying the original Hexcells before buying Hexcells infinite. While this game can be played without the previous two games, it's much harder to comprehend the scenarios and best moves without the original game as a guide/starter.

If you've played the previous two games, Hexcells Infinite amps up the difficulty. As a personal analogy, I didn't have much trouble with the first game until somewhere around World 6. On the second game, I started running into trouble about halfway through World 4/beginning of World 5. In Hexcells Infinite, I'm running into blocks around late World 3/early World 4.

The random puzzle generator works as intended; all puzzles that came up for me were all unique solutions. On average, the puzzles seemed reminiscent of Hexcells Plus in their difficulty; I think the main levels in Hexcells Infinite were, on average, harder than the randomly-generated puzzles.

Hexcells Infinite delivers on it's promise and is a satisfying last game of the series. I highly recommend this game and its predecessors to anybody who likes puzzle games.

20066418.review:
Logic puzzle game, similar to minesweeper but without the need to guess any moves and latest entry into the Hexcells series.

[b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] adds several improvements to the series the biggest of which is the puzzle generator giving you access to 1 billion generated puzzles alongside the usual 36 main puzzles. Difficulty wise I found it overall a easier then Plus but there were a few puzzles in it that were on par with the harder ones in [b]Plus[/b].

Again like the other entries into the series every puzzle is fully solvable buy logic alone and again it is forgiving with no punishment for guessing or making mistakes.

The one main negative from the previous games was not mid puzzle saves, which thankfully are in Hexcells Infinite allowing you to leave and return to puzzles without having to start over.

One thing I did notice is that the generated puzzles lack a certain polish and feel that the hand-made puzzles had, they do lack a certain air of quality in comparison.

[b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] is worth its price for puzzle fans, it has any easier curve then [b]Plus[/b] so it would be a good entry to new comers if they only wanted to get one of the games, it is the best one.

[b]The complete collection[/b] itself is easily worth its price aswell, providing 102 hand-crafted puzzles over the 3 games and 1 billion generated puzzles from Infinite itself. 

I had no technical issues with Hexcells Infinite.

Possibly one of the best puzzle games of all time. The hand crafted puzzles offer are a challenge and will no doubt make you think logically. If you just want to finish the game, then it might not take you that long, but I personally believe that the game is meant to be played like a perfectionist. It is far more fun and rewarding to attempt to finish every puzzle without making a single mistake. That will take you a few hours, if not more. 

After finishing all of the puzzles, you can then move onto the infinite mode, where there are enough puzzles to last you a lifetime. As one might expect, the puzzles are in no way superior to the hand crafted ones, but they still offer a fantastic challenge and will challenge you in similar ways to the HexCell puzzles you are used to. If you are a fan of puzzles in any form you can possibly think of, there is no doubt in my mind that HexCells Infinite would be a great game to add to your collection.

19787680.review:
[h1][b]Game Series[/b][/h1]

Hexcells Infinite is the third game of its' series. Previous game: Hexcells and Hexcells Plus.

[h1][b]Game Visual/Audio[/b][/h1]

There isn't much can be said about the game's visuals asides from that they're minimalistic. Pretty much the same thing can be said about the game's audio. 

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]

There is no difficulty mode option that's assigned. But each of the puzzles has their own difficult.

Hexcells Infinite basically has same formula as its' predecessors Hexcells and Hexcells Infinite. So the objective remains the same. Which is to figure out which cells to make blue and which cells to make black.

There are total of three slots with six worlds that has thirty-six puzzles to solve. The first world for each of the three slots are automatically unlocked. Completing one world will unlocked the next one. All of these puzzles can be replayed after the first go around. Please do note that the puzzles in the other two slots are the same as the ones in the first slot.

There is a special feature bonus that Hexcell Infinite has. Right beneath the three slots, there's an option for continous gameplay of Hexcells. Henced why the game called Hexcell Infinite. The special feature bonus gameplay can be customized in many different ways that the regular gameplay of Hexcells cannot.

There's no time limit in this game. Allowing the individual take as much time that they want to solve each of the puzzles.

There seven achievements for this game. Each of these achievements has certain requirements before they can be unlocked.

[h1][b]Miscellaneous[/b][/h1]

Final thoughts, it's an neat game to play and enjoy. As for the game's replay value it's low. I would recommend this game but not at the full price.

19695831.review:
Genau wie im Vorgänger geht es darum ein Feld bestehend aus Hexfeldern aufzudecken. Ähnlich dem Minesweeperprinzip gibt es Information wieviele "Minen" es im Umfeld zu finden gilt. Erweitert wird dies allerdings durch verschiedene Spezialfelder. So gibt es nummerische Felder, welche die Information über zwei Reihen und nicht nur im direkten Umfeld des Feldes tragen, Felder die eine Verkettung von Minen im Umfeld vorraussetzen bzw. eben genau dies nicht und Angaben am Rande des Feldes, die angeben wieviele Minen horizontal, vertikal oder diagonal von dieser Zahl über das Feld ausgehen. Zudem sind diese Zahlen oft mit Verkettungen bzw. Splittungen kombiniert. 

Ein kniffliges und spannendes Spiel, dass jedem der schonmal Minesweeper oder Sudoku gespielt hat jede Menge Spaß machen wird. 

Das schöne an Hexcells Infinite (im Bezug auf die Vorgänger) ist die Tatsachen, dass der Entwickler einen Randommodus eingebaut hat, der nach Abschluss der Hauptkampagne noch für stundenlangen Spielspaß sorgt.

Im Sale oder nicht: eine klare Kaufempfehlung für alle Tüftler, Rätselfreunde und alle die die mal ihr Hirn richtig zum Rauchen bringen wollen!

19377424.review: Another great addition to the hexcells line! The acceleration of difficulty in the puzzles is not quite as steep as in Hexcells Plus, so you could start with Hexcells Infinite without first playing Hexcells. (I recommended practicing with Hexcells before diving into Hexcells Plus.) This edition comes with a really neat feature to generate puzzles randomly (hence the "infinite"), which provides endless hours of puzzle-solving fun! My only complaint is that the randomly generated puzzles seem to be relatively easy, for the most part, due to a lot of duplicated/unnecessary information provided. I don't know what sort of algorithm the authors use to generate the puzzles, but if the algorithm is flexible enough, it would be nice if the amount of information provided could be customized so that players could choose their difficulty level. Otherwise, Hexcells Infinite is a great puzzler that I'm sure I will be enjoying for a long time to come.

19281189.review:
The first and most obvious comparison of Hexcells is to Minesweeper, with two extra sides, and that's what you're going to get. Minesweeper is great for killing a few moments, from the basic versions in Windows 2000 and XP to the shiny new ones in 7 and 10. Start menu, "mines", press Enter, and away you go. Even when the hardest difficulty defeats me time and time again, I still find myself looking for it over Solitaire or Hearts.

So why does the "ambient logic" of Hexcells annoy me so much? Well, if you've picked up on how pretentious that quoted phrase sounds, you're riding the same wave of boredom that I am.

To put it plain, this game feels more like a tumor growing on Minesweeper than any real advancement. It's slow, it's overcomplicated, and it's not really about puzzles. It's about processes of elimination, like Sudoku, and with the pressure to complete every stage without error, you will feel discontent when you have to guess what's behind that next orange tile.

Don't kid yourself on this point: if you're looking for any shred of entertainment you'll have to guess. Life is too short to work out every combination and deduce if you're about to fuck up the tantalizing "Mistakes: 0" in the corner when there's regularly 50+ tiles and 10+ column hints to combine. Math majors aside, I don't know who could find that fun.

But enough of taking potshots at my humorless peers, let's take potshots at the developer instead. This game really is dead-set on monopolizing your time and attention. Minesweeper is a game to be played for a few minutes, preferably with the ability to quickly background it when something more important pops up (e.g., your boss rounds the corner). You're better off playing it on mute anyway; the audio is annoying and the interface is minimalist to a fault. Quick, exit to the stage select screen without touching the mouse (you can't) and without waiting for the pause menu to fully scroll into view (good luck). On OS X, this game disables every normal exit strategy to simply access another window - Cmd+Tab and Mission Control - and for what reason? Both Microsoft and Apple go to great lengths to disallow this behavior because even with the best of intentions, no application is so important as to block access to everything else. Yes, you can exit with Cmd+Q, yes, you can play it in a window by guessing at keyboard shortcuts, but disabling the ability to use my system as I see fit while it is running is really what made me cross over from indifference into irritation. And with gameplay this shallow, that's the strongest emotion this game musters up.

19249058.review:
If you liked the first two games, then this game is an easy buy!

Unlike the past two games, this one is most assuredly going to stump you (especially if you're going for Perfectionist - no mistakes in the campaign) and frustrate you. This one will definitely challenge you, and they definitely did their best to deliver a truly deserving finale.

As an addition, there are an 'infinite' number of additional games (past the handcrafted campaign ones, these seem a bit computer-generated, even using a seed). These puzzles are easier - you dont need to worry about making mistakes since those aren't being counted and just click away - but in a way, I can appreciate the option of having a load of extra puzzles to enjoy after having gone through the entirety of the game.

This one will last you longer than the other two combined, either because of the increased difficulty or the increased number of puzzles to go through. All in all, a good way to end the series.

18782106.review:
Hexcells Infinite é a sequencia de Hexcells e Hexcells Plus. O jogo é bem semelhante a Campo Minado, mas é muito mais complicado e com muitos outros elementos, basicamente apenas a regra principal é semelhante.

Existem 3 elementos no jogo:
Os numeros, dos quais você se baseia para saber o que estará embaixo dos Hexagons.
Os Hexagonos, dos quais você tem que descobrir quais são os pretos e os azuis para finalizar o level.
Os botões Direito e Esquerod do mouse, dos quais você usa para revelar os Hexagons Azuis e Hexagons Pretos.

OS NUMEROS:
Os numeros indicam quantos Hexagons Azuis tem naquela area especifica, existem diversos tipos de Numeros no jogo, vou explicar cada um deles:
-Numero no Hexagon Preto: Significa que aquela quantidade de Hexagons Azuis estão ao redor do Hexagon Preto.
-Numero no Hexagon Azul: Significa que aquela quantidade de Hexagons Azuis estão ao redor do Hexagon Azul.
-Numero fora dos Hexagons: Significa que aquela quantidade de Hexagons Azuis estão naquela linha direta.
Existem tambem 3 versões de Numeros:
-Numero Limpo: Signfica a quantidade Hexagons Azuis em qualquer lugar daquele local.
-Numero entre Colchetes: Significa que aquela quantidade de Hexagons Azuis estão todos unidos.
-Numero entre Hifem: Significa que aquela quantidade ed Hecagons Azuls NÃO estão todos unidos.

OS HEXAGONS:
Existem 3 tipos de Hexagons, seu objetivo é encontrar todos os Hexagons Azuis e todos os Hexagons Pretos.
-hexagons Laranjas: São os Hexagons incognitas, dos quais não sabemos o que tem embaixo deles.
-Hexagons Azuis: São os Hexagons que precisamos encontrar, são como a Bomba do Campo Minado.
-Hexagons Pretos: Todos os Hexagons que não são Azuis, usamos eles como dica para saber aonde estão os Azuis.

CLIQUE DIRETO E ESQUERDO:
Temos duas formas de revelar quais Hexagons estão embaixo do Hexagon Laranja, usando o clique do botão Direito e o do Esquerdo.
-Botão Direito: Quando clicamos com o botão direito, queremos dizer que embaio do Hexagon Laranja tem um Hexagon Preto. Se lá realmente estiver um Hexagon Preto, você o libera e continua o jogo, se lá estiver um Hexagon Azul, você erra e o jogo continua.
-Botão Esquerdo: Quando clicamos com o botão direito, queremos dizer que embaixo do Hexagon Laranja tem um Hexagon Azul. Se lá realmente estiver um Hexagon Azul, você o libera e continua o jogo, se lá estiver um Hexagon Preto, você erra e o jogo continua.

RESUMINDO: Hexcells é um Campo Minado muito mais complicado e com muito mais elementos.

18725295.review:
Hexcells Infinite. A simple, cheap casual puzzle game that I adore. There is one specific reason I adore this game, and that is also why I have Over 400 hours in this; It is incredibly fun to play while doing other things on the computer.

If something requires any less that 100% of your attention, as long as you're used to how the game works (by beating the previous two games and this one), the infinite mode is a nice little infinite amount of puzzles to just idly complete while you're doing other things.

+Cheap
+Simple
+Calming
+Small disk size wise
+Good for use while doing other things
-Comes as three games
-Infinitely generate puzzles are rarely as interesting as the handcrafted levels

18722227.review:
一打开游戏发现左下角的左右键功能切换就乐了，看来开发者也意识到这个用户习惯上的问题了。
[u]多设了一个按键的逻辑，估计一下最多也就加三行代码，改几个参数，却造福了全人类。[/u]
三部曲走过来，体验上的进步很明显。
不仅仅是关卡给人的趣味感，还有点击音效的多样化，不同的大关给人的体验是截然不同的。

当然，最重要一点，难到离谱。
能设计出如此虐心的关卡的设计者，我除了佩服之外找不到另外一种合适的态度了。
明明整个谜题的图案看起来很有规律，但偏偏就能难爆你。
这些问号是怎么想到放在这些地方虐人的？
[strike]果然这类游戏的进步总是伴随着抖S度的上升吗？[/strike]

[h1]接下来重点说说无限模式。[/h1]

无限模式的设计让我很感兴趣，[u]Seed就这么几位数字，是怎么做到通过每一个Seed来演算出关卡的？[/u]
如果每一关都是预置的，数据量如此庞大，我觉得不是人类做得到的。
[u]令我感到惊讶的是，每一个关卡的逻辑性都很完美，没有任何游戏上的困难。[/u]
这让我对开发者佩服到五体投地。
[h1]不仅随便输入一个Seed都能进入一个完整的、独有的关卡，而且一个个都丫的这么难！[/h1]
黑科技啊这是！
有机会的话真希望和开发者聊聊这部分的逻辑是怎么实现的。

[u]开发者真是一声不响地往这个游戏里加进了这么厉害的东西啊，[/u]
但是关于这个模式的成就居然只有一个（完成60次）。
我认为这个应该是重点应该让玩家着眼到的对象，
毕竟这游戏的副标题就是Infinite，把这个模式当做最主要的部分完全是没问题的。
然而仅仅一个60局成就，甚至连正确率要求都没有，
没有办法让玩家的关注点放在这个模式上，估计也就是草草刷完60盘就删游戏了吧。
这很可惜。
我认为这个模式的表现不应该只是这样。若有续作，期待这个模式有更好的地位。





[strike]然而说了这么多，我玩了几个小时都还没能把无限模式的成就拿到。[/strike]

[strike]11.9：终于全成就，庆祝一下。[/strike]

18298274.review:
The best, most brain-busting game in the hexcell "trilogy"... at least for the main, "campaign" puzzles. If you're looking for is many hours spent staring at yellow, grey, and blue hexagons, wondering for five straight minutes where the next move is, then this is made for you, but if you're hoping for perpetual puzzling potential, then move along.

Be aware that the problem with the infinite mode is my only complaint. This is still a great game, but since the infinite mode is such a big part of the game that it's in the title, it has to be addressed.

The campaigns through all three games have a good number of memorable puzzles, some of which employ excellent variations in implimenting of the game's hint mechanics, but no such thing can be found in the infinite mode. Infinite puzzles are all bland, unmemorable blobs, and they offer no surprises in how they combine various hints. After playing about 15 infinite puzzles, you can be fairly confident that you have seen everything infinite can offer you in terms of challenge--even if it can challenge you at all. If you've managed to complete the entire campaign honestly, working to understand complex chains of hints, then most infinite puzzles should be trivial to complete.

A trivial puzzle is not a fun puzzle.

So, yes. If you love puzzles, buy this game, but don't expect to be playing it for months and remain entertained.

18267548.review:
My thoughts on [b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] are essentailly the same as my thoughts on the original game and [b]Hexcells Plus[/b], so read [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/AroNocebo/recommended/265890/]my review for [b]Hexcells[/b][/url] to understand my stance on the gameplay and style. 

[b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] is more or less a standalone expansion pack for the original [b]Hexcells[/b], but definitely more difficult and challenging. There are a few new obstacles and hints in the puzzles that have been introduced since the original game too, which can make problem solving a little more thought-prevoking. [b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] brings an "Infinite mode" to the table, which is basically a random puzzle generator. This is a really nice addition that gives this game endless replayability, so you'll always have a reason to go back to this version if you're in the mood for it.

If you enjoyed your time with [b]Hexcells[/b] and [b]Hexcells Plus[/b], you will definitely enjoy your time with this too. There isn't much else to say here, this is definitely another one to pick up for puzzle fans of all ages.

18183652.review:
普通のマインスイーパと違って、各ステージが人間の手で設計されており、攻略には道筋が存在するようになってます。
そのため運に頼ることなく、ステージ内の手がかりだけでクリアが可能でやりがいがあります。
次のステージへ進むたび、マス（Heｘ）の示すヒントの種類も増えて、ゲームの奥行きが豊かになります。
悩んだ末の1マス（Hex）が突破口となって、次々と開けていく時などは、その優れたステージデザインに感心します。
プレイ中は製作者に挑戦しているような、導かれるような、不思議な気分です。

ミスをしても爆発してサヨウナラということもなく、そのまま続けられるので、ノーミス実績を狙わないのであれば簡単です。
また音楽とSEも穏やかで心地よいです。でも良すぎてときどき眠たくなります。

おまけとして、8桁の数字の組み合わせ（シード）から1億通りのステージを生成して遊べます。
さすがに製作者の作為がない分、通常ステージをクリアした後では難易度的にも物足りないと思います。
コミュニティの掲示板でシードの紹介もされているので、探してみるのもいいかもしれません。

一つ欠点を上げると、各通常ステージの展開は一本道というところ。
ノーミス実績狙いの場合、一つ誤クリックでもすればやり直しですが、その際は失敗箇所まで同じものをなぞり直す作業になります。

総体、手軽に起動して熱中もできる、良いゲームでした。
3作全てやっても、まだ遊び足りないといった心持ちです。

18028158.review:
La série des Hexcells reprend à peu de choses près le jeu du démineur, mais l'agrémente de plusieurs éléments un peu plus complexes notamment empruntés au jeu du picross. Cette critique est d'ailleurs valable pour les trois opus : Hexcells, Hexcells Plus et Hexcells Infinite.

Tout comme pour le démineur, il y a donc deux types de cases : les cases bleues qui font office de "bombes" et les cases numérotées qui indiquent le nombre de cases bleues adjacentes. Sur ce seul principe, il y a déjà de quoi faire, d'autant que chaque niveau possède une géométrie différente. Pour les niveaux plus avancés, on nous donnera également des informations sur le nombre de cases bleues sur certaines colonnes ou diagonales, ou encore des indices sur leur disposition.

L'épisode Plus propose une ou deux nouvelles notions, comme les cases bleues indiquant le nombre des autres cases bleues dans un certain périmètre ; et si l'épisode Infinite ne propose pas de nouvelles mécaniques, il propose enfin un mode permettant de générer des niveaux aléatoirement.

Bref, une série bien sympathique pour les fans du démineur et du picross, avec un joli design graphique et sonore ; mais conseillée à petit prix, étant donné la très faible durée de vie de l'ensemble (si l'on exclue la génération aléatoire).

Is Minesweeper a big thing for you? Do you enjoy cracking puzzles using logic? Do you want an endless amount minesweeper inspired logic puzzles that require 0% guessing and 100% pure thought to solve? Well Hexcells Infinite is just the game for you.

Aesthetically the game is very minimalistic, clear and clean. The ambient music and the soothing ethereal piano keys played, when you unravel successive hexes, can be quite relaxing. 

The game has a finite amount of hand-crafted puzzles with a decent enough difficulty curve. The earlier levels are pretty easy to grasp and as more elements and guidelines are introduced the puzzles get increasingly harder. The last of the hand-crafted puzzles can be seriously challenging to beat using just your logic and not guessing without making any mistakes. But like I've said each and every one of these can be beaten without guesswork, just need to look at it in the right angle.

After you've completed the hand-crafted there's the infinite puzzle generator. While I've noticed that the levels you get using the generator are usually a lot easier than the last of the manually created levels, so there's not that much challenge there anymore for me, but I still occasionally find myself popping back in to complete a few of them. It's refreshing to warm up your brain's logical thinking with them I suppose.

All in all I have to recommend this title to any puzzle fans and especially to those who love minesweeper (because it's pretty much minesweeper but better). Great value for the price. Even more so if you can get it with a discount.

17792686.review:
[b]What is Hexcells Infinite?[/b]
Hexcells Infinite is the successor to both Hexcells and Hexcells Plus, puzzle games that look rather like Minesweeper. Players are presented with an orange grid comprised to hexagons and it is up to them to determine whether these cells belong to the blue pattern or not (black cells). The black cells not part of the pattern have a number in them to indicate how many blue cells are adjacent to them, thus providing a clue as to how to proceed.
After completing a puzzle the player is awarded blue hexcells based on the amount of mistakes made; these in time accumulate to unlock one of five new areas - allowing you to complete more difficult puzzles. Some areas also introduce new clues and rules to help you, making the puzzles more complex over time.
The biggest addition to this game is the infinite mode, where puzzles are randomly generated so there is always a new puzzle to try out.

Although similar to Minesweeper as mentioned, there is a key difference: there is always a logical next step. You never have to take a gamble so if you feel stuck, take a step back and focus on another area.

[b]Why I recommend the game[/b]
Hexcells Infinite is a very simple puzzle game in its visual design. The menu is simple and provides the players with the option of turning the ambient music on or off, selecting which mouse button turns the cells blue or black and selecting one of three save slots. The same can be said for the puzzles themselves; a grid of hexagons on a white backdrop. To me this is good design, as I'm here for the puzzles and that's where the focus clearly lies.
The puzzles themselves are interesting, more difficult than Hexcells but slightly less difficult than Hexcells Plus.
What's more, my biggest problem with both previous titles has been resolved; it is now possible to leave a puzzle mid-game, thereby saving your progress and being able to continue next time where you left it.

However, like previous titles it is still not possible to erase a save slot so starting completely from scratch is not an option if all three slots are in use.
Furthermore, I personally find the infinite mode wanting. The randomly generated puzzles are neither as difficult nor as interesting compared to those made by Matthew Brown, the developer of Hexcells.

That being said, I recommend this title (and both previous ones) wholeheartedly for anyone interested in puzzle games.
