17686809.review:
The second addition to the original Hexcells game.

[h1][u][b]Addendum[/b][/u][/h1]
If you love Hexcells that much, that you can't stop playing it, then I have a solution for you and you are sitting right in front of it: Hexcells Infinite. Not only does this game add new puzzles for you to solve, it also adds a random generator for you to enter a random seed and get solving! Too much time on your hand? Don't worry, there are many, and I mean MANY, puzzles waiting to be solved by pure logic and process of elimination. Happy Solving for infinity and beyond!

Here is my original Review for "Hexcells".

[quote=Enix]A compelling puzzlegame, as an obvious big brother of Minesweeper.

Content
Many puzzles await your solving. Go through different levels of difficulty and solve all of the puzzles to get to 100%. Can you get every one with no mistakes?

Hexcells (apparent from the name) adds new dimensions to the classical game of Minesweeper: More adjacent fields to one hexagon as well as border numbers, which indicate how many fields of the pattern are in a line/row/diagonale. Each boder number can indicate different things, everything is explained within the game. No need to rush things. You are now thinking outside of hexcells.

Sound & Music
Shallow but fitting background soundtracks and sounds. Nothing special, but that wasn't needed here. The soundtrack and soundeffects change every once and a while when you complete a puzzle.

Graphics
Don't expect anything here. The game is primarily a puzzle game, so no high end graphics or effects. The design does its deeds and fulfills its task. Visuals are never irritating and do what they need to do.

Weakpoints
Sometimes, portions of the soundtrack are a little too high-pitched in my opinion. This can get annoying, if you are not used to hearing the same sounds over and over again. They are adjustable ingame though, from soundeffects only to completely mute.

Concluding Thoughts
Great puzzlegame, compelling, challenging, tricky but fair. Nice soundtrack, nice sounds, simple gameplay yet sometimes mindwreckingly hard. Don't worry, if you are the enthusiastic puzzle type of gamer, you will get used to loving this game![/quote]

17316999.review:
Having now spent 30 hours on this game I think the time has come for me to finally write a review for this masterpiece. It truly is a complete masterpiece and I don't think anyone could come up with a better long lasting puzzle idea if they tried. Wheras I find most puzzle games loose there charm after a while of just doing very similar puzzles over and over again I find that hexcells has enough variation to keep it intriguing and fun to play for hours on end!

So hexcells infinite is a follow up to the originals, hexcells and hexcells hexcells plus. They are pretty much identical games with a few differences. I will cover all of the games in this review because I think if your going to play them you should start from the beginning and play all of them. The original hexcells is a very easy concept version of the two later games. I say concept because this is what it felt like at this stage. Its as if he was just testing the water as to whether people enjoyed it. It was very simple and when replaying it, it only took me around 1 hour to complete. But then you go on to hexcells plus. This is a very large step up in difficulty and really does get you thinking. Infinite follows on with this step up in difficulty following around the same level of difficulty. 

Well what do you do in hexcells? It's basically an upgraded version of minesweeper. Having the field instead in a hex format makes for much more extensive gameplay. They have extra functions in around the hexes instead of just numbers. You have {} which say that the hexes are connecting each other. - - show that they aren't connecting each other. You have large orbits (Not sure what to call them so that name will do?) which show how many hexes are in a large area. And finally there are numbers above some rows that show how many hexes are in that row. So all of these new elements really make you have to think and utilize all of them together to complete a level without making mistakes.

This newest entry series introduces a new feature called inifnite mode. It is a randomly generated field of hexes that is unique every time. There is said to be 999,999,999 different combinations so good luck getting through them all. I have currently done about 150 puzzles. This is where the real longevity of the game comes from. Although infinite mode isn't quite as challenging as the story puzzles it does make it so you don't have to keep playing the default puzzles over and over. I have found myself playing hours on end on this mode. 

There is one thing that makes this truly better than minesweeper. No guessing. Yes you heard that correct. There is no guessing at all in hexcells. The maps and algorithms are specially crafting so you never find yourself uncertain to whether there is hex there or not. This makes the gameplay infinitely more fun and makes it so it doesn't get aggrivating after a while. 

So if you are a fan of minesweeper or any puzzle game at that hexcells is definitely for you. You can currently buy the hexcells complete pack for a price of £5.99 which is an absolute steal for the amount of time of gameplay you can get out of it. It is an ideal game to spend 10 minutes or so on now and then whenever you have a moment. 

Really this isn't the kind of game I expected I would lose my life to but i'm glad I found it!

16755402.review:
Hexcells Infinite does it again, marking yet another great entry in the Hexcells series. Just like its predecessors, it features fantastic Minesweeper-like mechanics that are supplemented with different methods of revealing information about the solutions to its well-designed puzzles. It also features that same ambient-style soundtrack that leaves players both relaxed and focused. One small but appreciated addition is the ability to quickly restart puzzles and save progress on the current puzzle. It's especially great for taking a break from those bigger puzzles.

The difficulty here, save for a puzzle or two, felt slightly easier than Hexcells Plus. I'm not sure if this is actually due to the hours of practice I've put into the first two games, but regardless I'd recommend at least playing through the original Hexcells before taking on Infinite.

My reviews of the previous games contained complaints about having a limited replay value and, even as well-crafted as the game's pre-designed puzzles are, this is still an issue. But now the game tries to counter that with its Infinite mode, creating randomly generated puzzles to provide an infinite amount of content.

The only problem with this is that many of the puzzles generated are nowhere near as satisfying to play as the ones included with the game. Few of them approach the challenge and cleverness of these pre-arranged puzzles. Playing the randomly-generated puzzles makes one appreciate the care the designer took to make the pre-built puzzles enjoyable. In spite of this, it's hard to complain: Infinite mode is just icing on the cake and is something that will likely make me keep this game installed for quite a while even though I've mastered all the built-in levels.

The bottom-line is that Hexcells is a brilliant game series and Infinite is, while not the most challenging entry, the best entry yet. It's easy to recommend for anyone who enjoys logic-based puzzles.

Hexcells Infinite adds what the first two games most needed; a level generator. Hexcells and Hexcells Plus each had 36 AMAZING hand-built puzzles of ever-increasing difficulty, but once you completed the puzzles with no more than 1 mistake each, that was it. The game went back on the shelf.

Hexcells Infinite also has 36 well-crafted hand-built puzzles, but once those are done you can keep playing with randomly-generated levels. If you buy only one of the trilogy, get this one.

To the developer(s): There are a couple things I'd still like to see improved.

1 - The randomly generated levels vary widely in difficulty and in how long they take to solve. I like to play Hexcells during a 15-minute break at work, and I'd like to be sure I can solve a puzzle in that time. So I'd like to see some size and difficulty settings when generating levels. It would also be nice to be able to disable some of the mechanics, like line clues and blue cell clues, when generating levels.

2 - Just a small UI annoyance. When you go to the Infinite screen to start a random level, it always has 000000 as its seed. You have to click "use a random seed" and then "start". I almost always want to use a random seed, so just pre-populate it with one and save me a step.

3 - Eventually I'd like to see player-built levels (and even worlds/series of levels) be an option. Random maps are great, but I bet some of your players could come up with really awesome, brain-wrenchingly difficult, beautiful puzzles. Steam has tools (Community Workshop) that make sharing user-created content easy. If this has to be done in a 4th title, then I'll be happily buying another Hexcells game when it's finished.

16630279.review:
Hexcells Infinite is easily my favorite logic puzzle game at the moment. I strongly recommend it to both casual and hardcore puzzle fans. While I've never played the two previous games, I've also never played a puzzle game that so elegantly turns simplicity into difficulty without any sort of contrived pressures such as time limits or fail states. You'll go from feeling like Aristotle to agonized trying to faultlessly solve later levels.

Some describe it like Minesweeper, but I have no attachment to minesweeper. I never even understood it until a friend explained it to me in my 2nd year of college. You just deduce (and in my experience, with enough thought you'll never need to guess and check) where blue and gray hexes are in a field of uncovered, yellow ones. It's simple, but grows fairly deep as new mechanics are added.

Between the 36 handmade levels and the practically infinite levels, Hexcells Infinite packs more than enough content for me to recommend it at a full price. While it begins easy and ends quite hard, there's no fail state, so you can play as carelessly or cautiously as you wish. It also has some of the best puzzle mechanics for such a simple foundation such that it doesn't need to necessarily increase the number hexes to increase the difficulty of a level. The designers deserve a lot of praise, as the later levels are able to both hide and provide information, cleverly entwining hints and further complexity into one hex. It's casual, for sure, as it doesn't pressure you. I like this, because some of the levels truly frustrate me. If anything, it actively tries to sooth you with its clean and calm ambiance.

16265971.review:
Hexcells is a logic game that plays like a crazy version of Minesweeper. The core levels have been specifically designed so that there are no 'guesses' required and that if you figure out the logic correctly, all moves are 100% certainties. 

I love logic games and figured I was quite good at them - but this one humbled me. Lots of times I got stumped and it was a relief when you cracked the next move. Embarrassingly I had to resort to youtube a couple times to see how other people figured out the logic chain. This version of Hexcells (this is the third I believe), also has a random puzzle generator (hence the 'Infinite' part of the name) which is also fun, but not specifically designed.

Basically a great game for anyone who loves figuring out logic puzzles. One small improvement that I personally would have liked was a hint on where to start a given level. Some levels, especially the later ones, have so many cells that it takes so long just to figure out where to start. That's not very fun to me, but who knows, the game has proven I am a simpleton.

16240829.review:
[h1]Really cool puzzle game [/h1]
think of minesweeper, but with enough mechanics to actually be called a puzzle. Sure you will pick up reflexes playing, you will recognize patterns, but you will always have to think.
This third game in the series brings few new mechanics to the table, but it seems like the game designer has finally seen the full potential of the game. Know you don't only think with what is on the table anymore, you think with what is not there. You have to make deductions and subtractive thinking, instead of simple pattern recognition. You won't anymore end up in situations where you feel you outsmarted the dev by solving the puzzle by not needing half the elements in the game. Real thinking inside.

[b]Pros[/b]:
[list]
[*] Hexcells is finally really challenging.
[*] News ways to think with the same mechanics
[*] Actual "how do I move on from here?" situations
[*] Really slick interface
[*] Extremely satisfactory "oh I got it" moments
[*] Ambiance/music variation through the game makes the game sound tolerable even for a long time
[*] Level generator
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]:
[list]
[*] The "mistakes" counter makes the game feel like a chore sometimes: one missclick and you have to redo the same grid with 150 mines. Level 6-5 sucks.
[*] Last puzzle was extremely underwhelming compared to the last game
[*] The last levels are not cleverer, just bigger
[*] The level generator does not create challenging levels - at all
[/list]

16239048.review:
Was für ein großartiges Spiel!

Genau wie im Vorgänger geht es darum ein Feld bestehend aus Hexfeldern aufzudecken. Ähnlich dem Minesweeperprinzip gibt es Information wieviele "Minen" es im Umfeld zu finden gilt. Erweitert wird dies allerdings durch verschiedene Spezialfelder. So gibt es nummerische Felder, welche die Information über zwei Reihen und nicht nur im direkten Umfeld des Feldes tragen, Felder die eine Verkettung von Minen im Umfeld vorraussetzen bzw. eben genau dies nicht und Angaben am Rande des Feldes, die angeben wieviele Minen horizontal, vertikal oder diagonal von dieser Zahl über das Feld ausgehen. Zudem sind diese Zahlen oft mit Verkettungen bzw. Splittungen kombiniert. 

Ein kniffliges und spannendes Spiel, dass jedem der schonmal Minesweeper oder Sudoku gespielt hat jede Menge Spaß machen wird. 

Das schöne an Hexcells Infinite (im Bezug auf die Vorgänger) ist die Tatsachen, dass der Entwickler einen Randommodus eingebaut hat, der nach Abschluss der Hauptkampagne noch für stundenlangen Spielspaß sorgt.

Im Sale oder nicht: eine klare Kaufempfehlung für alle Tüftler, Rätselfreunde und alle die die mal ihr Hirn richtig zum Rauchen bringen wollen!

16164536.review:
Sequel to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890/]Hexcells[/url] and [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900/]Hexcells Plus[/url], Hexcells Infinite is more of the same in a similar package and with fairly similar ambient musical theme and abstract graphics. This is in no way a bad thing.

Like in the originals, the game mechanics are simple but interesting: you have to find out whether all the hexes within the puzzle are blue or black with rules similar to Mine Sweeper and Hanjies. Baseline is that you can always deduce everything: no guessing is required. Though guessing is not punished either. Nevertheless, you need a near-perfect streak to acquire most achievements.

The mechanics have not changed at all after the originals: black hexes contain a number that states how many hexes around it are blue, and blue ones might contain a number stating how many hexes in a two-hex radius are blue. In addition there are Hanjie-like column-numbers that state how many blue hexes are there in a given line.

All 36 puzzles are new, so the owners of the original ones will be pleased. The difficulty curve is a bit steeper than in the original Hexcells but little less than in Hexcells Plus. In effect, it is great as a stand-alone title requiring no knowledge of the two games from before. For me it took 8 hours to complete all 36 hand-crafted puzzles.

Thankfully, saving within a puzzle has finally been provided! I have to wonder why it wasn't featured in the originals. The other new, much-sought after feature are the random-generated puzzles that add a ridiculous amount of replayability: you provide a random number seed and the level is generated, there being supposedly 2 billion levels. Unfortunately, I found the random levels frankly uninspiring and underwhelming in difficulty when compared to the original puzzles. Curiously, the way the random seed is provided introduces a social feature: you can post the coolest random levels (i.e. their seeds) to public forums for others to try. With so many random levels, there are bound to be some gems in the flock discovered only by trying.

With Hexcells Infinite, I'd wager this kind of puzzle game has pretty much been perfected as a concept. I would certainly welcome there being more of these cleverly crafted and well-designed puzzles. The graphics are as perfect as they can be for an abstract game and the ambient music fits the abstract theme splendidly.

If you already played and enjoyed [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890/]Hexcells[/url] and [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900/]Hexcells Plus[/url], this game is a must-buy. Otherwise I'd really recommend either [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890/]Hexcells[/url] or Hexcells Infinite for their balanced difficulty curves.

15656074.review:
Hexcells Inifinite est un mini-jeu de réflexion, du même type qu'un Démineur : la principale différence tient du fait que le joueur n'a pas affaire à des carrés (4-voisins), mais à des hexagones (6-voisins).

2 touches sont disponibles : un clic et l'on colore une case (mine), l'autre clic et l'on découvre la case, c'est-à-dire le nombre de cases piégées voisines. Simplissime.

Au gré des niveaux, quelques variations apparaissent : indications sur le nombre de cases piégées le long d'une ligne entière ou dans une zone de 2 cases de rayon, et leur contiguïté (ou leur discontinuité). Ces variations apportent de nouvelles stratégies de grilles... qui peuvent commencer à demander un bon coup d'oeil. Point très positif : AUCUNE grille ne nécessite de faire des "coups au pif" pour avancer. Elles sont toutes très faisables.

Contrairement aux 2 jeux précédents (Hexcells - sorte d'introduction, et Hexcells Plus - sorte d'extension), Hexcells Infinite, en plus de proposer une nouvelle campagne composée de grilles de plus en plus compliquées, propose un générateur aléatoire. Le jeu devient donc rejouable à l'infini (enfin).

Les grilles générées aléatoirement restent cependant beaucoup plus simples que les grilles de la campagne, mais conservent leur faisabilité sans coup hasardeux.

Enfin, un mot sur la réalisation des Hexcells : elle est épurée et excellente, tant au niveau des sons d'ambiance discrets qu'au niveau des graphismes.

15572925.review:
It's an amazingly fun game to pick up and play for hours, but the same issue that plagued the first game still exists in this one.  There are too many 'trial and error' puzzles.  A good example of this very early on would be in level 1-4.  In this, the game teaches the player how a {#} hex works in that the active hexes are consecutive.  The only problem with this is that in the very middle there's a lone {2} hex with 4 blanks on either side and an active hex on the top.  There is no possible way to figure ou from that puzzle, which side the blue hex is supposed to go.  It could go on the left, or it could go on the right.  There's no indication at all on where the active hex is supposed to be.

Like I said before, this game is amazing fun, but there are a lot of these trial and error puzzles that are just impossible to figure out because the puzzle itself doesn't give the player the information they would need to solve it without either chancing it, or cheating.

15547332.review:
Not surprisingly, more of the same, but that's a good thing. Still a bunch of clever puzzles based around a hybrid of minesweeper, picross, and similar ideas,. The benefit of them being hand-crafted is that they can pull some neat tricks and have a pretty good difficulty curve, and you both know that there's some sadistic jerk out there responsible for it when you get stuck on one and then get to feel smart when you beat HIM instead of the computer.

What's new is the "Infinite" mode, which randomly generates new puzzles. They're still satisfying to play, but they do show off why the previous two games and the other half of this one have human-made puzzles. The machine-generated ones don't have nearly the intricacy or intentionality that a person can come up with, so even though they do add to the game, they're not quite the same. It is interesting seeing the differences though, and they have their own kind of flavor, but they're generally somewhat easier and a bit...weirder. Still enough fun that I got all the achievements though, but the highlight is the main mode, and if you want more of those puzzles, the previous two games have those (although if you can beat this one, the first game will be very easy, and you really should've started there first).

Edit: I have continued to do randomly-generated puzzles for the two years since originally writing this. Send help.

15190838.review:
This is the third game in a series of addictive puzzlers (Hexcells, Hexcells Plus, Hexcells Infinite), and I would not recommend starting here -- go back and play through the others as the difficulty here is tuned assuming you've already taken the training wheels off. 

The overall idea is not that complex; like Minesweeper and Picross, you use partial information to slowly reveal whether a tile is "on" or "off" until you are done.  You never need to guess; the information is always there.  The magic here is in the ways the information is presented (at varying times you will learn how many tiles are on in a given column, row, or diagonal, how many tiles adjactent to a tile are on, how many tiles in a region are on, and whether the tiles that are on are contiguous or not).  Early in the game there is enough information to happily click through and solve the puzzles; late in the game, every bit of information has you trying to figure out how it can combine with existing information to yield one more "yes" or "no."

The end result is incredibly satisfying, a well-earned "perfect" score.

It also has replay value with a random level generator, but the real magic of the game is in the hand-crafted puzzles that force you to collate all the available information until the next logical action pops out.

It's a thing of beauty, and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys logic puzzles.

I went out and bought all 3 versions (Hexcells, Hexcells: Plus, and Hexcells Infinite) and boy am I glad I did. This game is nothing but fun. The best version of Hexcells by far.

The simplest way to describe it is a mix between minesweeper and picross; and it adds even more puzzle elements.  Any fan of those games will certainly appreciate Hexcells.

Infinite keeps all of the mechanics from Plus and adds a random generator so you can essentially never run out of hexcells puzzles to play. 14933938.review:
Жемчужина серии! 
Снова шестиугольники, чудесная смесь "сапёра", японских кроссвордов и ещё одного элемента, указывающего количество синих ячеек в определённом радиусе. Со всем этим вас плавно и кратко познакомят, и игра стремительно наберёт сложность. 
Снова чудесный интерактивный саундтрек, которого по сути нет, лишь приятная фоновая полумузыка и чудесные звуки при отмечании и вскрытии ячеек, формирующую что-то вроде мелодии и гармонично дополняющие процесс игры. Впрочем, то или другое (или всё сразу) можно отключить, если вдруг будет мешать.
Снова красивое лаконичное окружение, если и изменившееся со времени прошлых частей, то в лучшую и более удобную сторону, поскольку я этого вообще не ощутила.
Всё вместе по-прежнему создаёт то странное и чудесное ощущение, будто мозг одновременно и работает в полную силу, и расслабленно отдыхает. Это непревзойдённо!

Разработчики взяли две предыдущих отличных игры и улучшили их, при этом почти не изменив, а лишь добавив несколько небольших удобств. Например, добавили меню паузы, из которого можно сразу перезапустить уровень, и подсказку, будет сохранён прогресс при выходе или нет (как мне этого не хватало в предыдущих частях!), возможность сменить кнопки мыши (если вы играли в предыдущие части, вряд ли это захочется сделать), возможность включить границу для синих ячеек с цифрами (как включила, так и не выключаю). Ну и, конечно, то, что дало имя игре - генератор уровней.
В генераторе уровней можно задать "зерно", и будет создан определённого вида уровень. И всего этих уровней целых 100000000 (сто миллионов!). Тут уж если и пройдёшь какой-то два раза, всё равно не заметишь. Можно задать случайное число, использовать текущую дату, а можно и самостоятельно задать номер.
Уровни в генераторе нельзя назвать сложными. Да, есть полегче и посложнее, но в основном это можно назвать средним уровнем. Для меня - самое то! Особенно с учётом того, что можно ошибаться сколько хочешь - и никто не отнимет у тебя возможность получить ачивку :)
Для тех же, кто любит головоломки посложнее, есть уже привычный режим с созданными разработчиками уровнями. Вот они, особенно под конец, действительно мозгодробительны. И хотя, как говорят, для каждого хода там есть своё обоснование, по-моему, нужно быть просто гением логики, чтобы найти этот верный ход. И если хочешь получить ачивку "Перфекционист", ошибаться больше одного раза нельзя. Лично я в таких безвыходных ситуациях просто угадывала, запоминала расположение, начинала снова, ошибалась, начинала опять - и так до победного конца. Достижение я-таки получила, но теперь с большим облегчением обхожу этот раздел стороной. Хотя это было действительно интересно, тут не поспоришь.

Недостатки в игре? Ну, те, что у меня есть, больше похожи на придирки.
Например, одна из фоновых полумелодий, из новых, чертовски похожа на звук моего внешнего кулера в его худшие дни и заставляет меня некоторое время напряжённо прислушиваться :D Или то, что разработчики явно не ожидали, что кто-то воспримет их слова "60 down 999,999,940 to go!" ("60 сделано, впереди 999'999'940!") буквально и начнёт проходить все уровни один за другим, так что не сделали ни начала уровня по нажатию Enter, ни кнопки "следующий уровень" в режиме генератора.
Но, правда, это ведь сущие пустяки!

Головоломка шикарна, и если вы любите занять чем-то подобным своё время, попробовать надо обязательно. И лучше взять весь пак из трёх игр и пройти их последовательно. В данном случае шестиугольников много не бывает :)

14914766.review:
Spielzeit: ~18 Std (mit 100% Achievements)
Rätselschwierigkeit: Mittel - Sehr schwer
Wiederspielwert: sehr hoch (dank täglicher wechselnder Rätsel)
Negativ: Wie bei den Vorgängern auch wiederholen sich die Teile
Wünschenswert: selbst bestimmbare Schwierigkeitsgrade und Größen der Daylie-Rätsel

Der mit Abstand schwerste der 3 Teile! Zudem enthält er als einziger einen Daylie / Randomgenerator-Modus, um auch nach dem Durchspielen der Level freude daran zu haben. Für Anfänger des Spiels würde ich trotz kurzer Erklärung abraten und erst den ersten Teil zum besseren Verständnis durchspielen.

Es ist ein tolles logikspiel! Das Prinzip ist ähnlich wie Minesweeper, aber die zusätzlichen Elemente verhindern, dass man gezwungen wird an manchen stellen zu raten. Zudem ist das Spiel nicht gleich vorbei, wenn man mal falsch lag -> Es gibt am Ende lediglich evt. Punktabzug dafür. (ab 2 Fehler)

Es gibt unterschiedliche Elemente:
- Alle blauen Flächen liegen 100% aneinander gereiht; 
- Es ist zu 100% eine Lücke in der blauen Reihe; 
- In der Reihe sind X blaue Flächen;
- In einem markierten Bereich befinden sich x blaue Flächen. 

Ich finde, dass die zusätzlichen Elemente des Spiels es leichter machen, als Minesweeper (für die, die es vergleichen wollen), es jedoch auch umfangreicher und damit spaßiger ist als Zeitvertreib.
Die neuen Elemente sorgen allerdings auch für mehr Denksport (wenn man das so sagen kann)

Für Achievementjäger sei gesagt, dass hier nur einer der Teile relevant ist und man hierbei Fehler machen kann (!) sofern man am Ende alle Punkte für das Level bekommt. Plus 60 Daylie / Random-Level.

Mir fehlt der 3. Teil und 40 Daylie / Random-Level noch. Die Level sind teilweise SO schwer, dass man echt verzweifelt, wenn man sich kurz vor Ende verdrückt und damit nicht mehr volle Punktzahl bekommt. Es ist außerdem wirlich eine Herausforderung hier den nächsten logischen Schritt zu finden in manchen Leveln. (besonders bei 6.5)

14896804.review:
[h1]Bullet points[/h1]
[list]
  [*] "Minesweeper on steroids"
  [*] All puzzles solvable with pure logic (no guessing)
  [*] Infinite replay value due to procedurally-generated levels
[/list]
[h1]Full review[/h1]

[i]This review is for the third game in the Hexcells trilogy: "Hexcells Infinite".  The gameplay across the series is essentially the same (which is why the Curator links for the first two games also point here), but I'll cover the important differences between the three titles.  In the interest of full disclosure, the "infinite replay value" bullet point above only applies if you have "Hexcells Infinite".[/i]

Let's just get the elephant in the room out of the way first; the parallels with Minesweeper are obvious.  That said, calling this a "Minesweeper clone" is like calling a Lamborghini a "Honda Civic clone" because they're both cars.  Even so, taking a Honda Civic around the block will still give you a decent idea of whether you like driving cars or not, so it's a starting point.

The Hexcells games will most appeal to people who like Minesweeper, but thought the game mechanics got a little bland and are irritated by the fact that some blind guesswork is almost always necessary on the harder boards.  Here, you've got a wide variety of "cell types", but arguably more importantly: no guesswork ever.

That's not to say Hexcells isn't tough; the first game may lull you into a false sense of security, I'll admit, but by the time you're solving the latter puzzles of "Plus" or "Infinite" you'll realize that this is a [url=http://www.gamesradar.com/why-dark-souls-friendliest-most-benevolent-game-its-generation/]Dark Souls[/url] of cell-logic puzzling.  I lost count of how many times I got stuck for minutes at a time, just staring at the screen looking for the next clue, finally seeing it, getting excited at the prospect of homesteading another swath of the game board...only to find that the logic train derailed after a single cell or two.  But it's not just that it's hard, it's that -- it's hard to describe without playing the game, but it's a common theme in people's comments -- you can [i]tell[/i] that the author did it on purpose.  He [i]knew[/i] you were going to be at that exact spot, thinking that exact thing, and he [i]deliberately[/i] pulled the rug out.  It's just something about the way the puzzles go: there's a devilish humor in some of the dead ends.

The first game ("[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890]Hexcells[/url]") definitely has the easiest of the "designed" levels, and introduces most of the game mechanics.  It's a solid game on its own, and I would certainly recommend starting with it, but if you're only going to buy one of the three, skip it (but don't...buy [url=http://store.steampowered.com/sub/50074]the bundle[/url]).

The second game ("[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900]Hexcells Plus[/url]") features much harder "designed" levels (although they do start out pretty easy as well), and again I would certainly recommend playing it in sequence as part of the trilogy...but if you're only going to buy one, skip it (but don't...buy [url=http://store.steampowered.com/sub/50074]the bundle[/url]).

The third game ("[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/304410]Hexcells Infinite[/url]") has "designed" levels on par, difficulty-wise, with "Plus".  If you're only going to buy one of the three, this is the no-brainer choice because in addition to the manually-designed levels, "Infinite" also has a randomized level generator (the pedants in the audience will point out that it's really just a set of 10,000,000 procedurally-generated levels, but...yeah).  It's also the only one of the three to support user-created levels (the support is clearly a bolt-on in all its kludgy glory, but bless its heart it does work and kudos to the developer who went back in and added it in an update at the community's request).

The generated levels aren't nearly as hard as the lovingly-crafted "main campaign" levels, but they're difficult enough to give you a bit of a think and personally I like the fact that I can chew through them a few minutes at a time with a lot of action-packed, exciting clicks and right-clicks.  I've even encountered a few that had "gotchas" that almost looked deliberate.

As a last parting shot, just in case there are any of you out there who are thinking "I liked Minesweeper's gameplay perfectly fine thank you very much...but yes, the forced guesswork [i]was[/i] annoying", check out [url=http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/puzzles/js/mines.html]Simon Tatham's "mines" implementation[/url].  In my opinion it's not nearly as much fun as Hexcells (sorry Simon!) but it does scratch that specific itch.

[h1]If you like this game, check out...[/h1]
[list]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/78000]Bejeweled 3[/url]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/207570]English Country Tune[/url]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/32150]Everyday Genius: SquareLogic[/url]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/272040]KAMI[/url]
  [*] [url=http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/puzzles]Simon Tatham's Portable Puzzle Collection[/url]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/321480]Sigils of Elohim[/url]
  [*] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/286380]Strata[/url]
[/list]

14880517.review:
マインスイーパーとイラストロジックを組み合わせたパズルゲーの第3弾です。
難易度は無印、Plusに比べるとさらにアップしており、Plusをようやく解いてきた私の心をポキリと折ってくれます。
かなり数字ヒントも少なめになっており、初見では本当に全部理詰めで解けるのか疑った位です。

無印、Plusで培った理詰め理論でほぼ対応できますが、1つの面だけどうしてもわからなくて、一度解いて開けられる
場所を覚える(2-3か所)＆紙と鉛筆による場合分けというチート(?)を行ってようやく解決しました。
すべての面を頭の中で理詰め処理できた方はかなりすごいと思います。

Plusもそうでしたが眠い時の長考にはマウスから手を離すことをお勧めします。でないと考えている最中にウトウトしてマスを
開いてミスが付きます。

無限面生成モードがついているのですが、パターンが似ていてInfiniteを解いて来た人には物足りないです。
難易度的には無印の最初～中盤くらいのレベルでしょうか。Infinite解いた方ならほぼ止まらずにマスを開けていけます。
また、生成面のランキングも見つけられなかったので、タイムアタックを他の人と競うのにも少しハードルがあります。

続編がでるのか不明ですが、次のバージョンだとどんなに恐ろしい理詰めがでてくるのかと期待して待ちたいと思います。
このバージョンから買う方もいると思いますが、是非無印とPlusで力つけてきた方が無難です。

扫雷,作为windows系统中必不可少的游戏而广为人知晓,其简单而富有挑战的玩法深受男女老少的欢迎.我第一次接触它是在初中的电脑课上,从此它就为我无聊的课程带来无限的乐趣.但是玩过扫雷的都知道它有一个很致命的缺陷,就是经常会出现不确定的雷点,此时只能靠运气,就像在拆弹，红线or蓝线，选错就boom,这使我对扫雷又爱又恨.直到我发现了Hexcells这个游戏,它能够完美的解决这个问题,这里的每一部都是经过作者精心的布置环环相扣,绝对不会出现这样的不明确事件,而且从扫雷的四边形升级成六边形,再加上对角线.连续数.不连续数和范围数等不同的地雷数显示方式大大增加了可玩度和难度,如果喜欢扫雷的话那一定会更加喜欢这个游戏!

PS:我是打折买的大包.包括了原版.plus和infinite.3部都有固定的36关.但infinite多了随机生成的关卡.不过随机的比较简单.如果真心喜欢扫雷的话建议入大包,普通爱好者建议只入无限.总体难度个人感觉是原版最简单.plus和indinite差不多.按键的初始设定和扫雷相反,如果不习惯的话可以在进游戏前设置一下.

14764175.review: This is the third and definitive entry into the Hexcells series. This game remedies the primary problem with the first two games in that it has a random level generator. Now, unlike the first two games, you have a good degree of replayability when you've finished the main progression. 14758314.review:
This is a very fun puzzle game, a cross between Minesweeper and Picross/Nonograms. It has great relaxing music and visuals, and the puzzles themselves are designed to be fun and relaxing.

That first paragraph is the one I copy/pasted between all of my Hexcells reviews. Hexcells Infinite continues the trend the others set, but is FAR more polished with more features.

Firstly, along with the standard 36, there's a new puzzle generator using 'seeds'. Seeds is just a random string of numbers used to generate something, in this case a puzzle. You can choose for the Puzzle Generator to either randomly generate a seed for you(and therefore a random/new puzzle), or use the current days date, making it a sort of daily challenge. Either way, you can share the seed with friends and compete to see who does better.

Secondly, there's far more sounds and music tracks to listen to while you play, all of which are wonderful and relaxing.

And lastly, theres some customization options now. For those who have played the other two Hexcells, you know of the mechanic/clue thats a blue cell with a number in it that tells you how many blue cells are in the area, and that you can left click it to make it highlight its 2 cell radius. In Infinite, there's an option to make that highlight flash, or to make it not flash and have a black border. Either way improves visibility in the way you like it. Next is that you can switch which mouse button does what, so instead Left Click for Blue Tiles and Right Click for Black Tiles, you can reverse that so it's Left Click Black, Right Click Blue.

Anyway, if you like Hexcells and Hexcells Plus, then Infinite is a absolutely must have. If you haven't played any, and can only afford one of the Hexcells games, then I recommend this one, as it has the Standard 36 Puzzles, Puzzle Generator, More Music/Sound, better Customization, and just generally better overall. And for those who don't know, each Hexcells has little text tutorials that does wonders for teaching and isn't invasive/hand-holding.

Each new Hexcells DID introduce new mechanics, and while Infinite does explain it properly, I'd say get the Hexcells Complete Pack since it's such a great Puzzle game. But again, if you can only get one of them, get Infinite, I definitely recommend to any Minesweeper/Picross/Nonogram/Puzzle fan.

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ satisfying gameplay
+ really nice UI & menu
+ relaxing soundtrack
+ more chalenging than original Hexcells
+ infinite level generator in Infinite mode

[b]CONS:[/b]
- can get a repetitive feel when played for a longer while

[b]Comment:[/b]
An okay game that makes you think more and more as the levels progress. And think infinitely when playing the random levels that are generated. Overall it is a good "time waster" when you have a couple of minutes to play. Hexcells had a couple of points where you would more or less just guess what tile to choose. Hexcells Plus had a lot of this and it can be really frustrating. Hexcells Infinite is a middle ground netween the two. They fixed most of the complaints I had before, a level can be exited and continued later and there is as many levels as you dare to play. I very recommend this to anyone who likes logic games. Also worth mentioning are two prequels, all three games can be bought in a nice bundle.

No, ano, ale… Ale vlastně jaképak copak; jsou, protože přesně v duchu hesla „na každém šprochu pravdy trochu“ se nepochybně dá říci, že jsou to [i]Miny²[/i]. This is one of the best logic puzzles I've seen in a long time. Unlike Minesweeper, to which this is often compared, there is no guessing necessary. There are many more ways of identifying the number of "mines" in a given area, which allows for more creative puzzles and solutions.

The infinte mode is great for being able to continue playing after beating all 36 pre-designed puzzles, but those pre-defined puzzles give the most challenge. I haven't done a lot of the random puzzles yet, so I'm hoping that some will be harder. The pre-defined levels also introduce you to new concepts as you go, so they are important in order to understand what you are seeing in the infinite mode.

14671635.review:
Hexcells is an expertly-crafted mind-bending game of deduction and observation, reminiscent of two great classic puzzle games, Minesweeper and Picross.

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Fresh gameplay from familiar concepts
+ Puzzles do not require guess-work
+ A good amount of puzzles - each more challenging than the one before it
+ Good difficulty scaling for puzzles
+ Includes a procedurally-generated puzzle mode
+ Concept is simple and easy to pick up, with good tutorials incorporated into the levels
+ Clean minimal UI design keeps the focus on the puzzles
+ Good sound design gives the game a tranquil ambience

[b]Cons[/b]
- Tutorial on -#- notation (World 2-1) is a little unclear and misleading (see below)
- Dat hidden menu button

[b]The -#- Notation (You can skip this if you want)[/b]
The tutorial in World 2-1 explains that a cell with a notation -2- has 2 blue cells around it that are [b]NOT[/b] connected, leading players (or rather, me) to think that [b]NONE[/b] of the blue cells around a cell with such notation may be connected.

Whereas the -#- notation really means that there is [b]at least one space between the blue cells surrounding this cell[/b] - some of the blue cells may still be adjacent, such as in the case of -4-.

According to the tutorial, if there is a cell with the notation -3-, it means that there are three blue cells surrounding that cell, each spaced out from another. In truth, the -3- notation means that that are three blue cells surrounding that cell, where at least one of them is spaced out from another. Meaning, it is possible that two out of three of them may still be adjacent.

The tutorial did not give false information, it just wasn't clear.

[b]Overall[/b]
9/10

14349778.review:
This is a must-buy game for fans of logic puzzles. It is similar in concept to Minesweeper, but is played on a hex grid. Gameplay consists of deducing which hexes are empty and which should be marked blue ("mines"). The similarity to Minesweeper ends there, and Hexcells improves on the experience in a couple of very important ways.

First, the levels in Hexcells are hand-crafted, not the randomized grid of Minesweeper. And the level design is flat-out brilliant. You're led through a series of challenges of gradually increasing complexity, at each point figuring out new ways to combine the information you have and make forward progress. In all, the main levels constitute perhaps 6 to 10 hours of gameplay.

This version of the game (Hexcells Infinite) also includes an infinite mode with computer-generated levels. These aren't quite as aesthetically pleasing as the hand-made levels, but they are still very enjoyable. With infinite mode the game has infinite replayability.

The second thing that makes this game so fun is that all of the puzzles -- including the computer-generated ones in infinite mode -- can be solved using pure logical deduction. No guessing is needed, ever! (One could solve levels using trial and error, but that really isn't in the spirit of the game.) The sense of satisfaction here comes from figuring out the logical deductions, the "aha!" moments, that allow you to advance. The levels are brilliantly designed to give you just enough information -- if you're clever enough to piece it together.

Buy all three of the Hexcells games. Each has different puzzles and all are equally rewarding.

14338661.review:
The third and final Hexcell game, once again, brings only improvements to the game.

Hexcells is a minesweeper-like with hexagons. There is also many other features like "?" marks, line indicators, "blue" numbers, etc... And again, the levels are so awesome and different from randomly generated minesweeper because the game design of these is perfect!
Those are all things that aren't new but they're worth saying because this is the core of the game.

About the new things :

Hexcells is one of my favourite puzzle games in recent years. It is similar to minesweeper, but with an important difference: there is no guesswork, everything can be worked out entirely through logic. So if you ever feel stuck, you know it is not due to poor puzzle design, but because you simply haven't reasoned your way through the next step yet.

There was one small downside to the previous Hexcells games, which is that it didn't remember how far along a puzzle you were when you quit the game. And since some of the later, more complicated puzzles can easily take more than half an hour to figure out, it is a welcome addition to Hexcells Infinite that it now stores your intermediate progress within a puzzle.

If this type of logic puzzle appeals to you, I highly recommend getting the Complete pack containing all three Hexcells games for the full experience.

14102248.review:
Traditional Rating - 95/100
Recommendation - The Best Hexcells Yet!

Remember the free old Windows game Minesweeper? Remember how fun it was finding those hidden mines, and how you could feel your brain scream "NOOOOOOOOOOO" whenever a mine would pop its stupid head up and kill you? Remember how immensely frustrating it was when it was entirely impossible to solve levels without guessing?

WELL, NO MORE! Hexcells to the rescue. 

Hexcells is very similar to Minesweeper in that you have to use various clues and reasoning to find the hidden blue cells on each level, but unlike Minesweeper, Hexcells' soultions can ALWAYS be reasoned, and if you're doing it right you will never have to guess.

The levels start out easy, with simple rules and puzzles, but new tricks are added just regularly enough to fully grasp, and before you know it, you'll find yourself scanning through 15 different criteria to find the 1-in-100 blue cell to start a level off. It's very satisfying.

Speaking of satisfying, the puzzles here never seem overwhelming or too tricky. Take my opinion with a grain of salt (since I have always loved games like this), but the level of difficulty in these puzzles was just perfect, and while some levels did force me to stare at them for a while, the solution was always there somewhere just waiting for me to grab it.

The Hexcells series is really 3 games: Hexcells, Hexcells Plus, and Hexcells Infinite. They each have different puzzles, and they are each worth getting, but Hexcells Infinite is the one to get if you're on a budget. It has the most advanced puzzles, and it includes a random level generator, so you can literally play to your heart's content. All 3 of them will slowly progress you through the mechanics of the game, though, so don't feel like you will be overwhelmed if you jump right into Infinite.

It's worth mentioning that the random levels in Infinite are mere pale shadows compared to the premade levels (they are often quite easy), but for fans that cannot get enough and don't want to go back to the guess-fest Minesweeper, they can be a lot of fun.

I highly recommend this game. If you're a fan of logic-based puzzle games, you can't go wrong with any of these 3 games. The prices are cheap, and the series is rather unique. If the devs could have just tightened up the infinite level generator ever-so-slightly, this game might be the only game I've rated to pass Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons.

Scratch that Minesweeper itch, my friend!

14073583.review:
This is the third game in the Hexcells trilogy, and I definitely recommend that you play the first game (Hexcells) and then the second game (Hexcells Plus).  If you don't, jumping into Hexcells Infinite is going to be extremely difficult.

As the final game in the trilogy, these are the puzzles that separate the men from the boys (or the women from the girls).  They are big, they are complex, and they are at times seemingly impossible.  However, every puzzle does have a solution (with no guessing required), you just need to look at more than just the immediately obvious information, and start looking at the bigger picture.

Even if you finish the set puzzles, you now have the option of playing an "infinite" number of generated puzzles.
(Okay, not infinite, but more than enough that you could never possibly play them all in a single lifetime.)

This game, and the whole trilogy, are definitely worth playing.

14069294.review:
Herní série Hexcells vypadá z obrázků neuvěřitelně složitě, ale skutečnost je zcela opačná. Tento logický výtvor od jediného člověka staví na principech známé hry Minesweeper (česky Hledání min) okořeněné o hexové buňky. Musíte postupně zaplnit herní pole buď šedými nebo modrými políčky. Hra se řídí dle jednoduchých pravidel, která pochopí každý a časem k nim sice přibudou nová, ale opravdu to není nic složitého.

Na začátku máte zpřístupněnou pouze první sadu z celkových šesti. Další sady se odemykají za bodíky, získané z předchozích hádanek. Čím méně chyb uděláte, tím více bodů získáte a tím rychleji se dostanete na konec hry.

Poslední díl každé trilogie musí být epický. A to tenhle splňuje. Uživatelům vadily dvě věci na předchozích dílech - absence ukládání a žádný mód s náhodně generovanými hádankami. A oboje, dámy a pánové, naleznete v tomto skvostu!

Třetí díl s podtitulem Infinite je téměř podobný jako Plus, s tím rozdílem, že nabízí tyto dvě funkce. Můžete mít uložených více hádanek najednou a konečně si tak můžete užít i těžší kousky bez stresování se, jestli budete mít dostatek času na jejich dokončení...

Druhá novinka, díky které dostal tento díl název, je mód Infinite. Pomocí náhodně generovaných úrovní lze hrát až 1 000 000 000 hádanek. A jestli tohle nikoho neohromí, tak je jasné, že tahle série není pro něj.

Zatímco první díl byl jen takovým vstupem do světa Hexcells a druhý přidal na obtížnosti, třetí je oba trumfnul možností ukládat a generovanými hádankami, díky kterým se herní doba prodlouží až do nebeských výšin. Takže všichni, kteří milujete logické hry, kupte si tuhle bezvadnou trilogii a já vám slibuji, že nebudete litovat. Je to jedna z nejlepších her daného žánru a za těch pár euro rozhodně stojí.

13993674.review:
The Hexcells series (Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and now Hexcells Infinite) has been an incremental polishing of a strong concept. The game base mechanics feel like a mix between Sudoku and the old Microsoft Minesweeper.

One difference should be pointed out, though: Sometimes in Minesweeper, you would end up having to guess, because with the information available to you, there were more than one possible solution. Not so in Hexcells. There's [b]always[/b] enough info to get you one step further. You just have to be able to process the information properly. Don't get me wrong - there are times when I've been completely stuck. Some of the later pre-made levels are monstrously tough to do flawlessly. The fact that you [i]know[/i] it's all down to you and your abilities though, makes it more of a challenge and less frustrating.

The ways the information about the board is communicated to you, has been one of the primary points of evolution in the series. To my mind, the developer has been extraordinarily clever in devising new ways give you hints. If you haven't played the earlier games, the major difference for you as a player, is that the boards are much more varied in this version, simply due to the developer having more tools available to play with. The earlier games are good, but this version truly shines.

This latest iteration is called Infinite for a reason, though. He has finally been able to make a level generator, which only needs an 8-digit seed to produce a board. That means if you really want to, there are 100,000,000 boards to play. It's not really infinite, but for all intents and purposes, it might as well be. One of the fun things about this level generator, is that it gives you the possibility to challenge other players to complete the same boards as you do. All you have to do is tell them the seed for that board.

In short, if you're a fan of abstract, number-type puzzles, this game should keep you occupied for quite some time.

Minesweeper meets picross, with minesweeper's pick up and play replay value through randomized puzzles, and picross's criss-crossing clues that ensure you're always provided enough information to complete the puzzle without mistakes or guessing. That description should be enough to instantly decide whether you'd enjoy this game or not. A simple, chill timekiller.

13983201.review:
Hexcells Infinite is a final entry in a trilogy of minesweeper-genre puzzles. Or stand-alone expansion pack, whatever you want to call it. And it comes packing 36 more levels and, guess what, even more level.
This game is pretty much stands for Hexcells fans who just want more and more, because more is more fun. And enjoyable not only for fans.

The formula didn't change. Neither did any art or soundtrack. As players will still have to solve field full of hexes, clearing and tagging the "mines" based on information provided and revealed in these non-randomized puzzles, making your brain go hot. Or rather making your eyes twitch around, trying to find what you missed. While listening to ambient something that is nothingess that is supposed to be sound and soundtrack.
What it gives is 36 more levels. And they are as real deal as in Hexcells Plus, tutorials taking little time before sending you to solve many challenging puzzles. Maybe even slightly harder, one level takes a lot of "what if blue hexes were there" preplanning.
But well, that's about it, the puzzles challenge isn't as different as between Hexcells and Hexcells Plus and Infinite doesn't introduce not even a single new element this time around.
Oh, and you can also easily cheat, by clicking on everything on the map, then remembering it and redoing the puzzle perfectly. Better resist this and instead do it all fairly, restarting upon a single mistake.

Instead it gives you a whole new mode: Infinite mode!  Which brings out a randomizer into play, finally. And it's still more fair than Minesweepers.
Puzzles there are generated from the certain some-digit number, so it could be shared. You are present with few options, where you can either randomly generate it, or you can generate based on current date (so you would know what some others got to experience same puzzle as you today), or you can paste the number (that you saved because you want to farm achievement on easy puzzle or because friend shared with you) or you can continue the puzzle on which you leaved the game.
Puzzles are always made to be so you can figure them out fairly. And well, there are so much you can randomize and keep it fair, that you find the experience actually quite repetive. You will quickly learn the possible field form. All the methods it uses. Even more annoyingly, it can be overloaded with more than enough information. So this much-awaited feature isn't going to last so long either.

It's still probably the best Hexcells out of pack, having levels as good as in Hexcells Plus plus the bonus randomizer feature. Though you still should get the whole bundle.

If you like "Hexcells" or "Hexcells Plus", you should definitely buy this one.

As you would expect, it has new and challenging puzzles. But it is also an incremental update over the previous games:
- It saves the progress of puzzles, so you can exit the game and resume where you left.
- Has a seeded puzzle generator, so you never run out of puzzles (hence the "infinite" in the name).
- Supports custom levels (you can create your own or find some community created ones).
- and other minor improvements.

PS. the level editor is not integrated. It's called "SixCells" and is created and maintained by the community as an opensource project.

13831133.review:
[h1]Minesweeper V34.0 - 10/10[/h1]

[b]Introduction:[/b]
Imagine Hexcells Infinite as a modern version of Minesweeper, only with hexcells, an increased difficulty and well thought out new game mechanisms. You don't need to have played the previous Hexcells games before (count me in), but it's the first Hexcells game, which includes a random puzzle generator, if I'm not mistaken. Therefore the prior titles are obsolete and Hexcells Infinite could be all you need. The objective is similar to Minesweeper: identify all blue fields (bombs) and reveal the whole stage. The hexcells themselves and the new game mechanisms like indicators, which will reveal, how many blue fields are widespreaded in one straight line or how many have to be in a certain area and in which order (in sequence or detached), are great innovations and can deliver a great and satisfying challenge for your brain, especially in huge levels, where you can easily loose the overview and have to count a lot. On average most levels can be solved in 7-20 minutes.

The game has 2 modes: chapter mode (6 chapters with 6 levels per chapter) and infinite mode (generate random levels (8 digit seed number), share your level by sharing your seed number, import seed numbers from friends or simply use the date of the day as seed number)


[b]Pro:[/b]
[list][*]easy to learn, hard to master without doing one single mistake
[*]no gameover if you've done a mistake (BUT you have to replay the whole level, if you want to gain 100% in every level and the related achievement)
[*]no time limit (time will still be logged)
[*]relaxing and zenlike atmosphere/music
[*]36 challenging predefined levels plus random puzzle generator = more puzzles than you will ever play, probably
[*]the random generated levels can be shared with other people
[*]extremely addicting
[*]very high replayability
[*]mid-level saving possible
[*]price[/list]


[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list][*]you could get the ambition to punch someone or destroy something, if you did an unwary turn (again) and have to repeat the same level (again) for perfection (that's no contra, because difficulty is an essential part of logic games, but still....AAAARGH)[/list]


[b]Contra:[/b]
[list][*]surprisingly nothing[/list]


[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Hexcells Infinite is the perfection of an ancient logic puzzle game, simple as that. It's another useful game for a healthy brain workout and I have absolutely nothing to complain about. If you've played Hexcells or Hexcells Plus before and liked it, but you've missed a random puzzle generator, then here it is, the true INFINITE version! It's no problem, if you haven't played Hexcells before. You can learn it easily and have a great time staring at your screen until your eyes pop out of your head. The random puzzle generator guarantees a very high replayability and endless fun. You can get a lot of entertainment for a very fair price. Absolutely recommendable for logic puzzle lovers. Requirement: brain.


[b]10/10[/b]


----------------------

13768016.review:
[h1]At the Time of Writing[/h1]
[b]Game:[/b] Hexcells Infinite
[b]Price:[/b] $5.49*
[b]Genre:[/b] Puzzle
[b]Time Played:[/b] 20 hours
[b]Personal Enjoyment Rating:[/b] ☺ ☺ ☺ ☺ ☺ (out of 5)

[h1]General[/h1]
First of all, I would strongly recommend buying the bundle of Hexcells games if you don't already own any of the previous two.

I've had a slightly rocky road towards enjoying the Hexcells series because I've always felt they were too easy and too short. Hexcells Infinite addresses both of those issues, though with varying success. It has to be said that the concept behind Hexcells is fantastic, and my issues with the games truly stem from wanting more, more, more!

As I said in my Hexcells Plus review, you'll get the most enjoyment out of the game if you  are disciplined and refuse to let yourself make a blind guess. Every puzzle is solvable without making a guess, even when you're absolutely convinced that there is no other option but to guess. You'll find (if you post on the forums) that you've inevitably missed some subtle piece of logic which will get you past the hurdle.

[b]Too Easy[/b]
This issue was addressed in two ways - later puzzles are harder, and community made puzzles - although I don’t find my appetite for these puzzles sated yet. The later puzzles got quite difficult and took me a significant amount of time to solve, which I enjoyed and appreciated. The community made puzzles are a good way of getting some tricky puzzles to do. Lastly, I have to say that I was disappointed to find that the first few worlds were once again a too easy tutorial, and I wish that the tutorial levels had been put into a separate section of the game so that we could have had 6 full worlds of puzzles to exercise “the little grey cells” to quote Poirot.

[b]Too Short[/b]
Again, this second issue was addressed in two ways - infinite mode, and community made puzzles. Infinite mode generates random puzzles for the user to complete and it certainly satisfies the issue of there not being enough puzzles. However, whilst it delivers quantity, it fails at quality. By quality I mean difficulty, because the randomly generate puzzles are far from difficult. It seems like a great idea with potential, but it could definitely do with some difficulty settings so that you can request hard random puzzles. The community made puzzles offer some harder choices to do, but it will take time for the selection to be built up.

[b]Community Puzzles[/b]
I know this is getting a bit long, but this is an interesting new part of this particular Hexcells game. I will point you to the post that explains it and strongly suggest that you watch the two videos there because they do all the explaining (I originally didn’t bother to watch them and was confused for it). It is very easy to play custom puzzles, you simply copy the puzzle to the clipboard, open Hexcells, and click the option in the bottom right to play a custom puzzle. Making your own puzzles is something I haven’t yet explored. One note is that I’ve learned to mostly avoid any that have custom rules because the logic sometimes seems a bit sketchy leaving you to guess.

[b]Community Puzzle Links[/b]**
[list][*][url=http://steamcommunity.com/games/304410/announcements/detail/233383138547016335]Hexcells Infinite Announcement - Custom Level Support[/url]
[*][url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/304410/discussions/0/613936673556813085/]Hexcells Inifinite > General Discussions > Topic Details > “Level Editor: Create and Play Custom Levels!”[/url]
[*][url=http://www.reddit.com/r/hexcellslevels/]Hexcells Infinite community shared levels on Reddit[/url][/list]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The concept of this game is wonderful. It adds a few levels of complication than Minesweeper and the solutions are all attainable through pure logic. No guesses are required, if they are sometimes tempting to do, so get in touch with your inner vulcan mind.

Some of those complications I mentioned include:
[list][*]cells are hexagons
[*]hint numbers are quite varied, and form a set of logical rules 
[list][*]in cells
[*]at the top of columns/rows
[*]signify that "mines" are adjacent
[*]signify that "mines" can not be adjacent
[*]a larger hex area has a certain number of "mines"
[/list][/list]

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Very simple - right click and left click. Plus, now featuring a button in-game to flip the button functions! Rejoice! This can also still be changed about in the options dialogue that pops up when opening the game.

Although, by this time I've become entirely accustomed to them and didn't make too many stupid mistakes by hitting the wrong button. 

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
No storyline, doesn't need one.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Relaxing gentle zen echoey noises. Also, when you click a cell you get nice tinkling chime-like noises. I don't know why that makes it more satisfying to click on cells, but it does! It's fun to go back to the really easy puzzles and click through like mad to get a cascade of tinkling noises.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Very crisp, clean, and clear. The numbers are reasonably large. Some puzzles form an interesting overall image or pattern, and overall, the puzzles come across as well designed. There is also an option in-game to make blue cells with numbers have a different outline effect.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]+ [/b]crisp clean graphics whose job is to be functional
[b]+ [/b]simple controls to grasp
[b]+ [/b]more interesting concept than random old Minesweeper
[b]+ [/b]improvements over the first two games
[b]+ [/b]community made puzzles create more variety
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]- [/b]still lacking in [b]really[/b] tough puzzles
[b]- [/b]the random puzzles are too easy

[h1]Help Me Help You[/h1]
[b]If you did not find this review helpful,[/b] I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

[h1]Rothana's Steam Review Archive[/h1]
For those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: [b]rothana dot weebly dot com[/b]

13300978.review:
--Revised Review--
So, after getting some other replies commenting that I wasn't giving fair review to the game, I've decided to give  another shot before revising the review. I brewed some coffee, have some nice cookies on plate. Clicked the game, headphones on, play time. 

Things that I noticed, is that this game is incredibly logical. Horsemedic (guy who commented) was right, this game is entirely made out of logic, to the point of ridiculousness. 
One of the rule, "-#- means that blue numbers of panels are NOT connected", sounds quite simple, but when you think about it, this phrase DID NOT say "ALL blue panels are NOT connected". Which means, there is at least one panel that isn't next to each other, but has no guarantee in -3- as this can have 3 blue panels that are not connected, or have pair that is next each to other and have one separated. While this only make the game confusing, it still is, following the rule of the game.

Further that I played, I noticed that this "hole" of the rule isn't conflicting the game at all. If you get stuck, you can look for other clues. Eventually you'll hit the spot you were stuck on, but with more clues to help out. 

I've already said in the last review but the graphic and music are top notch. I like the color use of this game, it's gentle and comfortable to see it for long time. Music is very relaxing, good soothing sound.

I guess, the only complain that I can make at this point is that I wish there were spread sheet of set of rules instead of explaining it beliefly and let you try it out during the gameplay. (which helps too but isn't very clear sometime) As understanding the set of rules become the most crucial part of this game I think developer could have spent a little more time for it. Maybe, on the first Hexcell, it might have been more user friendly. I haven't tried it yet.

As a last note, this is NOT a minesweeper. Who ever said it is, did not think enough through like me. The format is very close to it, I agree, but the minesweeper somtime takes you to a gamble while Hexcell can make "educated guess" to clear without making single mistake. 

So let me say it again- this game, is NOT a minesweeper. It is more like a Sudoku. Don't expect be like one; this game has no timer, nor any score system for it. Take your time. Grab coffee or tea. Rewind your brain and take the challenge. 

I recommend this game.

[h1]Short Review[/h1]
A fun little puzzle game akin to Mine Sweeper. Plus is the follow up game to Hexcells, adding more levels. A final entry to the series called Hexcells Infinite rounds out the series with a random puzzle generator allowing the ability to play forever!

[h1]Score[/h1]

13233535.review:
This series is criminally overlooked.

If you enjoy games like sudoku, you will find logical puzzles here that work your brain for hours. While a naive comparison, the game plays similarly to a very advanced Minesweeper. By the second act, though, you'll have discovered the futility of that comparison; this game is on an entirely different level and has an elegance in the solutions that random Minesweeper puzzles cannot ever hope to achieve.

A couple of the puzzles stumped me for more than 90 minutes, and my roommate rapidly grew tired of me talking the solution out loud as I moved my mouse around. There's a brilliant simplicity to the gameplay and yet, while playing, one must keep a large amount of logic in their head. It's easy to get overwhelmed by logic in one area of the puzzle while overlooking the simple move forward in another area, and the feeling is intense when you slap your forehead in stupidity on discovering it.

The soundtrack is quite relaxing, and even after working on the same puzzle for an hour it did not grow tiresome. It's really fun when you get on a "roll" of solving the puzzle, too, because you generate little ditties as a reward.

The only negative of Infinite compared to the rest of the series is the randomly-generated puzzles. The developer added these so that he could put a bow on the series and call it done and, while they do indeed fill a gap, you can tell they're a far different experience than the handmade puzzles (don't worry, Infinite has the same number of handmade puzzles as the previous two). Sudoku has this issue, too, and it's just the nature of puzzle generation algorithms. Still, if you're dying for a new puzzle, they might hold you over, otherwise I'd just play them for the achievement.

At any rate, I've found if I step away from a puzzle or play others, I forget a solution, so you could probably revisit the entire series in a few weeks' time and have a whole new game.

The entire Hexcells series contains puzzles that are among the greatest I've ever solved. I highly recommend the entire collection, and also very strongly recommend that you start with Hexcells. It is easier than the other two, this one included, by far. Definitely, though, work up to this one. Absolutely worth your purchase.

For perspective, I am not the greatest logician, and I invested about 13 hours solving this campaign -- for 13 hours of gameplay, this game is a steal.

13217364.review:
I love the multidirectionality of Hexcells Infinite: solving a single cell can affect three lines of cells, as well as the set of surrounding cells. At first, it felt much like a hexagonal version of Minesweeper. When the lines were added, I was reminded of nonograms / paint-by-numbers puzzles. Then, as the puzzles continued, my mind became so occupied with the intersecting logic that I stopped trying to compare it to other games at all. 

The level design is excellent, and the puzzle progression slowly encourages you to learn new solving techniques, with no huge jumps in difficulty. In addition to the handmade puzzles, Hexcells Infinite includes a random puzzle generator to increase your playtime, and add a nice break when you get stuck in the main game. 

Hexcells Infinite improves on the previous versions by allowing you to save your progress in every. In spite of that, it may be worth also getting Hexcells Plus for the additional puzzles, and the slightly easier difficulty.

12513716.review:
Absurdly addictive game - I love the Hexcells series. They fixed one of my major gripes from previous iterations with this one in that when you exit a puzzle, it saves your progress so that you can continue at a later date. My only two issues remaining are as follows: 1) you cannot see, on the main map screen, which levels you have perfected (no mistakes), which is irritating if you are going for the perfect score; 2) you have to be 100% sure of every tile if you are going for the perfectionist badge as there is no 'undo' option, so one mistake on a massive grid means beginning all over again.

That said, I'm a perfectionist, and I get mad with myself when I make mistakes! If you haven't played these games, check them all out. Infinite introduces the 'infinite' puzzle mode, which relies on seed-based generation to present you with one of one million puzzles to work on, so it will keep you going for a while! That said, many of the generated levels (having completed over 60 at this point) are the same map with different layouts of blues and greys - unsurprising, but I seem to get one map in particular quite a lot.

Highly recommended for puzzle fans. I came onto this from a Picross background, and I think I like this even more!

12494877.review:
A fantastic game. It has been called a cross between minesweeper and picross, and the description fits the basic mechanics. The game is soothing, with great sound and visual design, and with no time pressure. Although it doesn't end when you make a mistake, instead allowing you to continue playing, it does encourage you to keep mistakes to a minimum by giving you a score at the end of the puzzle, which is used to unlock furthur puzzles.

As for the puzzle design itself, the puzzles that come with the game have a great difficulty curve, but one which works best if you've played the first two games. It starts off with a refresher on the mechanics, but quickly becomes devilishly difficult. I fully recommend sleeping on some of them and coming back with a fresh pair of eyes; this is something the game lets you do, as you can end a puzzle and come back at any time. One potential issue with this is that it forgets which clues you have highlit or dismissed, although you may consider that to be a good thing as it forces you to reconsider every clue when you come back to the puzzle.

The automatically-generated "infinite" puzzles are much less difficult, but still fun for the most part. There is also a level editor that can be found on reddit, and a subreddit for user-made levels, which can be very fun.

I heartilly recommend getting the complete pack and playing all three games in order, for anyone even mildly interested. A fantastic puzzle game all round.

Das Grundprinzip kommt einem im ersten Moment noch aus Minesweeper bekannt vor, aber es werden schnell immer weitere Mechaniken eingeführt, womit das Spiel deutlich schwieriger und interesannter wird.

Das Grundspiel bietet einen guten Einstieg in das Spiel und ist sehr interessant. Hexcells Infinite habe ich mir wegen dem auf ein Seeding basierten Levelgenerator geholt. Die damit erstellten Level sind zwar i.d.R leichter, als die vorgefertigten, machen aber durchaus Spass und können auch fordnernd werden. 

Perfekter Rätselspass für zwischendurch.

12292493.review: Put simply, if the answer to whether you enjoy puzzle games is a "yes", then by all means buy this.

12286483.review:
Hexcells Infinite, like its predecessors, is a puzzle game which features minesweeper-like playstyle on a hexagonal grid. In it, you are given information about the number of specific tiles (and some context clues of where they lie), and must use logic to determine where the tiles are.

Hexcells Infinite picks up where Plus left off and once more has an excellent level of challenge throughout. In addition to this, it has a random level generator with 1 billion (yes, you read that right) levels available. Furthermore, if you check the Steam forums, they're putting out a tool which lets users create levels then share the keys. While this isn't quite as nice as having integrated Steam Workshop support where people can rate and download those levels automatically, it provides nigh on infinite replayability within the game. I'd recommend picking up the whole trilogy, but if you're going to pick up a single Hexcells game, this is it. Tons of fun.

12278641.review:
The easy and immediate comparison here is to minesweeper. This game starts off pretty much the same; numbers in cells telling you how many of the adjacent cells are part of the "pattern" of the level (incidentally, for people who have played a lot of minesweeper like me, the left and right mouse butons will be swapped around from what you might expect, which caused me a few mistakes early on, but I eventually got used to it). Of course the cells are hexagonal rather than square, but it is still VERY minesweeper to start with (the one major difference being that in this game you never have to guess; you're welcome to if you want, but you can always work it out somehow).

It really starts to pick up as you play through though; new rules to play to are introduced- you are given numbers of cells that must be adjacent, numbers that aren't adjacent, numbers over entire columns or diagonal lines of the game's grid and finally numbers that tell you how many cells up to two cells away are in the pattern.

Every rule is simple, and they're introduced at a good pace that lets you get used to them before the next one comes along. But the sum of the 6 or 7 simple rules and the large variety in sizes and shapes of game grids provides some fabulously complicated puzzles; and they seem to be done in such a way so that there are any number of places to get stuck, not just one incredibly hard point per level that a lot of other puzzle games seem to end up with.

I haven't tried too many of the randomly generated levels- you can use 8 digit seeds to create levels (theoretically 100 million of them)- the ones I have had a go at are obviously not as well crafted as the main levels in the games "campaign", but they did offer more difficulty than I expected, so I was pleased by that as well.

TL:DR; This is like a harder, much more complicated and polished minesweeper with more rules to remember; leading to more variety in the levels, with the added advantage that there is no guessing required. It's great for anyone who likes logic puzzles.

12273302.review:
I'm usually not the biggest fan of straight-up puzzle games (with the exception of the likes of Tetris or Bejeweled), but the Hexcells series has really gripped me. Especially Infinite, since the puzzle generator can make, well, an infinite number of puzzles. Not as clever as the hand-crafted puzzles that are also included, but still nice. Either way, it's really rather calming to listen to the soothing music and sound effects as you kinda zone out and let the hexagons consume you. 

Full disclosure: Crispix is my favorite cereal.

12258600.review: J'ai trouvé le second (Hexcells Plus) plus compliqué à terminer. Mais c'est toujours un plaisir de se lancer dans les puzzles proposés par le créateur. La fonction infinite est enfin arrivée, proposant le générateur de niveau et allongeant grandement la durée de vie. Même si les niveaux aléatoires ont tendance à tous se ressembler et à être peu difficile, j'attendais cela depuis le premier.

12237990.review:
Hexcell Infinity is very similair to its predessors Hexcell and Hexcell Plus. In this version of the game there is a additional random puzzle generator which is very challenging.

This game is very similar to the Mine swiper game you find in any version of Windows, but with a little twist. The idea of the puzzles is very simple. I found this version of the game a bit harder than the other games. Also I believe that there are more situations whereby you need to make an outright guess. This spoils the michanic of the game a little.

Like the orginal game, it does get fustrating in the last couple of stages were the puzzles get bigger. Specially if you are after the achivements.

The music and sound is very good and compliments the game well. However after long play it does get a little repetative and you may want to switch the music off.
