12234425.review:
(9/10) - Near Perfection

I had my hopes up a few months ago when i learned, that the third installment of hexcells will have infinite levels.
I wish i could tell you that they were completly satisfied, but sadly i can´t.
Don´t get me wrong: the puzzles are still fun and you really never have to guess. It´s funny seeing this game accomplish something with way more difficult rules that microsoft coudln´t (looking at minesweeper right now).
But still, they are sadly too easy. They all feel the same and after a little while, i just got bored.
No comparison to what this game still does perfectly: The actual game.
The levels created by Mr. Brown are once again extremly well executed and with them, i would recommend this game to anyone enjoying thinking a lot and from time to time putting some numbers into the puzzle.

12229919.review: If you like logic puzzles Hexcells will be right up your alley.  No guessing needed to solve the puzzles.  Even randomly generated puzzles are fair and you can figure them out without needing to guess on the last piece.  Music is very calming and revealing pieces makes part of the tune which is a neat little feature.  I highly recommend this to anyone who likes logic puzzles.

12225414.review:
Overall, very happy with buying Hexcells Infininte. It builds on the previous two iterations (Hexcells and Hexcells Plus), adding another level of difficulty to the puzzles. Similar to Sudoku in that it's a very logic-based puzzle game, using deduction to find out which tiles are blue/black. In previous Hexcells, there were often multiple ways to solve a puzzle, in Infinite, it's often the case that there is only one approach to solving a level, which I found enjoyable and frustrating at times, staring at the puzzles in hopes of finding that one clue to progress onwards.

What's new in this iteration is the addition of a level generator, which takes a number as a seed. Played around 70 of these so far and they're very varying in difficulty. Some that I've played can seem to be very similar. Also added in is the ability to save mid-level.

Well worth it for the price for a few hours' casual enjoyment and easy to pick up for a quick puzzle (or ten!).

12208459.review: Finally, a version of Hexcells that I can play forever. This game may be best described as a severely upgraded Minesweeper. However, I feel that that description falls a bit short. The replacement of Minesweepers grid with a hex layout and the addition of different clue types makes this game an almost dangerously addictive puzzler. The result is a challenging, yet easy-going test of your logic skills. And now that the game has a random puzzle generator, I've had to push my bedtime back by a solid hour.

12135083.review: The first two were great, this one is more of that greatness, with a new twist towards the end. Infinite puzzle mode is a nice addition, though the levels in it don't have quite the same hand-crafted feel as the main levels, and are never as hard.

12122589.review:
"минер" с дополнительными правилами и возможностью игры на случайно-генерируемых уровнях, помимо 36 базовых. Есть сохранение прогресса уровня и стим-клауд. Правила, которые я успел открыть:

(List of rules:)
- числа в скобках в пустой (черной) клетке означают, что в соседних клетках мины расположены одной цепочкой, без разрыва. 
- числа с минусами в пустой (черной) клетке означают, что в соседних клетках мины расположены с разрывом/-вами. 
- числа над гексами указывают на количество мин в данном ряду (ряд можно подсвечивать или снимать отметку кликом по цифре). Верхнее число включает в себя и нижние значения (т.е. из верхнего надо вычитать нижнее, если они в одном ряду, и тогда мы получим кол-во мин в "промежутке" между числами).
- разрывом в ряду (для дополнительного условия {n} или -n-) считается не отсутствие гекса как такового, а именно отсутствие мины в нем (черный гекс).
- числа в синих клетках (минах) говорят, что в области двух клеток от данной будет находиться указанное кол-во мин.

Генератор понимает только числа (до 8 цифр) в качестве сида, что дает вам 100 миллионов возможных вариантов паззла. Если тратить 7 минут на решение каждого по 8 часов в день, то на решение всех вариантов уйдет 3995 лет  (thanks to Nemonical-Yves for this info)

Признаюсь, брал из-за генератора, но, как оказалось, карты он штампует уж совсем несложные. Треть гексов закрашиваешь на автомате, все время попадаются "закрась 4 из 4" или "0 из 0". А вот уровни в сценарии , напротив, порадовали. Четвертая глава (из 6) уже требует расчета  наложения трех параметров. В ней уже бывает сложно открыть даже первый гекс.

12104163.review: This is basically what you would get if Minesweeper was actually a good game and you could actually win. Also, recommended are Hexcells and Hexcells Plus.  They're all cheap enough that you might as well buy them together.  If you cannot afford to buy them, then sell your plasma or become a surrogate mother.  You won't regret it.

12104124.review: Hexcells Infinite: it's still the solid puzzle game I keep pointing out in Hexcells/Hexcells Plus, but this time it's on a slightly tighter engine and it comes with an "Infinite" mode where, in addition to the usual 36 handmade levels, there's now a seed-driven set of "infinite" puzzles you can go through. It literally turns the game into hex-grid Minesweeper. I will probably never uninstall this because of that. It's still only $5. HOP ON THIS GAME.

12095295.review:
킬링타임용으로 좋다
로직/지뢰찾기 짬뽕해놓은 느낌
도타하면서 매칭잡을때, 캐릭 죽었을 때, 그냥 시간때우고 싶을때 하면 시간 잘간다.

숫자는 검은색 육각형 안에 있는것, 육각형 밖에 있는 것, 푸른 색 육각형 안에 있는것으로 나뉜다
숫자는 기본적으로 숨겨져있는 푸른색 박스의 갯수를 말함

검은색 육각형의 숫자는 맞닿고 있는 칸(검은색 육각형을 둘러싼 1줄)중 파란색 칸의 갯수
육각형 퍼즐 밖의 숫자는 그 열의 칸 중 파란색 칸의 갯수 (숫자 클릭하면 열 확인 가능)
푸른색 안의 숫자는 클릭하면 영역이 지정되는데, 이 영역안에 있는 파란색 칸의 갯수임. 
 (파란색 육각형을 둘러싼 2줄. 일단 영역 클릭하면 바로 이해할 수 있음.클릭한 칸은 빼고 셀것)

그냥 숫자는 무작위로 파란색 칸이 존재함
{숫자}는 각 갯수의 파란색이 연이어서 존재함
-숫자-는 각 갯수의 파란색이 어딘가 무조건 끊어져서 존재함.
(예를 들면 -3-은 1/1/1로 끊어져있거나 1/2 또는 2/1등으로 끊어져있음)

단계별로 패턴이 차례대로 나오니, 각종 변수는 플레이하면서 익히면 된다.
키설정같은경우, 인피니티는 인게임 들어가서 좌측 하단에 마우스 아이콘 클릭하면 바꿀 수 있다.
헥셀즈와 헥셀즈 플러스는 게임 실행전 해상도 조절하는 창에서 수동으로 바꾸면 된다.

겜하다가 자꾸 지뢰찾기랑 마우스 버튼 헷갈려서 둘이 바꿔서 플레이했다.
(기본설정이 지뢰찾기와는 반대로 되어있다고 생각하면 쉬움.)

시리즈는 헥셀즈/헥셀즈 플러스/헥셀즈 인피니티가 존재하는데
헥셀즈플러스부터  파란색 육각형 안에 숫자가 나오는 패턴이 등장한다
헥셀즈/헥셀즈 플러스는 한번 다 깨고나면 끝이지만
인피니티는 무한대 모드가 존재하며, 랜덤 SEED를 클릭하면 수없이 많은 종류의 퍼즐을 즐길 수 있다.

3가지 시리즈 전부 1단계~6단계가 존재하며, 실수가 적을 수록 '블럭'을 더욱 많이 획득하게 되는데
각 단계에서 이걸 일정 갯수를 모아야 그 다음단계를 도전하는 방식. 단계가 올라가야 다양한 패턴을 맛볼 수 있다.
각 단계는 6개의 스테이지로 이루어져있고, MISTAKE(실수)를 0~1번이내에 끝내게 되면
그 스테이지는 퍼펙트처리가 되어 윤기나는 칸으로 바뀐다
그런데 3시리즈 모두 공통점이 단계모드를 플레이하다보면 찍어야 할 경우가 많아서 스트레스 받음ㅋㅋㅋ
하지만, 문제가 다 똑같아서 그림판으로 찍은담에 똑같이 찍으면 퍼펙트는 어렵지 않음
참고로, 도전과제 따려면 3시리즈 모두 36개의 스테이지를 퍼펙트로 깨면 됨. (그림판 복붙노가다)

스테이지 깰때는 그냥 도전과제 딸라고 스트레스 받으면서 할 정도지만
인피니티 무한대모드는 정말 심심풀이용으로 잘 쓰고 있음ㅋㅋ
스테이지 모드보다 쉬운 문제도 많고 똑같이 고통 주는 문제도 있고 재밌다 

나는 헥셀즈 세일하길래 한번 즐기고나서 다른 시리즈 정가에 다 구매해서 플레이했지만
세일기간에 생각나면 질러서 플레이하면 퍼즐 좋아하는 사람은 정말 후회 안한다. ㅇㅇ
근데 시리즈 자체가 가격이 싼편이라 부담없으면 다 질러서 해보는것도 좋고
인피니티만 구매해서 하는게 제일 돈 절약하는 방법이다.

헥셀즈 인피니티 사세요
세일할 때 사면 더 좋음~

12064765.review:
More Hexcells is always welcome, and Hexcells Infinite delivers.  It includes more puzzles with Hexcells Plus-like difficulty, albeit with an extended tutorial section for new players.  There are no new puzzle mechanics, just a procedural puzzle generator capable of producing millions of potential puzzles.  This puzzle generator turned out rather disappointing, unfortunately.  Most of the puzzles it generates are very similar and can be blazed through very quickly due to lots of obvious clues.  None of them come anywhere close to the difficulty of the hand-made puzzles.  That is a general problem with procedurally-generated content though.  It's extremely difficult to make it as good as hand-made content.

Despite the disappointing puzzle generator, the game is just as fun as previous Hexcells and I highly recommend it to puzzle game fans.

12041824.review:

12024714.review:
The third and most likely final sibling in the Hexcells family, Hexcells Infinite, like its title suggests, provides an infinite game experience: in addition to another set of 36 hand-crafted levels, it includes a random puzzle generator!

The hand-crafter levels are about as difficult as the ones in Hexcells Plus, or marginally easier (either that, or I'm just getting better at solving them.) I regret that only one of them provides special instructions (in this case "each column contains an odd number of blue cells") as I feel more of them would benefit the challenge variety. This absence is also partially responsible for the scarcity of satisfying "aha" moments, when several clues combine beautifully into a challenging part of the solution. Previous games had me complaining about the puzzles' less than perfect elegance: you usually have quite more clues than you really need. This is still a problem, even if it's now marginally less severe than it was. Another issue, especially for newcomers, is that nowhere in the instructions does the game direct your attention to the box at the top left corner, containing the number of yet undiscovered blue cells, even though it's an essential information for many of the puzzles. All of that didn't stop me from enjoying the 36 puzzles and feeling a real satisfaction each time I could perfect one. They are more missed opportunities than mortal sins.

The real attraction of Hexcelles Infinite, of course, is the randomly generated levels. There are 100 millions of them, so there is no risk of running out before growing completely tired of Hexcells. You can let the computer choose or you can specify a seed yourself, so it's easy to share a level with your friends . There is an option to use the date as a seed as well, and have a "puzzle of the day", but don't expect a leaderboard for it, à la Spelunky. The real question is this: "Are the randomly-generated puzzles as good as the hand-crafted one?" Predictably, the answer is no. Mainly because the elegance issue, that I mentioned above, is considerably worse. Random levels are chock-full of redundant clues, and lack any kind of the symmetry that makes a puzzle attractive. I find that a real shame, as it shouldn't be too difficult to devise an algorithm that gets rid of some of the redundancy, and maybe couple it with a difficulty setting. Are the random puzzles good enough to sustain interest? Your mileage may vary, depending on whether you play casually, or seriously. "Serious" players will lament the low difficulty. Most of them took me less than 4 minutes and I've yet to find one that I couldn't solve in less than 10. But that may be exactly what you're looking for, and as a way to relax and pass a bit of time, the random puzzle generator is serviceable. Nevertheless, my impression is that those that enjoy the kind of challenge offered by the 36 main levels, will find the random ones too trivial for their taste.

Audio-visually, Hexcells Infinite is identical to its predecessors. You get the same white, blue and yellow colours, the same menu presentation, the same ambient soundscapes... It's all very nice and stylish, but a bit of variety, like selectable visual themes, for example, would have been welcome.

Hexcells Infinite is the best Hexcells yet. It feature another 36 good, difficult puzzles and the random number generator has the potential to satisfy your need for casual puzzle solving during a great many hours.

12020679.review:
While Hexcells Plus still is the best of the 3 Hexcells titles(featuring the most balanced puzzle set) more Hexcells is never a bad thing and Infinite is certainly worth picking up. Though having said that, while most definitely recommended, it is not without flaws either.

In Infinite there is a difficulty jump in some puzzles, unfortunately in such a way that you feel rewarded by guessing more than in Plus. The obscurity of or mental notation required for some late game "hints" without any method to make notations in game(ie: Minesweeper question marks or Sudoku progams often having multiple number entry "scratch paper" type options) can feel overwhelming, and hurts the general relaxing ambiance of the series as it introduces an element of frustration not present in the previous two games.

The Infinite puzzle generator is also a bit of a bust. While a wonderful idea, the unfortunate truth is that random generated puzzles in this sort of game simply can't compare with hand crafted(and the developer does an excellent job at that). And as there is no difficulty option when generating the puzzles, you are often thrown a near endless parade of fairly simple(and overly large for that simplicity) boards. Rather than the random generator, being able to access player designed puzzle might be a better option for extending the life of the game, be it through workshop integration or simply allowing a puzzle editor that would provide a sharable code as the random seed generator does now.

Anyway, bottom line is this: Any Hexcells is amazing, but if you have to choose between one of the three go with Plus still. The original is far too easy and Infinite simply isn't quite as elegant as Plus's puzzles.

The third Hexcells game. Based on the same formula. Surely the welcome's been worn out, yeah?

No. It's even better than the first two. And they were already great. This one starts out a little more difficult than its predecessors, and feels finely tuned throughout. You'll not want for challenge, especially towards the end. And still, it's not frustrating. It's always logical. Always. Even when you're convinced it can't be.

11984674.review:
当年刚接触电脑的时候，我就曾经玩上面微软自带的扫雷玩几个通宵；不过在玩了几个通宵之后迅速就脱坑了，因为扫雷有很严重的问题，那就是地雷和提示线索是自动生成的，一局里有太多的地方需要完全靠运气乱蒙，很多时候不蒙甚至连第一步都没法点，蒙的时候被炸死了觉得太冤了，久而久之就没什么游戏的热情了。

Hexcells 系列刚出的时候我顿时眼前一亮，比起扫雷不但增加了几个简明但是并不简陋的提示规则，而且每一关都经过了精心设计，提示条件是“充分但不必要”的，就是说每一步的决断都肯定会给你至少一条线索让你推导，但是有可能会有多余的线索，总之没有一关会有需要你蒙和猜的场合出现。虽然靠乱猜乱点过关更加轻松，但是并不推荐这么玩，那其实是很大的浪费。唯一可惜的是，第一作和第二作总共也只有72关，虽然很多关比较难，解决之后很有思考的快感，但是玩通之后也就再也没有重复的必要了。

本作名为无限，实际上也确实解决了前两作的弊端，可以近乎无限地玩下去，为这个系列完成了圆满的收官。除了常规模式的36关之外，制作组终于研制出了自动生成关卡的算法。我曾经以为这是像扫雷的自由模式那样，随机安排地雷，牺牲了推理过程中的严谨性，应该也会出现那种条件不足，不得不纯靠运气的场合。但是制作组巧妙地运用提示规则的生成机制解决了这一问题，无限模式我已经玩了几十局，至今依然没有发现条件不足的场合，我觉得这甚至可以说是游戏史上史无前例的一场革命，至少对扫雷迷来说是这样。当然，比起精心设计的常规模式来说，难度是被大幅下降了。但是胜在耐玩性被无限提高了。无限模式靠输入八位数列来生成关卡，理论上有99,999,999种不同的关卡，就算每一关用10分钟解决，也足够玩上几千万个小时了——当然如果有人能坚持一直玩下去的话。

最后还有两点感觉比较遗憾：1.如果这游戏能用上steam的排行榜甚至就对战功能就好了，我相信那将会成为不亚于俄罗斯方块的经典好游戏；2.这游戏其实更加适合手游和移动主机，只在PC上推出着实有些浪费了。

评分：10/10

11974893.review:
The whole Hexcells series is great, but Infinite really completes the trilogy perfectly. The basic Minesweper-like premise of uncovering and filling in hexagons based on numerical clues remains, but the premade puzzles are more well thought out than ever. You are able to save your progress and come back later, a welcome addition, as well as restarting without having to exit the level entirely. 

The infinite puzzle generator is the real draw of this game, and it does not disappoint. The algorithm doesn't generate puzzles that are quite as clean and stripped down as the main game; there are often redundant clues. This also means they tend to be easier, though, which comes as a relief to me after spending an hour unsuccessfully wrestling with a level 6 puzzle. I was a little apprehensive about the procedurally generated levels; I was reminded of Minesweeper's frequent guesses and subsequent frustration. There's no guessing required, though, at least in the levels I played. Really, having played the other two games in the series, I should have known better. There are daily puzzles (specifically, puzzles using the current date as the seed), and you can also play random puzzles. If you like, you can use the seed of a given puzzle and share it to challenge your friends.

All in all, if you like this sort of puzzle game, you should pick up Hexcells Infinite. It's worth it at full price. I'd recommend getting the others as well. Hexcells seems fairly easy to me in retrospect, but Hexcells Plus is every bit as hard as this game.

11973923.review:
Very much the same as Hexcells and Hexcells Plus with some interesting new puzzles, and the same gentle introduction to the various hint mechanics. Unlike the previous two games, this one also includes an "infinite" mode - procedurally generated puzzles that is effectively endless. Generally speaking the procedurally generated puzzles are a lot easier to solve, but still fun and a great way to get into a zen groove if you're a fan of these logic puzzles.

Would very much recommend this to anyone who liked the first two, or is a fan of logic puzzles. Looking forward to seeing what Matthew Brown comes up with next!

不过一些细节上的改进还是让人觉得舒服不少：单击菜单可以选择重新游戏，而不用像前作那样重新选择关卡；退出当前关卡时会对进度进行保存，下一次就能继续了，再也不用因为某些情况从头来过；可以选择左右键的作用，如果觉得默认的操作方式不舒服那就换一下。

This thing is intense and a marked improvement over its predecesor.  The packaged puzzles are mind-bendingly difficult.  I've played for six hours and I'm only 50% of the way through the game.

However, there's also an "infinate" mode -- where you can use a random number generator (or today's date) to create a puzzle that is less imposing but still a lot of fun.  This adds the replayability that was missing from the first title.

11952700.review:
After a couple of hours playtime, I can honestly say that the game is everything I was hoping for.
If you didn't like the first two installments, don't bother with this one either since it didn't bring anything new to the table gameplay-wise when compared to Plus. It's essentially an ultimate version with some _really_ hard levels, where you can stare at the board for ten minutes at a time before you have deduced the next possible step.

The logic involved seems to me to be a bit more advanced than in Plus sometimes. There are for example more occasions, in which the puzzles require counting the remaining blues and determining by addition of unsaturated column-restrictions and number-blocks, that there is no possible way that some unrelated  cells could be anything other than blacks (or blues), often giving you the decisive hint to complete the puzzle.

I'm three levels short of completing the game, but will pause for now, since it's getting late and sleeping during work hours is for some reason frowned upon at my job. But the level-generator is certainly great for long-term motivation and I can see myself going back to it every now and again, even if the resulting puzzles don't seem to be as challening or clever than the hand-made ones.

In terms of presentation, little has changed compared to Hexcells Plus. Wouldn't have needed to anyway, in my opinion. Saving puzzles is nice though when you're stuck, and as someone who enjoys watching tv-shows or listening to music while playing, the option to turn off music and sound separately is great and much appreciated.

In conclusion: Truly good successor with very well designed puzzles and another difficulty-increase. The level-generator is the icing on the cake, I recommend this game to every puzzle-fan. Though if you've never played any hexcell-game, you might as well start with Plus (or even the original, which I've personally found a bit too easy, but still makes an excellent tutorial to the series). Just play them all in order, and continue playing infinite for the random-puzzles once you're done with the handcrafted levels! :)

11949223.review:
After 20 (oops, 100 now) hours of gameplay, I have completed the game, made more than 5 levels in the level editor, and won +100 randomly generated levels, and perfected every single level (the other hours are there because someone else is playing on slot 2), all I can say: this game is one of the best puzzle games i've played.

Remember when you thought that Hexcells Plus was hard? Ha, Hexcells Infinite just laughs at that.
The puzzles are so well made and most of the time you'll stare at your screen for a good 10 minutes until you see what you have to do for the next step, and often it turns out to be the most simple thing, the game hides its clues very well in the least obvious way possible, so I really recommend playing the first two games before this one to get you ready, but before you do that, i'll let you know, that no matter what, there is no need to guess in all of the Hexcells games at all, so try to think twice before you make your next move!

And now, the new stuff! Randomly generated levels, I find them pretty enjoyable, they are all possible without guessing, which is impressing! The only problem I have with them is that they are kind of "too easy" compare to Hexcells Infinite levels, but I don't blame the creator for that, they are still very enjoyable to solve. 

And the last thing left, the level editor, yes you heard me, a LEVEL EDITOR, everyone likes level editors (Ri.. right??), however, the level editor does not come with the game and needs to be downloaded from the Steam Community, but I didn't really mind that, the level editor also has an auto-solver that tries to solve your puzzles to make sure they are 100% possible without guessing, and I find that neat, the editor is fun to mess around with, and will sure give you a few hours of enjoyment. 

And now for my final opinion:
Hexcells Infinite is a MUST for any puzzle fan, it's great, fun, cheap, and has a great replay value because of the randomly generated levels and the level editor.

*If you liked Hexcells Infinite you may also like:*
- Hexcells and Hexcells Plus.
- Squarecells. 
- Crosscells.
Every other puzzle game made by the same developer, basically.
